trans-unit.source: This is the Eucalyptus Administration Guide. The guide shows you how to access Eucalyptus with a web-based GUI and with command line tools. This guide also describes how to perform common administration tasks in three areas: system management, identity management, and resource management.
trans-unit.target: This is the Eucalyptus Administration Guide. The guide shows you how to access Eucalyptus with a web-based GUI and with command line tools. This guide also describes how to perform common administration tasks in three areas: system management, identity management, and resource management.

trans-unit.source: This document is intended to be a reference. You do not need to read it in order, unless you are following the directions for a particular task.
trans-unit.target: This document is intended to be a reference. You do not need to read it in order, unless you are following the directions for a particular task.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus is a Linux-based software architecture that implements scalable, efficiency-enhancing private and hybrid clouds within an enterprise’s existing IT infrastructure. Because Eucalyptus provides Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), you can provision your own resources (hardware, storage, and network) through Eucalyptus on an as-needed basis.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus is a Linux-based software architecture that implements scalable, efficiency-enhancing private and hybrid clouds within an enterprise’s existing IT infrastructure. Because Eucalyptus provides Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), you can provision your own resources (hardware, storage, and network) through Eucalyptus on an as-needed basis.

trans-unit.source: A Eucalyptus cloud is deployed across your enterprise's on-premise data center. As a result, your organization has a full control of the cloud infrastructure. You can implement and enforce various level of security. Sensitive data managed by the cloud does not have to leave your enterprise boundaries, keeping data completely protected from external access by your enterprise firewall.
trans-unit.target: A Eucalyptus cloud is deployed across your enterprise's on-premise data center. As a result, your organization has a full control of the cloud infrastructure. You can implement and enforce various level of security. Sensitive data managed by the cloud does not have to leave your enterprise boundaries, keeping data completely protected from external access by your enterprise firewall.

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus was designed from the ground up to be easy to install and non-intrusive. The software framework is modular, with industry-standard, language-agnostic communication. Eucalyptus is also unique in that it provides a virtual network overlay that isolates network traffic of different users as well as allows two or more clusters to appear to belong to the same Local Area Network (LAN).
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus was designed from the ground up to be easy to install and non-intrusive. The software framework is modular, with industry-standard, language-agnostic communication. Eucalyptus is also unique in that it provides a virtual network overlay that isolates network traffic of different users as well as allows two or more clusters to appear to belong to the same Local Area Network (LAN).

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus also is compatible with Amazon’s EC2, S3, and IAM services. This offers you hybrid cloud capability.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus also is compatible with Amazon’s EC2, S3, and IAM services. This offers you hybrid cloud capability.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: There are two ways to interact with Eucalyptus. You can use the administrative command line interface for making requests to Eucalyptus, or you can use the web-based user interface, called the Eucalyptus Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: There are two ways to interact with Eucalyptus. You can use the administrative command line interface for making requests to Eucalyptus, or you can use the web-based user interface, called the Eucalyptus Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: This guide will show both CLI and Dashboard steps for performing a task, when the task can be performed by both methods.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show both CLI and Dashboard steps for performing a task, when the task can be performed by both methods.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus supports two command line interfaces (CLIs). The administration CLI is installed when you install Eucalyptus server-side components. The administration CLI is for maintaining and modifying Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus supports two command line interfaces (CLIs). The administration CLI is installed when you install Eucalyptus server-side components. The administration CLI is for maintaining and modifying Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: The other user CLI, called Euca2ools, can be downloaded and installed on clients. Euca2ools are for end users and can be used with both Eucalyptus and Amazon Web Services (AWS).
trans-unit.target: The other user CLI, called Euca2ools, can be downloaded and installed on clients. Euca2ools are for end users and can be used with both Eucalyptus and Amazon Web Services (AWS).

trans-unit.source: The commands used in this guide assume that the environment variables exported by a eucarc file for an administrative Eucalyptus user have been set. For more information, see the Eucalyptus Installation Guide.
trans-unit.target: The commands used in this guide assume that the environment variables exported by a eucarc file for an administrative Eucalyptus user have been set. For more information, see the Eucalyptus Installation Guide.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: The Eucalyptus Dashboard provides cloud administrators with a way to perform several management tasks in a web user interface.
trans-unit.target: El Eucalipto Dashboard ofrece nube los administradores una manera de realizar varias tareas de gestión en una interfaz de usuario web.Eucalipto Dashboard Panorama.

trans-unit.source: The Dashboard provides Quick Links for standard administrative actions and queries. These links, located on the left side of the screen, provide a convenient way to navigate through the Dashboard. For example, if you click Accounts, the Dashboard displays the Accounts page, listing all accounts in your system. Any property of a link, e.g., an account ID, displays on the right side of the screen as a link.
trans-unit.target: The Dashboard provides Quick Links for standard administrative actions and queries. These links, located on the left side of the screen, provide a convenient way to navigate through the Dashboard. For example, if you click Accounts, the Dashboard displays the Accounts page, listing all accounts in your system. Any property of a link, e.g., an account ID, displays on the right side of the screen as a link.

trans-unit.source: For more experienced users, the Dashboard provides a robust search engine. You can search for information or tasks quickly by building your own search. Because the Dashboard is search-based, even the Quick Links and other returned URLs from searches are themselves searches. Because each link is search, any Dashboard link you bookmark is also a search.
trans-unit.target: For more experienced users, the Dashboard provides a robust search engine. You can search for information or tasks quickly by building your own search. Because the Dashboard is search-based, even the Quick Links and other returned URLs from searches are themselves searches. Because each link is search, any Dashboard link you bookmark is also a search.

trans-unit.source: So the Dashboard offers you two ways to get information: by search or by following links. To show the member users of an account, you can click Accounts in quick links, select the account, and then click on the Member users link in the Properties section. Or, you use the Search box and type: user:account=<account_name>.
trans-unit.target: So the Dashboard offers you two ways to get information: by search or by following links. To show the member users of an account, you can click Accounts in quick links, select the account, and then click on the Member users link in the Properties section. Or, you use the Search box and type: user:account=<account_name>.

trans-unit.source: Signing in to the Eucalyptus Dashboard
trans-unit.target: Signing in to the Eucalyptus Dashboard

trans-unit.source: This section describes how to sign in to the Eucalyptus Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: This section describes how to sign in to the Eucalyptus Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: The Eucalyptus Dashboard is web-based interface that allows you to manage your system, identities, and resources.
trans-unit.target: The Eucalyptus Dashboard is web-based interface that allows you to manage your system, identities, and resources.

trans-unit.source: To sign in to the Dashboard:
trans-unit.target: To sign in to the Dashboard:

trans-unit.source: Open a browser window and go to https://<CLC_IP_address>:8443
trans-unit.target: Open a browser window and go to https://<CLC_IP_address>:8443

trans-unit.source: Accept the self-signed SSL certificate and continue.
trans-unit.target: Accept the self-signed SSL certificate and continue.

trans-unit.source: Enter your account name in the Account field.
trans-unit.target: Enter your account name in the Account field.

trans-unit.source: For system admins, the account name is eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: For system admins, the account name is eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: Enter your user name in the User field.
trans-unit.target: Enter your user name in the User field.

trans-unit.source: Enter your password in the Password field.
trans-unit.target: Enter your password in the Password field.

trans-unit.source: The Dashboard Start Guide page displays.
trans-unit.target: The Dashboard Start Guide page displays.

trans-unit.source: You can now use the Dashboard to manage your system, identities, and resources.
trans-unit.target: You can now use the Dashboard to manage your system, identities, and resources.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: This section explains the components of the Dashboard screen.
trans-unit.target: This section explains the components of the Dashboard screen.

trans-unit.source: The Dashboard screen has the following areas:
trans-unit.target: The Dashboard screen has the following areas:

trans-unit.source: This area includes the logo, the link to a user profile setting menu, and the big search box.
trans-unit.target: This area includes the logo, the link to a user profile setting menu, and the big search box.

trans-unit.source:
The current login user identity displays on the right side of the logo area. It shows the user name and the account name of the user identity, in the format of <user_name>@<account_name> Click the profile name to display the user profile menu. The menu provides the following functions:
View/change profile: Displays the search result of the current user. In the search result page, you can view or change your identity’s profile.
View access key: Displays the search result of the current user’s access key.
Change password: Displays a dialog to change password.
Download new credentials: Downloads the current user’s credential package in a zip file.
trans-unit.target:
The current login user identity displays on the right side of the logo area. It shows the user name and the account name of the user identity, in the format of <user_name>@<account_name> Click the profile name to display the user profile menu. The menu provides the following functions:
View/change profile: Displays the search result of the current user. In the search result page, you can view or change your identity’s profile.
View access key: Displays the search result of the current user’s access key.
Change password: Displays a dialog to change password.
Download new credentials: Downloads the current user’s credential package in a zip file.

trans-unit.source: The left side of the Dashboard screen contains the Quick Links area. This area provides links to various contents of the Dashboard. The Quick Links area is organized into sections made up of two levels. The top level is a heading for that section. Under each heading is a second section that contains a list of links. Each link is a search query in the form of the URL. Click a link to return the associated search result. For example, Your Keys is a search query of all the access keys belonging to you. You can hide the Quick Links area by clicking the arrow of the vertical separator between Quick Links and the main content area.
trans-unit.target: The left side of the Dashboard screen contains the Quick Links area. This area provides links to various contents of the Dashboard. The Quick Links area is organized into sections made up of two levels. The top level is a heading for that section. Under each heading is a second section that contains a list of links. Each link is a search query in the form of the URL. Click a link to return the associated search result. For example, Your Keys is a search query of all the access keys belonging to you. You can hide the Quick Links area by clicking the arrow of the vertical separator between Quick Links and the main content area.

trans-unit.source: The center part of the main screen displays the main content, usually the search result list. In many content displays, the Dashboard displays a toolbar that contains action buttons. The bottom of the content area provides the page navigation controls. The search result list usually has multiple columns, some of which are sortable. Click the title in the column to sort the column display. If the list is too long, the Dashboard partitions the list into multiple pages. By default, each page displays a maximum of 25 rows, but you can configure this number.. When you select an item in the main content area, the Dashboard highlights the entire row and displays the Properties area. To select multiple items, use the Ctrl key for individual items, or the Shift key for a continuous block of items.
trans-unit.target: The center part of the main screen displays the main content, usually the search result list. In many content displays, the Dashboard displays a toolbar that contains action buttons. The bottom of the content area provides the page navigation controls. The search result list usually has multiple columns, some of which are sortable. Click the title in the column to sort the column display. If the list is too long, the Dashboard partitions the list into multiple pages. By default, each page displays a maximum of 25 rows, but you can configure this number.. When you select an item in the main content area, the Dashboard highlights the entire row and displays the Properties area. To select multiple items, use the Ctrl key for individual items, or the Shift key for a continuous block of items.

trans-unit.source:
The Properties area displays the detailed information about a selected search result item. The properties are displayed in two columns: the property name is on the left, and the property value is on the right. Working with the Properties area:
The Dashboard displays values of editable properties in a white input box. If you make any changes to value, the Dashboard displays the Save button at the bottom. Click this button to save any changed values. Some properties are of complex types. For example, the list of member users of an account. In these cases, the property names are displayed in hyperlinks with a magnifying glass icon. These hyperlinks invoke a search query. Other properties display an "action" icon. For example, Password displays a pencil icon. Click that icon to change the password. The Dashboard allows you to customize the displayed information in Properties. Click the plus icon to add a new property to the display. Click the minus icon to delete a property from the display. Click the X next to the Properties title to hide the area.
trans-unit.target:
The Properties area displays the detailed information about a selected search result item. The properties are displayed in two columns: the property name is on the left, and the property value is on the right. Working with the Properties area:
The Dashboard displays values of editable properties in a white input box. If you make any changes to value, the Dashboard displays the Save button at the bottom. Click this button to save any changed values. Some properties are of complex types. For example, the list of member users of an account. In these cases, the property names are displayed in hyperlinks with a magnifying glass icon. These hyperlinks invoke a search query. Other properties display an "action" icon. For example, Password displays a pencil icon. Click that icon to change the password. The Dashboard allows you to customize the displayed information in Properties. Click the plus icon to add a new property to the display. Click the minus icon to delete a property from the display. Click the X next to the Properties title to hide the area.

trans-unit.source: The bar at the bottom of the main screen shows system status messages, log window toggle button and the software version (from left to right).
trans-unit.target: The bar at the bottom of the main screen shows system status messages, log window toggle button and the software version (from left to right).

trans-unit.source: Click the LOG button on the status bar to pop up the log window. The log window records important dashboard events, especially any operations that modify system states, e.g. adding a new account, etc. The log windows records the latest 1024 log messages.
trans-unit.target: Click the LOG button on the status bar to pop up the log window. The log window records important dashboard events, especially any operations that modify system states, e.g. adding a new account, etc. The log windows records the latest 1024 log messages.

trans-unit.target: This section details the Search function in the Eucalyptus Dashboard.

The browser URL will also change to reflect the search. Actually, the search query itself is part of the URL (after the pound sign). For example:

trans-unit.source: The System Management section of the Quick Links area allows you to go to the Start Guide or the Service Components page.
trans-unit.target: The System Management section of the Quick Links area allows you to go to the Start Guide or the Service Components page.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus is comprised of six components: Cloud Controller, Walrus, Cluster Controller, Storage Controller, Node Controller, and an optional VMWare Broker. Each component is a stand-alone web service. This architecture allows Eucalyptus both to expose each web service as a well-defined, language-agnostic API, and to support existing web service standards for secure communication between its components.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus is comprised of six components: Cloud Controller, Walrus, Cluster Controller, Storage Controller, Node Controller, and an optional VMWare Broker. Each component is a stand-alone web service. This architecture allows Eucalyptus both to expose each web service as a well-defined, language-agnostic API, and to support existing web service standards for secure communication between its components.

trans-unit.source: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the Node Controller for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers. As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the Node Controller for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers. As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Walrus allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use Walrus to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Walrus is interface compatible with Amazon’s Simple Storage Service (S3). It provides a mechanism for storing and accessing virtual machine images and user data. Walrus can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Walrus allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use Walrus to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Walrus is interface compatible with Amazon’s Simple Storage Service (S3). It provides a mechanism for storing and accessing virtual machine images and user data. Walrus can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.

trans-unit.source: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same subnet.
trans-unit.target: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same subnet.

trans-unit.source: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS). The SC is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.
trans-unit.target: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS). The SC is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.

trans-unit.source: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.

trans-unit.source: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy virtual machines (VMs) on VMware infrastructure elements. Broker mediates all interactions between the CC and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter. For more information about working with vSphere Server, see .
trans-unit.target: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy virtual machines (VMs) on VMware infrastructure elements. Broker mediates all interactions between the CC and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter. For more information about working with vSphere Server, see .

trans-unit.source: This section details Eucalyptus best practices for your private cloud.
trans-unit.target: This section details Eucalyptus best practices for your private cloud.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus with the VMware Broker option can create and manage virtual machines on all or a subset of vSphere infrastructure resources. Since Eucalyptus takes over the task of managing Virtual Machines, to avoid interfering with the operation of your cloud, it is important to avoid performing some operations though vSphere-specific tools, such as the vSphere Client. Conversely, since Eucalyptus does not manage vSphere hosts, network, or storage, the administrator will have to continue using vSphere-specific tools for other operations. The following is a comprehensive, but not exhaustive list of operations that should and should not be performed with vSphere-specific tools.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus with the VMware Broker option can create and manage virtual machines on all or a subset of vSphere infrastructure resources. Since Eucalyptus takes over the task of managing Virtual Machines, to avoid interfering with the operation of your cloud, it is important to avoid performing some operations though vSphere-specific tools, such as the vSphere Client. Conversely, since Eucalyptus does not manage vSphere hosts, network, or storage, the administrator will have to continue using vSphere-specific tools for other operations. The following is a comprehensive, but not exhaustive list of operations that should and should not be performed with vSphere-specific tools.

trans-unit.source: Actions that may be performed with vSphere tools at any time
trans-unit.target: Actions that may be performed with vSphere tools at any time

trans-unit.source: vSphere management tasks that do not involve resources (VMs, hosts, networks, datastores, folders, vCenter Server sessions, etc.) that have never been and are not being used by Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: vSphere management tasks that do not involve resources (VMs, hosts, networks, datastores, folders, vCenter Server sessions, etc.) that have never been and are not being used by Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: Adding new resources -- hosts, networks, datastores, folders -- to vCenter. Such resources may be discovered and used by Eucalyptus automatically, either immediately or after a VMware Broker restart, if the VMware Broker configuration allows that (see 'discover' option in the section on configuring the VMware Broker).
trans-unit.target: Adding new resources -- hosts, networks, datastores, folders -- to vCenter. Such resources may be discovered and used by Eucalyptus automatically, either immediately or after a VMware Broker restart, if the VMware Broker configuration allows that (see 'discover' option in the section on configuring the VMware Broker).

trans-unit.source: While we recommend using Eucalyptus's API to manage instances, a VM created by Eucalyptus may be powered off using vSphere Server tools. (It is not necessary to delete such a VM as Eucalyptus will delete it.)
trans-unit.target: While we recommend using Eucalyptus's API to manage instances, a VM created by Eucalyptus may be powered off using vSphere Server tools. (It is not necessary to delete such a VM as Eucalyptus will delete it.)

trans-unit.source: Managing roles and permissions in ways that do not reduce privileges of Eucalyptus since the time it became active.
trans-unit.target: Managing roles and permissions in ways that do not reduce privileges of Eucalyptus since the time it became active.

trans-unit.source: Changing vCenter or ESX(i) host settings that do not interfere with ongoing sessions and operations. For instance, a license on a host utilized by Eucalyptus may be changed as long as the host remains operational.
trans-unit.target: Changing vCenter or ESX(i) host settings that do not interfere with ongoing sessions and operations. For instance, a license on a host utilized by Eucalyptus may be changed as long as the host remains operational.

trans-unit.source: Changing of vCenter ID or Name (see below regarding the change of IP address).
trans-unit.target: Changing of vCenter ID or Name (see below regarding the change of IP address).

trans-unit.source: Actions that may be performed when Eucalyptus is not active (specifically, when the VMware Broker is shut down):
trans-unit.target: Actions that may be performed when Eucalyptus is not active (specifically, when the VMware Broker is shut down):

trans-unit.source: Deleting the templates (VMs whose names start with 'emi-'). Those will be recreated if needed, albeit at the cost of additional instance start-up delay. To control the space used by and the number of templates, use VMware Broker's configuration properties vmwarebroker.vsphere_cache_limit_bytes and vmwarebroker.vsphere_cache_max_elements.
trans-unit.target: Deleting the templates (VMs whose names start with 'emi-'). Those will be recreated if needed, albeit at the cost of additional instance start-up delay. To control the space used by and the number of templates, use VMware Broker's configuration properties vmwarebroker.vsphere_cache_limit_bytes and vmwarebroker.vsphere_cache_max_elements.

trans-unit.source: Managing roles and permissions for Eucalyptus-managed resources, as long as new roles, if any, are reflected in VMware Broker configuration (see 'login' parameter) and as long as no Eucalyptus-created running VMs are taken out of Eucalyptus's control.
trans-unit.target: Managing roles and permissions for Eucalyptus-managed resources, as long as new roles, if any, are reflected in VMware Broker configuration (see 'login' parameter) and as long as no Eucalyptus-created running VMs are taken out of Eucalyptus's control.

trans-unit.source: vCenter IP address may be changed as long as VMware Broker's configuration is modified accordingly. IP addresses of ESX hosts may be changed as long as there are no running Eucalyptus VMs on the host (furthermore, a change of IP address may require adjustment of configuration unless the host can be discovered).
trans-unit.target: vCenter IP address may be changed as long as VMware Broker's configuration is modified accordingly. IP addresses of ESX hosts may be changed as long as there are no running Eucalyptus VMs on the host (furthermore, a change of IP address may require adjustment of configuration unless the host can be discovered).

trans-unit.source: Actions to avoid with vSphere tools at all times:
trans-unit.target: Actions to avoid with vSphere tools at all times:

trans-unit.source: Renaming, modifying the settings for, or cloning Eucalyptus-created inventory objects (the name of the top-level folder on vCenter, VM templates, VMs). This includes changing the virtual hardware characteristics of VMs created by Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: Renaming, modifying the settings for, or cloning Eucalyptus-created inventory objects (the name of the top-level folder on vCenter, VM templates, VMs). This includes changing the virtual hardware characteristics of VMs created by Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: Migrating, snapshotting, and failing over VMs or templates (emi-...) created by Eucalyptus to a different host or a different datastore with VMotion, VMware HA, or VMware DRS.
trans-unit.target: Migrating, snapshotting, and failing over VMs or templates (emi-...) created by Eucalyptus to a different host or a different datastore with VMotion, VMware HA, or VMware DRS.

trans-unit.source: Changing default ports (80 for HTTP and 443 for HTTPS).
trans-unit.target: Changing default ports (80 for HTTP and 443 for HTTPS).

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus components receive and exchange messages using either Query or SOAP interfaces (or both). Messages received over these interfaces are required to have some form of a time stamp (as defined by AWS specification) to prevent message replay attacks. Because Eucalyptus enforces strict policies when checking timestamps in the received messages, for the correct functioning of the cloud infrastructure, it is crucial to have clocks constantly synchronized (for example, with ntpd) on all machines hosting Eucalyptus components. To prevent user commands failures, it is also important to have clocks synchronized on the client machines.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus components receive and exchange messages using either Query or SOAP interfaces (or both). Messages received over these interfaces are required to have some form of a time stamp (as defined by AWS specification) to prevent message replay attacks. Because Eucalyptus enforces strict policies when checking timestamps in the received messages, for the correct functioning of the cloud infrastructure, it is crucial to have clocks constantly synchronized (for example, with ntpd) on all machines hosting Eucalyptus components. To prevent user commands failures, it is also important to have clocks synchronized on the client machines.

trans-unit.source: Following the AWS specification, all Query interface requests containing the Timestamp element are rejected as expired after 15 minutes of the timestamp. Requests containing the Expires element expire at the time specified by the element. SOAP interface requests using WS-Security expire as specified by the WS-Security Timestamp element.
trans-unit.target: Following the AWS specification, all Query interface requests containing the Timestamp element are rejected as expired after 15 minutes of the timestamp. Requests containing the Expires element expire at the time specified by the element. SOAP interface requests using WS-Security expire as specified by the WS-Security Timestamp element.

trans-unit.source: When checking the timestamps for expiration, Eucalyptus allows up to 20 seconds of clock drift between the machines. This is a default setting. You can change this value for the CLC at runtime by setting the bootstrap.webservices.clock_skew_sec property as follows:
trans-unit.target: When checking the timestamps for expiration, Eucalyptus allows up to 20 seconds of clock drift between the machines. This is a default setting. You can change this value for the CLC at runtime by setting the bootstrap.webservices.clock_skew_sec property as follows:

trans-unit.source: For additional protection from the message replay attacks, the CLC implements a replay detection algorithm and rejects messages with the same signatures received within 15 minutes.
trans-unit.target: For additional protection from the message replay attacks, the CLC implements a replay detection algorithm and rejects messages with the same signatures received within 15 minutes.

trans-unit.source: To protect against replay attacks, the CLC only caches messages for 15 minutes. So it’s important that any client tools used to interact with the CLC have the Expires element set to a value less than 15 minutes from the current time. This is usually not an issue with standard tools, such as euca2ools and Amazon EC2 API Tools.
trans-unit.target: To protect against replay attacks, the CLC only caches messages for 15 minutes. So it’s important that any client tools used to interact with the CLC have the Expires element set to a value less than 15 minutes from the current time. This is usually not an issue with standard tools, such as euca2ools and Amazon EC2 API Tools.

trans-unit.source: You can configure replay detection in the CLC to allow replays of the same message for a set time period. This might be needed to ensure that legitimate requests submitted by automated scripts closely together (such as two requests to describe instances issued within the same second) are not rejected as malicious. The time within which messages with the same signatures are accepted is controlled by the bootstrap.webservices.replay_skew_window_sec property. The default value of this property is three seconds. To change this value, enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: You can configure replay detection in the CLC to allow replays of the same message for a set time period. This might be needed to ensure that legitimate requests submitted by automated scripts closely together (such as two requests to describe instances issued within the same second) are not rejected as malicious. The time within which messages with the same signatures are accepted is controlled by the bootstrap.webservices.replay_skew_window_sec property. The default value of this property is three seconds. To change this value, enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: If you set this property to 0, Eucalyptus will not allow any message replays. This setting provides the best protection against message replay attacks, but may break some of the client-side scripts that issue commands too quickly.
trans-unit.target: If you set this property to 0, Eucalyptus will not allow any message replays. This setting provides the best protection against message replay attacks, but may break some of the client-side scripts that issue commands too quickly.

trans-unit.source: If you set this property to any value greater than 15 minutes plus the values of ws.clock_skew_sec (that is, to a value >= 920 sec in the default installation), Eucalyptus disables replay detection completely.
trans-unit.target: If you set this property to any value greater than 15 minutes plus the values of ws.clock_skew_sec (that is, to a value >= 920 sec in the default installation), Eucalyptus disables replay detection completely.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: High availability is the result of the combination of functionality provided by Eucalyptus and the environmental and operational support to maintain the constituent systems's proper operation. Eucalyptus provides functionality aimed at enabling highly available operation:
trans-unit.target: High availability is the result of the combination of functionality provided by Eucalyptus and the environmental and operational support to maintain the constituent systems's proper operation. Eucalyptus provides functionality aimed at enabling highly available operation:

trans-unit.source: Detection of service faults and monitoring of system health: gather service status, determine current service topology, admit requests which can be satisfied using only healthy services in that topology
trans-unit.target: Detection of service faults and monitoring of system health: gather service status, determine current service topology, admit requests which can be satisfied using only healthy services in that topology

trans-unit.source: Tools for interrogating the system's health: access to service state information
trans-unit.target: Tools for interrogating the system's health: access to service state information

trans-unit.source: Error gathering to aid in determining the cause: access to fault information as it impacts service function
trans-unit.target: Error gathering to aid in determining the cause: access to fault information as it impacts service function

trans-unit.source: Automated failover when redundant services are configured: removal of faulty services and enabling of healthy services
trans-unit.target: Automated failover when redundant services are configured: removal of faulty services and enabling of healthy services

trans-unit.source: Service state control: ability to remove individual component-services (when configured with HA pair) from operation without disrupting service
trans-unit.target: Service state control: ability to remove individual component-services (when configured with HA pair) from operation without disrupting service

trans-unit.source: Replacement/restoration of component-services: procedures for restoring/replacing a component service after a total-loss failure (e.g., disk failure, host combustion, etc.)
trans-unit.target: Replacement/restoration of component-services: procedures for restoring/replacing a component service after a total-loss failure (e.g., disk failure, host combustion, etc.)

trans-unit.source: In addition to previously detailed deployment recommendations, delivering highly available services with Eucalyptus depends on appropriate operational and maintenance support. The following sections detail the related system functionality and procedures.
trans-unit.target: In addition to previously detailed deployment recommendations, delivering highly available services with Eucalyptus depends on appropriate operational and maintenance support. The following sections detail the related system functionality and procedures.

trans-unit.source: The system monitors service health and enables healthy services to process user requests while marking faulty services as being NOTREADY. Each component service is interrogated by the system to determine its current state. Faults are detected either:
trans-unit.target: The system monitors service health and enables healthy services to process user requests while marking faulty services as being NOTREADY. Each component service is interrogated by the system to determine its current state. Faults are detected either:

trans-unit.source: The service reporting a fault has been detected (for example, due to misconfiguration, dependency service failure, environmental fault, etc.)
trans-unit.target: The service reporting a fault has been detected (for example, due to misconfiguration, dependency service failure, environmental fault, etc.)

trans-unit.source: The following table overviews the relevant states
trans-unit.target: The following table overviews the relevant states

trans-unit.source: Service is operating correctly and is selected for processing requests
trans-unit.target: Service is operating correctly and is selected for processing requests

trans-unit.source: Service is operating correctly but is not selected for processing requests
trans-unit.target: Service is operating correctly but is not selected for processing requests

trans-unit.source: Service is failing to operate correctly
trans-unit.target: Service is failing to operate correctly

trans-unit.source: Service is not contactable by the system
trans-unit.target: Service is not contactable by the system

trans-unit.source: Service has been stopped by an administrator
trans-unit.target: Service has been stopped by an administrator

trans-unit.source: The following diagram indicates the set of relevant states and transitions between them. Black arrows indicate a transition between states that is initiated by the system or an administrator request. Red errors indicate a failure to transition into the originating state that results in a transition to the destination error state.
trans-unit.target: The following diagram indicates the set of relevant states and transitions between them. Black arrows indicate a transition between states that is initiated by the system or an administrator request. Red errors indicate a failure to transition into the originating state that results in a transition to the destination error state.

trans-unit.source: Based on the collected service state, the system will:
trans-unit.target: Based on the collected service state, the system will:

trans-unit.source: Attempt to advance previously non-functioning services to a functional state
trans-unit.target: Attempt to advance previously non-functioning services to a functional state

trans-unit.source: Determine whether any functioning services can be ENABLED and added to the set used for serving requests
trans-unit.target: Determine whether any functioning services can be ENABLED and added to the set used for serving requests

trans-unit.source: The impact of a service fault on the system's availability depends upon the deployment and configuration of the system. The following table details the scope a service fault can have on system availability for each component type.
trans-unit.target: The impact of a service fault on the system's availability depends upon the deployment and configuration of the system. The following table details the scope a service fault can have on system availability for each component type.

trans-unit.source: The CLC is a cloud-wide service and must have at least one operation service.
trans-unit.target: The CLC is a cloud-wide service and must have at least one operation service.

trans-unit.source: Walrus is a cloud-wide service and must have at least one operation service.
trans-unit.target: Walrus is a cloud-wide service and must have at least one operation service.

trans-unit.source: CCs are associated with a partition and service requests specific to an availability zone. Should an availability zone not have an operational CC, instance requests will be rejected for the corresponding zone.
trans-unit.target: CCs are associated with a partition and service requests specific to an availability zone. Should an availability zone not have an operational CC, instance requests will be rejected for the corresponding zone.

trans-unit.source: Storage controllers are associated with a partition and service requests specific to an availability zone. Should an availability zone not have an operational storage controller volume and snapshot creation requests will be rejected for the corresponding zone
trans-unit.target: Storage controllers are associated with a partition and service requests specific to an availability zone. Should an availability zone not have an operational storage controller volume and snapshot creation requests will be rejected for the corresponding zone

trans-unit.source: VMware Broker are associated with a partition and service requests specific to an availability zone. Should an availability zone not have an operational VMware Broker instance requests will be rejected for the corresponding zone
trans-unit.target: VMware Broker are associated with a partition and service requests specific to an availability zone. Should an availability zone not have an operational VMware Broker instance requests will be rejected for the corresponding zone

trans-unit.source: Arbitrators are associated with a host that runs user-facing component services (CLC, Walrus). Each host must have an operational Arbitrator. Should a component service host have a configured but faulty Arbitrator, a fail-stop condition occurs and locally hosted services report a NOTREADY error.
trans-unit.target: Arbitrators are associated with a host that runs user-facing component services (CLC, Walrus). Each host must have an operational Arbitrator. Should a component service host have a configured but faulty Arbitrator, a fail-stop condition occurs and locally hosted services report a NOTREADY error.

trans-unit.source: NCs are associated with each node and interact with the hypervisor to service node-specific requests.
trans-unit.target: NCs are associated with each node and interact with the hypervisor to service node-specific requests.

trans-unit.source: A quick way to evaluate system availability is to determine whether:
trans-unit.target: A quick way to evaluate system availability is to determine whether:

trans-unit.source: The cloud has an enabled CLC
trans-unit.target: The cloud has an enabled CLC

trans-unit.source: The cloud has an enabled Walrus
trans-unit.target: The cloud has an enabled Walrus

trans-unit.source: The availability zone has an enabled CC
trans-unit.target: The availability zone has an enabled CC

trans-unit.source: The availability zone has an enabled SC
trans-unit.target: The availability zone has an enabled SC

trans-unit.source: The user-facing service host has one reachable Arbitrator per host (if you configure an Arbitrator)
trans-unit.target: The user-facing service host has one reachable Arbitrator per host (if you configure an Arbitrator)

trans-unit.source: You can perform the following cloud-related tasks listed in this section:
trans-unit.target: You can perform the following cloud-related tasks listed in this section:

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus provides access to the current view of service state and the ability to manipulate the state. You can inspect the service state to either ensure system health or to identify faulty services. You can modify a service state to maintain activities and apply external service placement policies.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus provides access to the current view of service state and the ability to manipulate the state. You can inspect the service state to either ensure system health or to identify faulty services. You can modify a service state to maintain activities and apply external service placement policies.

trans-unit.source: Use the euca-describe-services command to view the service state. The output indicates:
trans-unit.target: Use the euca-describe-services command to view the service state. The output indicates:

trans-unit.source: Partition in which the service is registered
trans-unit.target: Partition in which the service is registered

trans-unit.source: Last reported epoch (this can be safely ignored)
trans-unit.target: Last reported epoch (this can be safely ignored)

trans-unit.source: Fully qualified name of the service (This is needed for manipulating services that did not get unique names during registration. For example: internal services like reporting or DNS)
trans-unit.target: Fully qualified name of the service (This is needed for manipulating services that did not get unique names during registration. For example: internal services like reporting or DNS)

trans-unit.source: The default output includes the services that are registered during configuration, as well as information about the DNS service, if present. You can obtain additional service state information, such as internal services, by providing the -system-internal flag.
trans-unit.target: The default output includes the services that are registered during configuration, as well as information about the DNS service, if present. You can obtain additional service state information, such as internal services, by providing the -system-internal flag.

trans-unit.source: You can also make requests to retrieve service information that is filtered by either:
trans-unit.target: You can also make requests to retrieve service information that is filtered by either:

trans-unit.source: type of service (for example, CC or Walrus)
trans-unit.target: type of service (for example, CC or Walrus)

trans-unit.source: When you investigate service failures, you can specify -events to return a summary of the last fault. You can retrieve extended information (primarily useful for debugging) by specifying -events -events-verbose.
trans-unit.target: When you investigate service failures, you can specify -events to return a summary of the last fault. You can retrieve extended information (primarily useful for debugging) by specifying -events -events-verbose.

trans-unit.source: If, for example, you have SCs that are correctly configured and operating in HA mode. However, you want to shut down the primary SC for maintenance. The primary SC is SC00 and the secondary SC is SC01. SC00 is ENABLED and SC01 is DISABLED.
trans-unit.target: If, for example, you have SCs that are correctly configured and operating in HA mode. However, you want to shut down the primary SC for maintenance. The primary SC is SC00 and the secondary SC is SC01. SC00 is ENABLED and SC01 is DISABLED.

trans-unit.source: To disable SC00 and cause SC01 to take over, you would enter:
trans-unit.target: To disable SC00 and cause SC01 to take over, you would enter:

trans-unit.source: To check status of services, you would enter:
trans-unit.target: To check status of services, you would enter:

trans-unit.source: When SC01 is marked ENABLED, the eucalyptus-cloud process on the host that SC00 is running can be safely shutdown and maintenance tasks can be performed. When maintenance is complete, you can start the eucalyptus-cloud process on SC00. SC00 will enter the DISABLED state by default. You can chose to let SC00 continue to be the primary and SC01 will be the secondary.
trans-unit.target: When SC01 is marked ENABLED, the eucalyptus-cloud process on the host that SC00 is running can be safely shutdown and maintenance tasks can be performed. When maintenance is complete, you can start the eucalyptus-cloud process on SC00. SC00 will enter the DISABLED state by default. You can chose to let SC00 continue to be the primary and SC01 will be the secondary.

trans-unit.source: If you want to designate SC00 as the primary, make sure no volumes or snapshots are being created and that no volumes are being attached or detached, and then enter:
trans-unit.target: If you want to designate SC00 as the primary, make sure no volumes or snapshots are being created and that no volumes are being attached or detached, and then enter:

trans-unit.source: Monitor the state of services using euca-describe-services until SC01 is marked DISABLED and SC00 is ENABLED.
trans-unit.target: Monitor the state of services using euca-describe-services until SC01 is marked DISABLED and SC00 is ENABLED.

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus provides access to the current view of service state and the ability to manipulate the state. You can inspect the service state to either ensure system health or to identify faulty services. You can modify a service state to maintain activities and apply external service placement policies.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus provides access to the current view of service state and the ability to manipulate the state. You can inspect the service state to either ensure system health or to identify faulty services. You can modify a service state to maintain activities and apply external service placement policies.

trans-unit.source: Use the euca-describe-services command to view the service state. The output indicates:
trans-unit.target: Use the euca-describe-services command to view the service state. The output indicates:

trans-unit.source: Partition in which the service is registered
trans-unit.target: Partition in which the service is registered

trans-unit.source: Last reported epoch (this can be safely ignored)
trans-unit.target: Last reported epoch (this can be safely ignored)

trans-unit.source: Fully qualified name of the service (This is needed for manipulating services that did not get unique names during registration. For example: internal services like reporting or DNS)
trans-unit.target: Fully qualified name of the service (This is needed for manipulating services that did not get unique names during registration. For example: internal services like reporting or DNS)

trans-unit.source: The default output includes the services that are registered during configuration, as well as information about the DNS service, if present. You can obtain additional service state information, such as internal services, by providing the -system-internal flag.
trans-unit.target: The default output includes the services that are registered during configuration, as well as information about the DNS service, if present. You can obtain additional service state information, such as internal services, by providing the -system-internal flag.

trans-unit.source: You can also make requests to retrieve service information that is filtered by either:
trans-unit.target: You can also make requests to retrieve service information that is filtered by either:

trans-unit.source: type of service (for example, CC or Walrus)
trans-unit.target: type of service (for example, CC or Walrus)

trans-unit.source: When you investigate service failures, you can specify -events to return a summary of the last fault. You can retrieve extended information (primarily useful for debugging) by specifying -events -events-verbose.
trans-unit.target: When you investigate service failures, you can specify -events to return a summary of the last fault. You can retrieve extended information (primarily useful for debugging) by specifying -events -events-verbose.

trans-unit.source: If, for example, you have SCs that are correctly configured and operating in HA mode. However, you want to shut down the primary SC for maintenance. The primary SC is SC00 and the secondary SC is SC01. SC00 is ENABLED and SC01 is DISABLED.
trans-unit.target: If, for example, you have SCs that are correctly configured and operating in HA mode. However, you want to shut down the primary SC for maintenance. The primary SC is SC00 and the secondary SC is SC01. SC00 is ENABLED and SC01 is DISABLED.

trans-unit.source: To disable SC00 and cause SC01 to take over, you would enter:
trans-unit.target: To disable SC00 and cause SC01 to take over, you would enter:

trans-unit.source: To check status of services, you would enter:
trans-unit.target: To check status of services, you would enter:

trans-unit.source: When SC01 is marked ENABLED, the eucalyptus-cloud process on the host that SC00 is running can be safely shutdown and maintenance tasks can be performed. When maintenance is complete, you can start the eucalyptus-cloud process on SC00. SC00 will enter the DISABLED state by default. You can chose to let SC00 continue to be the primary and SC01 will be the secondary.
trans-unit.target: When SC01 is marked ENABLED, the eucalyptus-cloud process on the host that SC00 is running can be safely shutdown and maintenance tasks can be performed. When maintenance is complete, you can start the eucalyptus-cloud process on SC00. SC00 will enter the DISABLED state by default. You can chose to let SC00 continue to be the primary and SC01 will be the secondary.

trans-unit.source: If you want to designate SC00 as the primary, make sure no volumes or snapshots are being created and that no volumes are being attached or detached, and then enter:
trans-unit.target: If you want to designate SC00 as the primary, make sure no volumes or snapshots are being created and that no volumes are being attached or detached, and then enter:

trans-unit.source: Monitor the state of services using euca-describe-services until SC01 is marked DISABLED and SC00 is ENABLED.
trans-unit.target: Monitor the state of services using euca-describe-services until SC01 is marked DISABLED and SC00 is ENABLED.

trans-unit.source: Generate reports to monitor cloud resource use over a specified date range. Usage can be reported for instances, storage, and Walrus.
trans-unit.target: Generate reports to monitor cloud resource use over a specified date range. Usage can be reported for instances, storage, and Walrus.

trans-unit.source: Instances: Shows a count and duration of instances running, sorted by image size, as well as I/O net and disk, during the date range specified. If desired, the report can be displayed on a per-user, per-account, per-cluster or per-availability zone basis. Once filtered, reports can be grouped using the same criteria as filters. For example, you might display the results by user, and then group the results so that they are displayed based on accounts, e.g. each user in account A is shown followed by each user in account B, etc.
trans-unit.target: Instances: Shows a count and duration of instances running, sorted by image size, as well as I/O net and disk, during the date range specified. If desired, the report can be displayed on a per-user, per-account, per-cluster or per-availability zone basis. Once filtered, reports can be grouped using the same criteria as filters. For example, you might display the results by user, and then group the results so that they are displayed based on accounts, e.g. each user in account A is shown followed by each user in account B, etc.

trans-unit.source: Storage:Shows GB of storage used (max and GB-days) for volumes and snapshots during the date range specified. Display filters and grouping are the same as for instances.
trans-unit.target: Storage:Shows GB of storage used (max and GB-days) for volumes and snapshots during the date range specified. Display filters and grouping are the same as for instances.

trans-unit.source: Walrus: Shows maximum buckets and objects used through Walrus during the date range specified. Display filters and grouping are available on a per-user or per-account basis.
trans-unit.target: Walrus: Shows maximum buckets and objects used through Walrus during the date range specified. Display filters and grouping are available on a per-user or per-account basis.

trans-unit.source: You can generate reports in either CSV, PDF, or HTML formats for use with external tools.
trans-unit.target: You can generate reports in either CSV, PDF, or HTML formats for use with external tools.

trans-unit.source: Log in to the Dashboard at https://<CLC_hostname_or_ipaddress>:8443.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the Dashboard at https://<CLC_hostname_or_ipaddress>:8443.

trans-unit.source: Click Usage Report in the Quick Links section.
trans-unit.target: Click Usage Report in the Quick Links section.

trans-unit.source: In the Start date field, select the date to start
trans-unit.target: In the Start date field, select the date to start

trans-unit.source: The usage report displays, reflecting your choices in the report.
trans-unit.target: The usage report displays, reflecting your choices in the report.

trans-unit.source: To see resource use by your cloud users, Eucalyptus provides the following commands with the -verbose flag:
trans-unit.target: To see resource use by your cloud users, Eucalyptus provides the following commands with the -verbose flag:

trans-unit.source: euca-describe-groups verbose: Returns information about security groups in your account, including output type identifier, security group ID, security group name, security group description, output type identifier, account ID of the group owner, name of group granting permission, type of rule, protocol to allow, start of port range, end of port range, source (for ingress rules) or destination (for egress rules), and any tags assigned to the security group.
trans-unit.target: euca-describe-groups verbose: Returns information about security groups in your account, including output type identifier, security group ID, security group name, security group description, output type identifier, account ID of the group owner, name of group granting permission, type of rule, protocol to allow, start of port range, end of port range, source (for ingress rules) or destination (for egress rules), and any tags assigned to the security group.

trans-unit.source: euca-describe-instances verbose: Returns information about your instances, including output type identifier, reservation ID, name of each security group the instance is in, output type identifier, instance ID for each running instance, EMI ID of the image on which the instance is based, public DNS name associated with the instance (for instances in the running state), private DNS name associated with the instance (for instances in running state), instance state, key name, launch index, instance type, launch time, availability zone, kernel ID, ramdisk ID, monitoring state, public IP address, private IP address, type of root device (ebs or instance-store), placement group the cluster instance is in, virtualization type (paravirtual or hvm), any tags assigned to the instance, hypervisor type, block device identifier for each EBS volume the instance is using, along with the device name, the volume ID, and the timestamp.
trans-unit.target: euca-describe-instances verbose: Returns information about your instances, including output type identifier, reservation ID, name of each security group the instance is in, output type identifier, instance ID for each running instance, EMI ID of the image on which the instance is based, public DNS name associated with the instance (for instances in the running state), private DNS name associated with the instance (for instances in running state), instance state, key name, launch index, instance type, launch time, availability zone, kernel ID, ramdisk ID, monitoring state, public IP address, private IP address, type of root device (ebs or instance-store), placement group the cluster instance is in, virtualization type (paravirtual or hvm), any tags assigned to the instance, hypervisor type, block device identifier for each EBS volume the instance is using, along with the device name, the volume ID, and the timestamp.

trans-unit.source: euca-describe-keypairs verbose: Returns information about key pairs available to you, including keypair identifier, keypair name, and private key fingerprint.
trans-unit.target: euca-describe-keypairs verbose: Returns information about key pairs available to you, including keypair identifier, keypair name, and private key fingerprint.

trans-unit.source: euca-describe-snapshots verbose: Returns information about EBS snapshots available to you, including snapshot identifier, ID of the snapshot, ID of the volume, snapshot state (pending, completed, error), timestamp when snapshot initiated, percentage of completion, ID of the owner, volume sized, description, and any tags assigned to the snapshot.
trans-unit.target: euca-describe-snapshots verbose: Returns information about EBS snapshots available to you, including snapshot identifier, ID of the snapshot, ID of the volume, snapshot state (pending, completed, error), timestamp when snapshot initiated, percentage of completion, ID of the owner, volume sized, description, and any tags assigned to the snapshot.

trans-unit.source: euca-describe-volumes verbose: Describes your EBS volumes, including volume identifier, volume ID, size of the volume in GiBs, snapshot from which the volume was created, availability zone, volume state (creating, available, in-use, deleting, deleted, error), timestamp of the volume creation, and any tags assigned to the volume.
trans-unit.target: euca-describe-volumes verbose: Describes your EBS volumes, including volume identifier, volume ID, size of the volume in GiBs, snapshot from which the volume was created, availability zone, volume state (creating, available, in-use, deleting, deleted, error), timestamp of the volume creation, and any tags assigned to the volume.

trans-unit.source: You can start the CC two different ways. A normal restart causes the CC to re-parse the eucalyptus.conf file without resetting the networking state of the cloud. This means that the CC maintains routes, firewall rules, IP assignments for running VMs. This is how you restart under normal circumstances.
trans-unit.target: You can start the CC two different ways. A normal restart causes the CC to re-parse the eucalyptus.conf file without resetting the networking state of the cloud. This means that the CC maintains routes, firewall rules, IP assignments for running VMs. This is how you restart under normal circumstances.

trans-unit.source: A clean restart causes the CC to reset the networking configuration it maintains. The CC clears any existing network configuration regardless of whether it is in use. That is, a clean restart of a CC managing active VMs can cause the network connectivity they are using to be irreparably lost. We recommend that you only perform this type of restart when you change network modes.
trans-unit.target: A clean restart causes the CC to reset the networking configuration it maintains. The CC clears any existing network configuration regardless of whether it is in use. That is, a clean restart of a CC managing active VMs can cause the network connectivity they are using to be irreparably lost. We recommend that you only perform this type of restart when you change network modes.

trans-unit.target: Describes the recommended processes to shut down Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: There may be times when you need to shut down Eucalyptus. This might be because of a physical failure, topological change, backing up, or making an upgrade. We recommend that you shut down Eucalyptus components in the reverse order of how you started them. To stop the system, shut down the components in the order listed.
trans-unit.target: There may be times when you need to shut down Eucalyptus. This might be because of a physical failure, topological change, backing up, or making an upgrade. We recommend that you shut down Eucalyptus components in the reverse order of how you started them. To stop the system, shut down the components in the order listed.

trans-unit.source: Backing up Eucalyptus involves saving contents of the specific directories on each component. On the CLC host, these directories are:
trans-unit.target: Backing up Eucalyptus involves saving contents of the specific directories on each component. On the CLC host, these directories are:

trans-unit.source: On the Walrus host (which, depending on your set-up, might be the same as the CLC host):
trans-unit.target: On the Walrus host (which, depending on your set-up, might be the same as the CLC host):

trans-unit.source: The Walrus buckets (the default location is /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits). You should only do this if you have enough spare disk space available. If the Walrus buckets location is an external storage location (like NFS), consult with your storage administrator to back up that location.
trans-unit.target: The Walrus buckets (the default location is /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits). You should only do this if you have enough spare disk space available. If the Walrus buckets location is an external storage location (like NFS), consult with your storage administrator to back up that location.

trans-unit.source: On the Storage Controller host (may be the same as the CLC host):
trans-unit.target: On the Storage Controller host (may be the same as the CLC host):

trans-unit.target: Calculate the disk space required to store the files about to be backed up (this is most relevant for buckets and volumes, which can be large). For example, on a single-cluster installation with default buckets and volumes paths:
