xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: In case your system experiences a failure, you can restore Eucalyptus from a backup by performing the following tasks:
trans-unit.target: In case your system experiences a failure, you can restore Eucalyptus from a backup by performing the following tasks:

trans-unit.source: Shut down any running Eucalyptus components. For further information about the shut down process, see .
trans-unit.target: Shut down any running Eucalyptus components. For further information about the shut down process, see .

trans-unit.source: If you are trying to recover from a broken upgrade by rolling back or by trying the upgrade again, this would be the right time to:
trans-unit.target: If you are trying to recover from a broken upgrade by rolling back or by trying the upgrade again, this would be the right time to:

trans-unit.source: Remove all software components related to Eucalyptus (for example, rpm -e or apt-get remove).
trans-unit.target: Remove all software components related to Eucalyptus (for example, rpm -e or apt-get remove).

trans-unit.source: Install the appropriate version. For more information, go to the Eucalyptus Installation Guide.
trans-unit.target: Install the appropriate version. For more information, go to the Eucalyptus Installation Guide.

trans-unit.source: DEBs will restart the services. Be sure you stop them again before copying back the backed-up files.
trans-unit.target: DEBs will restart the services. Be sure you stop them again before copying back the backed-up files.

trans-unit.source: If you backed up with cp, enter the following: cp -a $BACKUP/eucalyptus.conf /etc/eucalyptus cp -a $BACKUP/keys $BACKUP/db $BACKUP/bukkits $BACKUP/volumes /var/lib/eucalyptus
trans-unit.target: If you backed up with cp, enter the following: cp -a $BACKUP/eucalyptus.conf /etc/eucalyptus cp -a $BACKUP/keys $BACKUP/db $BACKUP/bukkits $BACKUP/volumes /var/lib/eucalyptus

trans-unit.source: If you backed up with tar, enter the following: tar xvf $BACKUP/eucalyptus-backup.tar
trans-unit.target: If you backed up with tar, enter the following: tar xvf $BACKUP/eucalyptus-backup.tar

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus manages access control through an authentication, authorization, and accounting system. This system manages user identities, enforces access controls over resources, and provides reporting on resource usage as a basis for auditing and managing cloud activities. The user identity organizational model and the scheme of authorizations used to access resources are based on and compatible with the AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) system, with some Eucalyptus extensions provided that support ease-of-use in a private cloud environment.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus manages access control through an authentication, authorization, and accounting system. This system manages user identities, enforces access controls over resources, and provides reporting on resource usage as a basis for auditing and managing cloud activities. The user identity organizational model and the scheme of authorizations used to access resources are based on and compatible with the AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) system, with some Eucalyptus extensions provided that support ease-of-use in a private cloud environment.

trans-unit.source: You can also perform user authentication by integrating Eucalyptus with an existing LDAP or Active Directory. In this case, the user, group and account information, and Dashboard login authenticate using the LDAP/AD service. This information cannot be changed from Eucalyptus side when LDAP/AD integration is turned on. However, other Eucalyptus-specific information about user, group and account is still stored within the local database of Eucalyptus, including certificates, secret keys and attached policies.
trans-unit.target: You can also perform user authentication by integrating Eucalyptus with an existing LDAP or Active Directory. In this case, the user, group and account information, and Dashboard login authenticate using the LDAP/AD service. This information cannot be changed from Eucalyptus side when LDAP/AD integration is turned on. However, other Eucalyptus-specific information about user, group and account is still stored within the local database of Eucalyptus, including certificates, secret keys and attached policies.

trans-unit.source: For more information about synchronizing an existing LDAP or Active Directory with Eucalyptus, see .
trans-unit.target: For more information about synchronizing an existing LDAP or Active Directory with Eucalyptus, see .

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: The Eucalyptus design of user identity and access management provides layers in the hierarchical organization of user identities. This gives you refined control over resource access. The core of the this design is compatible with the AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) service. There are also a few Eucalyptus-specific extensions that meet the needs of enterprise customers.
trans-unit.target: The Eucalyptus design of user identity and access management provides layers in the hierarchical organization of user identities. This gives you refined control over resource access. The core of the this design is compatible with the AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) service. There are also a few Eucalyptus-specific extensions that meet the needs of enterprise customers.

trans-unit.source: The concept of “user” has changed from when Amazon first introduced IAM. The original “user” has become the “account,” and the new “user” is an identity within the “account”. We made a similar change in the current Eucalyptus implementation of an IAM-compatible identity management system. If you upgrade of Eucalyptus 2 to Eucalyptus 3 is performed, the “users” in Eucalyptus 2 are converted into “accounts” in Eucalyptus 3. Please refer to the Eucalyptus upgrade section in the Installation Guide for the details about this identity conversion process.
trans-unit.target: The concept of “user” has changed from when Amazon first introduced IAM. The original “user” has become the “account,” and the new “user” is an identity within the “account”. We made a similar change in the current Eucalyptus implementation of an IAM-compatible identity management system. If you upgrade of Eucalyptus 2 to Eucalyptus 3 is performed, the “users” in Eucalyptus 2 are converted into “accounts” in Eucalyptus 3. Please refer to the Eucalyptus upgrade section in the Installation Guide for the details about this identity conversion process.

trans-unit.source: In Eucalyptus 2, the access management ability was limited:
trans-unit.target: In Eucalyptus 2, the access management ability was limited:

trans-unit.source: The admin user had full access control of the system resources.
trans-unit.target: The admin user had full access control of the system resources.

trans-unit.source: Regular users controled resources that they created.
trans-unit.target: Regular users controled resources that they created.

trans-unit.source: Certain resources could be shared among users, using mechanisms like image launch permissions and Walrus bucket ACLs.
trans-unit.target: Certain resources could be shared among users, using mechanisms like image launch permissions and Walrus bucket ACLs.

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus 3 introduces a two-tier hierarchy of user identities based on accounts. The access control, therefore, is provided at both tiers:
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus 3 introduces a two-tier hierarchy of user identities based on accounts. The access control, therefore, is provided at both tiers:

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus 2 style resource sharing is still available, but now implemented at account level.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus 2 style resource sharing is still available, but now implemented at account level.

trans-unit.source: Within each account, fine-grained access control is provided by a policy that is fully compatible with IAM.
trans-unit.target: Within each account, fine-grained access control is provided by a policy that is fully compatible with IAM.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: This section describes what Eucalyptus access is and what you need to know about it so that you can configure access to your cloud.
trans-unit.target: This section describes what Eucalyptus access is and what you need to know about it so that you can configure access to your cloud.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source:
In Eucalyptus, user identities are organized into accounts. An account is the unit of resource usage
accounting, and also a separate namespace for many resources (security groups, key pairs, users, etc.)
trans-unit.target:
In Eucalyptus, user identities are organized into accounts. An account is the unit of resource usage
accounting, and also a separate namespace for many resources (security groups, key pairs, users, etc.)

trans-unit.source: Accounts are identified by either a unique ID (UUID) or a unique name. The account name is equivalent to IAM’s account alias. It is used to manipulate accounts in most cases. However, to be compatible with AWS, the EC2 commands often use account ID to display resource ownership. There are command line tools to discover the correspondence of account ID and account name. For example, euare-accountlist lists all the accounts with both their IDs and names.
trans-unit.target: Accounts are identified by either a unique ID (UUID) or a unique name. The account name is equivalent to IAM’s account alias. It is used to manipulate accounts in most cases. However, to be compatible with AWS, the EC2 commands often use account ID to display resource ownership. There are command line tools to discover the correspondence of account ID and account name. For example, euare-accountlist lists all the accounts with both their IDs and names.

trans-unit.source: An account can have multiple users, but a user can only be in one account. Within an account, users can be associated with Groups. Group is used to attach access permissions to multiple users. A user can be associated with multiple groups. Because an account is a separate name space, user names and group names have to be unique only within an account. Therefore, user X in account A and user X in account B are two different identities.
trans-unit.target: An account can have multiple users, but a user can only be in one account. Within an account, users can be associated with Groups. Group is used to attach access permissions to multiple users. A user can be associated with multiple groups. Because an account is a separate name space, user names and group names have to be unique only within an account. Therefore, user X in account A and user X in account B are two different identities.

trans-unit.source: Both users and groups are identified by their names, which are unique within an account (they also have UUIDs, but rarely used).
trans-unit.target: Both users and groups are identified by their names, which are unique within an account (they also have UUIDs, but rarely used).

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus has two special identities for the convenience of administration and use of the system.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus has two special identities for the convenience of administration and use of the system.

trans-unit.source: The eucalyptus account: This is like the root group in a Linux system. Every user in the eucalyptus account has full access to the resources in the system. These users are often referred to as sys admin or cloud admin. This account is automatically created when the system starts for the first time. You can not remove eucalyptus account from the system.
trans-unit.target: The eucalyptus account: This is like the root group in a Linux system. Every user in the eucalyptus account has full access to the resources in the system. These users are often referred to as sys admin or cloud admin. This account is automatically created when the system starts for the first time. You can not remove eucalyptus account from the system.

trans-unit.source: The admin user of an account: Each account, including the eucalyptus account, has a user named admin by default, i.e. created automatically by the system when an account is created. The admin of an account has full access to the resources owned by the account. You can not remove the admin user from an account. The admin can delegate resource access to other users in the account by using policies.
trans-unit.target: The admin user of an account: Each account, including the eucalyptus account, has a user named admin by default, i.e. created automatically by the system when an account is created. The admin of an account has full access to the resources owned by the account. You can not remove the admin user from an account. The admin can delegate resource access to other users in the account by using policies.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Each user has a unique set of credentials. These credentials are used to authenticate access to resources. There are three types of credentials:
trans-unit.target: Each user has a unique set of credentials. These credentials are used to authenticate access to resources. There are three types of credentials:

trans-unit.source: An X.509 certificate is used to authenticate requests to the SOAP API service.
trans-unit.target: An X.509 certificate is used to authenticate requests to the SOAP API service.

trans-unit.source: A secret access key is used to authenticate requests to the REST API service.
trans-unit.target: A secret access key is used to authenticate requests to the REST API service.

trans-unit.source: A login password is used to authenticate the Eucalyptus Dashboard access.
trans-unit.target: A login password is used to authenticate the Eucalyptus Dashboard access.

trans-unit.source: You can manage credentials using the command line tools (the euare- commands) or the Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: You can manage credentials using the command line tools (the euare- commands) or the Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: In IAM, each account has its own credentials. In Eucalyptus, the equivalent of account credentials are the credentials of admin user of the account.
trans-unit.target: In IAM, each account has its own credentials. In Eucalyptus, the equivalent of account credentials are the credentials of admin user of the account.

trans-unit.source: You can download the full set of credentials for a user or an account, including X509 certificate and secret access key, by:
trans-unit.target: You can download the full set of credentials for a user or an account, including X509 certificate and secret access key, by:

trans-unit.source: or by using the Download new credentials in the Eucalyptus Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: or by using the Download new credentials in the Eucalyptus Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Whichever way to request the credentials, Eucalyptus returns the following:
trans-unit.target: Whichever way to request the credentials, Eucalyptus returns the following:

trans-unit.source: An arbitrary existing active secret access key
trans-unit.target: An arbitrary existing active secret access key

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: You can create accounts two ways:
trans-unit.target: You can create accounts two ways:

trans-unit.source: Direct creation using command line tool or Eucalyptus dashboard by sys admin. The accounts created in this method will be available for accessing immediately.
trans-unit.target: Direct creation using command line tool or Eucalyptus dashboard by sys admin. The accounts created in this method will be available for accessing immediately.

trans-unit.source: Registration process. One can apply for an account through the dashboard. The process is as follows: The cloud user registers using the form on the dashboard interface. An email will then be sent to the sys admin for review. Sys admin can approve or reject the application by invoking a URL included in the email. A notification email will be sent to the intended account owner. If the application is approved, the account owner needs to invoke the URL included in the notification email to confirm the approval. Once confirmed, the new account becomes available.
trans-unit.target: Registration process. One can apply for an account through the dashboard. The process is as follows: The cloud user registers using the form on the dashboard interface. An email will then be sent to the sys admin for review. Sys admin can approve or reject the application by invoking a URL included in the email. A notification email will be sent to the intended account owner. If the application is approved, the account owner needs to invoke the URL included in the notification email to confirm the approval. Once confirmed, the new account becomes available.

trans-unit.source: The account registration status can be found in Dashboard. The account registration status is actually associated with the account admin user. That means you can use the following command to obtain the same information:
trans-unit.target: The account registration status can be found in Dashboard. The account registration status is actually associated with the account admin user. That means you can use the following command to obtain the same information:

trans-unit.source: Where the --show-extra option displays extra information of a user in the following order:
trans-unit.target: Where the --show-extra option displays extra information of a user in the following order:

trans-unit.source: The account registration status has the following values based on the status of registration process: REGISTERED, APPROVED, or CONFIRMED. An account that is not confirmed cannot be used or accessed. The system administrator can manipulate the account registration status in both dashboard and command line:
trans-unit.target: The account registration status has the following values based on the status of registration process: REGISTERED, APPROVED, or CONFIRMED. An account that is not confirmed cannot be used or accessed. The system administrator can manipulate the account registration status in both dashboard and command line:

trans-unit.source: The command line manipulation of the registration status does not send the notification emails. So unless you experienced, we recommend that you use the Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: The command line manipulation of the registration status does not send the notification emails. So unless you experienced, we recommend that you use the Dashboard.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus extends the IAM model by providing the following extra attributes for a user.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus extends the IAM model by providing the following extra attributes for a user.

trans-unit.source: Registration status: This is only meaningful for the account administrator (that is, the account level).
trans-unit.target: Registration status: This is only meaningful for the account administrator (that is, the account level).

trans-unit.source: Enabled status: . Use this attribute to temporarily disable a user.
trans-unit.target: Enabled status: . Use this attribute to temporarily disable a user.

trans-unit.source: Custom information: Add any name-value pair to a user’s custom information attribute. This is useful for attaching pure text information, like an address, phone number, or department. This is especially helpful with external LDAP or Active Directory services.
trans-unit.target: Custom information: Add any name-value pair to a user’s custom information attribute. This is useful for attaching pure text information, like an address, phone number, or department. This is especially helpful with external LDAP or Active Directory services.

trans-unit.source: You can retrieve and modify the registration status, enabled status, and password expiration date using the euare-usergetattributes and euare-usermod commands. You can retrieve and modify custom information using euare-usergetinfo and euare-userupdateinfo commands. For more information, see the CLI Reference Guide for details about these commands.
trans-unit.target: You can retrieve and modify the registration status, enabled status, and password expiration date using the euare-usergetattributes and euare-usermod commands. You can retrieve and modify custom information using euare-usergetinfo and euare-userupdateinfo commands. For more information, see the CLI Reference Guide for details about these commands.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus uses the same policy language to specify user level permissions as AWS IAM. Policies are written in JSON. Each policy file can contain multiple statements, each specifying a permission. A permission statement specifies whether to allow or deny a list of actions to be performed on a list of resources, under specific conditions.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus uses the same policy language to specify user level permissions as AWS IAM. Policies are written in JSON. Each policy file can contain multiple statements, each specifying a permission. A permission statement specifies whether to allow or deny a list of actions to be performed on a list of resources, under specific conditions.

trans-unit.source: A permission statement has the following components:
trans-unit.target: A permission statement has the following components:

trans-unit.source: Effect: Begins the decision that applies to all following components. Either: “Allow” or “Deny”
trans-unit.target: Effect: Begins the decision that applies to all following components. Either: “Allow” or “Deny”

trans-unit.source: Action or NotAction: Indicates service-specific and case-sensitive commands. For example: “ec2:RunInstances”
trans-unit.target: Action or NotAction: Indicates service-specific and case-sensitive commands. For example: “ec2:RunInstances”

trans-unit.source: Resource or NotResource: Indicates selected resources, each specified as an Amazon resource name (ARN). For example: “arn:aws:s3:::acme_bucket/blob”
trans-unit.target: Resource or NotResource: Indicates selected resources, each specified as an Amazon resource name (ARN). For example: “arn:aws:s3:::acme_bucket/blob”

trans-unit.source: Condition: Indicates additional constraints of the permission. For example: "DateGreaterThan"
trans-unit.target: Condition: Indicates additional constraints of the permission. For example: "DateGreaterThan"

trans-unit.source:
The following policy example contains a statement that gives a user with full permission. This is the same access as the account
administrator:
trans-unit.target:
The following policy example contains a statement that gives a user with full permission. This is the same access as the account
administrator:

trans-unit.source: For more information about policy language, go to the IAM User Guide.
trans-unit.target: For more information about policy language, go to the IAM User Guide.

trans-unit.source: You can combine IAM policies with account level permissions. For example, the admin of account A can give users in account B permission to launch one of account A’s images by changing the image attributes. Then the admin of account B can use IAM policy to designate the users who can actually use the shared images.
trans-unit.target: You can combine IAM policies with account level permissions. For example, the admin of account A can give users in account B permission to launch one of account A’s images by changing the image attributes. Then the admin of account B can use IAM policy to designate the users who can actually use the shared images.

trans-unit.source: You can attach IAM policies to both users and groups. When attached to groups, a policy is equivalent to attaching the same policy to the users within that group. Therefore, a user might have multiple policies attached, both policies attached to the user, and policies attached to the group that the user belongs to.
trans-unit.target: You can attach IAM policies to both users and groups. When attached to groups, a policy is equivalent to attaching the same policy to the users within that group. Therefore, a user might have multiple policies attached, both policies attached to the user, and policies attached to the group that the user belongs to.

trans-unit.source: Do not attach IAM policies (except quota policies, a Eucalyptus extension) to account admins. At this point, doing so won’t result in a failure but may have unexpected consequences.
trans-unit.target: Do not attach IAM policies (except quota policies, a Eucalyptus extension) to account admins. At this point, doing so won’t result in a failure but may have unexpected consequences.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus extends the IAM policy in order to meet the needs of enterprise customers.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus extends the IAM policy in order to meet the needs of enterprise customers.

trans-unit.source: In IAM, you cannot specify EC2 resources in a policy statement except a wildcard,“*”. So, it is not possible to constrain a permission on specific EC2 entities. For example, you can't restrict a user to run instances on a specific image or VM type. To solve that, Eucalyptus created the EC2 resource for the policy language. The following example shows the ARN of an EC2 resource.
trans-unit.target: In IAM, you cannot specify EC2 resources in a policy statement except a wildcard,“*”. So, it is not possible to constrain a permission on specific EC2 entities. For example, you can't restrict a user to run instances on a specific image or VM type. To solve that, Eucalyptus created the EC2 resource for the policy language. The following example shows the ARN of an EC2 resource.

trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus supports the following resource types for EC2:

trans-unit.target: address (either an address or address range: 192.168.7.1-192.168.7.255)

trans-unit.target: The following example specifies permission to launch instances with only an m1.small VM type:

trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus implements the following AWS policy keys:

trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus extends the policy keys by adding the following to the lifetime of an instance:

trans-unit.target: ec2:KeepAlive: specifies the length of time that an instance can run

trans-unit.target: Different identities have different default access permissions. When no policy is associated with them, these identities have the permission listed in the following table.

trans-unit.source: Access to all resources in the system

trans-unit.target: Access to all account resources, including those shared resources from other accounts like public images and shared snapshots

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus adds quota enforcement to resource usage. To avoid introducing another configuration language into Eucalyptus, and simplify the management, we extend the IAM policy language to support quotas. The only addition added to the language is the new limit effect. If a policy statement’s effect is limit, it is a quota statement.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus adds quota enforcement to resource usage. To avoid introducing another configuration language into Eucalyptus, and simplify the management, we extend the IAM policy language to support quotas. The only addition added to the language is the new limit effect. If a policy statement’s effect is limit, it is a quota statement.

trans-unit.source: A quota statement also has action and resource fields. You can use these fields to match specific requests, for example, quota only being checked on matched requests. The actual quota type and value are specified using special quota keys, and listed in the condition part of the statement. Only condition type NumericLessThanEquals can be used with quota keys.
trans-unit.target: A quota statement also has action and resource fields. You can use these fields to match specific requests, for example, quota only being checked on matched requests. The actual quota type and value are specified using special quota keys, and listed in the condition part of the statement. Only condition type NumericLessThanEquals can be used with quota keys.

trans-unit.source: An account can only have a quota policy. If you attach an IAM policy to an account (where, for example, the Effect is "Allow" or "Deny"), there will be unexpected results.
trans-unit.target: An account can only have a quota policy. If you attach an IAM policy to an account (where, for example, the Effect is "Allow" or "Deny"), there will be unexpected results.

trans-unit.source: The following quota policy statement limits the attached user to only launch a maximum of 16 instances in an account.
trans-unit.target: The following quota policy statement limits the attached user to only launch a maximum of 16 instances in an account.

trans-unit.source: You can attach quotas to both users and accounts, although some of the quotas only apply to accounts. Quota attached to groups will take no effect.
trans-unit.target: You can attach quotas to both users and accounts, although some of the quotas only apply to accounts. Quota attached to groups will take no effect.

trans-unit.source: When a quota policy is attached to an account, it actually is attached to the account administrator user. Since only system administrator can specify account quotas, the account administrator can only inspect quotas but can't change the quotas attached to herself.
trans-unit.target: When a quota policy is attached to an account, it actually is attached to the account administrator user. Since only system administrator can specify account quotas, the account administrator can only inspect quotas but can't change the quotas attached to herself.

trans-unit.source: The following is all the quota keys implemented in Eucalyptus:
trans-unit.target: The following is all the quota keys implemented in Eucalyptus:

trans-unit.source: Number of objects in each bucket,
trans-unit.target: Number of objects in each bucket,

trans-unit.source: total size of all buckets, in MB
trans-unit.target: total size of all buckets, in MB

trans-unit.source: Number of total volume size, in GB
trans-unit.target: Number of total volume size, in GB

trans-unit.source: Contrary to IAM policies, by default, there is no quota limits (except the hard system limit) on any resource allocations for a user or an account. Also, system administrators are not constrained by any quota. Account administrators are only be constrained by account quota.
trans-unit.target: Contrary to IAM policies, by default, there is no quota limits (except the hard system limit) on any resource allocations for a user or an account. Also, system administrators are not constrained by any quota. Account administrators are only be constrained by account quota.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus uses two types of algorithms to determine access.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus uses two types of algorithms to determine access.

trans-unit.source: You can associated multiple policies and permission statements with a user. The way these are combined together to control the access to resources in an account is defined by the policy evaluation algorithm. Eucalyptus implements the same policy evaluation algorithm as IAM:
trans-unit.target: You can associated multiple policies and permission statements with a user. The way these are combined together to control the access to resources in an account is defined by the policy evaluation algorithm. Eucalyptus implements the same policy evaluation algorithm as IAM:

trans-unit.source: If the request user is account admin, access is allowed.
trans-unit.target: If the request user is account admin, access is allowed.

trans-unit.source:
Otherwise, collect all the policy statements associated with the request user (attached to the user and all the groups the user belongs to), which match the incoming request (i.e. based on the API being invoked and the resources it is going to access).
If there is no matched policy statement, access is denied (default implicit deny). Otherwise, evaluate each policy statement that matches.
If there is a statement that explicitly denies the access, the request is denied. If there is no explicit deny, which means there is at least one explicit allow, access is allowed.
trans-unit.target:
Otherwise, collect all the policy statements associated with the request user (attached to the user and all the groups the user belongs to), which match the incoming request (i.e. based on the API being invoked and the resources it is going to access).
If there is no matched policy statement, access is denied (default implicit deny). Otherwise, evaluate each policy statement that matches.
If there is a statement that explicitly denies the access, the request is denied. If there is no explicit deny, which means there is at least one explicit allow, access is allowed.

trans-unit.source: Now we give the overall access evaluation combining both account level permissions and IAM permissions, which decides whether a request is accepted by Eucalyptus:
trans-unit.target: Now we give the overall access evaluation combining both account level permissions and IAM permissions, which decides whether a request is accepted by Eucalyptus:

trans-unit.source: If the request user is sys admin, access is allowed.
trans-unit.target: If the request user is sys admin, access is allowed.

trans-unit.source:
Otherwise, check account level permissions, e.g. image launch permission, to see if the request user’s account has access to the specific resources.
If not, the access is denied. Otherwise, invoke the policy evaluation algorithm to check if the request user has access to the resources based on IAM policies.
trans-unit.target:
Otherwise, check account level permissions, e.g. image launch permission, to see if the request user’s account has access to the specific resources.
If not, the access is denied. Otherwise, invoke the policy evaluation algorithm to check if the request user has access to the resources based on IAM policies.

trans-unit.source: Like the normal IAM policies, a user may be associated with multiple quota policies (and multiple quota statements). How all the quota policies are combined to take effect is defined by the quota evaluation algorithm:
trans-unit.target: Like the normal IAM policies, a user may be associated with multiple quota policies (and multiple quota statements). How all the quota policies are combined to take effect is defined by the quota evaluation algorithm:

trans-unit.source: If the request user is sys admin, there is no limit on resource usage.
trans-unit.target: If the request user is sys admin, there is no limit on resource usage.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, collect all the quotas associated with the request user, including those attached to the request user’s account and those attached to the request user himself/herself (for account admin, we only need collect account quotas).
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, collect all the quotas associated with the request user, including those attached to the request user’s account and those attached to the request user himself/herself (for account admin, we only need collect account quotas).

trans-unit.source: Evaluate each quota one by one. Reject the request as long as there is one quota being exceeded by the request. Otherwise, accept the request.
trans-unit.target: Evaluate each quota one by one. Reject the request as long as there is one quota being exceeded by the request. Otherwise, accept the request.

trans-unit.source: The hard limits on some resources override quota limits. For example, walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb (system property) overrides the s3:quota-bucketsize (quota key).
trans-unit.target: The hard limits on some resources override quota limits. For example, walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb (system property) overrides the s3:quota-bucketsize (quota key).

trans-unit.source: You can use the Eucalyptus LDAP/Active Directory (AD) integration to synchronize existing LDAP/AD user and group information with Eucalyptus. When you enable LDAP/AD synchronization, Eucalyptus does the following:
trans-unit.target: You can use the Eucalyptus LDAP/Active Directory (AD) integration to synchronize existing LDAP/AD user and group information with Eucalyptus. When you enable LDAP/AD synchronization, Eucalyptus does the following:

trans-unit.source: Imports specified user and group information from LDAP or AD and maps them into a predefined two-tier account/group/user structure
trans-unit.target: Imports specified user and group information from LDAP or AD and maps them into a predefined two-tier account/group/user structure

trans-unit.source: Authenticates Dashboard users through the connected LDAP or AD service
trans-unit.target: Authenticates Dashboard users through the connected LDAP or AD service

trans-unit.source: Note that Eucalyptus only imports the identities and some related information. Any Eucalyptus-specific attributes are still managed from Eucalyptus. These include:
trans-unit.target: Note that Eucalyptus only imports the identities and some related information. Any Eucalyptus-specific attributes are still managed from Eucalyptus. These include:

trans-unit.source: User credentials: secret access keys and X.509 certificates. The Dashboard login password is an exception. Eucalyptus does not download passwords from LDAP/AD and does not save them either. Eucalyptus authenticates Dashboard logins directly through LDAP/AD, using LDAP/AD authentication (simple or SASL).
trans-unit.target: User credentials: secret access keys and X.509 certificates. The Dashboard login password is an exception. Eucalyptus does not download passwords from LDAP/AD and does not save them either. Eucalyptus authenticates Dashboard logins directly through LDAP/AD, using LDAP/AD authentication (simple or SASL).

trans-unit.source: Policies: IAM policies and quotas. Policies are associated with identities within Eucalyptus, and stored in internal database.
trans-unit.target: Policies: IAM policies and quotas. Policies are associated with identities within Eucalyptus, and stored in internal database.

trans-unit.source: Also note that special identities, including system administrators and account administrators, are created in Eucalyptus and not imported from LDAP/AD. Only normal user identities are imported.
trans-unit.target: Also note that special identities, including system administrators and account administrators, are created in Eucalyptus and not imported from LDAP/AD. Only normal user identities are imported.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Identities in LDAP/AD are organized differently from the identity structure in Eucalyptus. So a transformation is required to map LDAP/AD identities into Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: Identities in LDAP/AD are organized differently from the identity structure in Eucalyptus. So a transformation is required to map LDAP/AD identities into Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: The following image shows a simple scheme of how the mapping works. In this scheme, the user groups in LDAP tree are partitioned into two sets. Each set is mapped into one separate account. Group 1, 2 and 3 are mapped to Account 1 and Group 4 and 5 are mapped to Account 2. As the result, all users in Group 1, 2 and 3 will be in Account 1, and all users in Group 4 and 5 will be in Account 2.
trans-unit.target: The following image shows a simple scheme of how the mapping works. In this scheme, the user groups in LDAP tree are partitioned into two sets. Each set is mapped into one separate account. Group 1, 2 and 3 are mapped to Account 1 and Group 4 and 5 are mapped to Account 2. As the result, all users in Group 1, 2 and 3 will be in Account 1, and all users in Group 4 and 5 will be in Account 2.

trans-unit.source:
Pick user groups from LDAP/AD and combine them into different accounts. There are two ways of doing this:
Use something called accounting groups. Account groups are essentially groups of groups. Each accounting group contains multiple user groups in LDAP/AD. Then each accounting group maps to an account in Eucalyptus. Manually partition groups into accounts. Each group partition maps to an account.
trans-unit.target:
Pick user groups from LDAP/AD and combine them into different accounts. There are two ways of doing this:
Use something called accounting groups. Account groups are essentially groups of groups. Each accounting group contains multiple user groups in LDAP/AD. Then each accounting group maps to an account in Eucalyptus. Manually partition groups into accounts. Each group partition maps to an account.

trans-unit.source: Once the accounts are defined (by accounting groups or group partitions), all the LDAP/AD user groups will be mapped into Eucalyptus groups within specific accounts; and LDAP/AD users will be mapped into Eucalyptus users. You also have options to filter the groups and users to be imported into Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: Once the accounts are defined (by accounting groups or group partitions), all the LDAP/AD user groups will be mapped into Eucalyptus groups within specific accounts; and LDAP/AD users will be mapped into Eucalyptus users. You also have options to filter the groups and users to be imported into Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: Note that each group can be mapped into multiple accounts. But understand that Eucalyptus accounts are separate name spaces. So for groups and users that are mapped into different accounts, their information (name, attributes, etc) will be duplicated in different accounts. And duplicated users will have separate credentials in different accounts. For example, Group 1 may map to both Account 1 and Account 2. Say user A belongs to Group 1. Then Account 1 will have user A and Account 2 will also have user A. User A in Account 1 and user A in Account 2 will have different credentials, policies, etc., but the same user information.
trans-unit.target: Note that each group can be mapped into multiple accounts. But understand that Eucalyptus accounts are separate name spaces. So for groups and users that are mapped into different accounts, their information (name, attributes, etc) will be duplicated in different accounts. And duplicated users will have separate credentials in different accounts. For example, Group 1 may map to both Account 1 and Account 2. Say user A belongs to Group 1. Then Account 1 will have user A and Account 2 will also have user A. User A in Account 1 and user A in Account 2 will have different credentials, policies, etc., but the same user information.

trans-unit.source: Currently, there is not a way to map individual users into an account. The mapping unit is LDAP user group.
trans-unit.target: Currently, there is not a way to map individual users into an account. The mapping unit is LDAP user group.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: The LDAP/AD Integration Configuration (LIC) is a JSON format file. This file specifies everything Eucalyptus needs to know about how to synchronize with an LDAP or AD service.
trans-unit.target: The LDAP/AD Integration Configuration (LIC) is a JSON format file. This file specifies everything Eucalyptus needs to know about how to synchronize with an LDAP or AD service.

trans-unit.source: You can find a LIC template at /usr/share/eucalyptus/lic_template. This template shows all the fields of the LIC, and provides detailed documentation and example values for each field.
trans-unit.target: You can find a LIC template at /usr/share/eucalyptus/lic_template. This template shows all the fields of the LIC, and provides detailed documentation and example values for each field.

trans-unit.source: To start a LIC file, use the LIC command line tool.
trans-unit.target: To start a LIC file, use the LIC command line tool.

trans-unit.source: The above command invokes the LIC tool to create a template LIC and fill in the encrypted password for authenticating to LDAP/AD service (i.e. the password of the administrative user for accessing the LDAP/AD during synchronization). The LIC tool’s primary functions are to encrypt the LDAP/AD password and to generate the starting LIC template. The usage of the LIC tool shows different ways to invoke the command.
trans-unit.target: The above command invokes the LIC tool to create a template LIC and fill in the encrypted password for authenticating to LDAP/AD service (i.e. the password of the administrative user for accessing the LDAP/AD during synchronization). The LIC tool’s primary functions are to encrypt the LDAP/AD password and to generate the starting LIC template. The usage of the LIC tool shows different ways to invoke the command.

trans-unit.source: Once you have the LIC template, you can fill in the details by editing the “*.lic” file using your favorite editor as it is a simple text file. As we said above, the LIC file is in JSON format. Each top level entity specifies one aspect of the LDAP/AD synchronization. The following shows one possible example of a LIC file.
trans-unit.target: Once you have the LIC template, you can fill in the details by editing the “*.lic” file using your favorite editor as it is a simple text file. As we said above, the LIC file is in JSON format. Each top level entity specifies one aspect of the LDAP/AD synchronization. The following shows one possible example of a LIC file.

trans-unit.source: In the following sections explain each field of LIC in detail.
trans-unit.target: In the following sections explain each field of LIC in detail.

xmrk:reference.domains: (topic reference) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: The ldap-service element contains everything related to the LDAP/AD service.
trans-unit.target: The ldap-service element contains everything related to the LDAP/AD service.

trans-unit.source: The LDAP/AD server URL, starting with ldap:// or ldaps://.
trans-unit.target: The LDAP/AD server URL, starting with ldap:// or ldaps://.

trans-unit.source: The LDAP/AD authentication method to perform synchronization.
trans-unit.target: The LDAP/AD authentication method to perform synchronization.

trans-unit.source: The ID of the administrative user for synchronization.
trans-unit.target: The ID of the administrative user for synchronization.

trans-unit.source: The credentials for LDAP/AD authentication, like a password. We recommend that you encrypt this using /usr/sbin/euca-lictool.
trans-unit.target: The credentials for LDAP/AD authentication, like a password. We recommend that you encrypt this using /usr/sbin/euca-lictool.

trans-unit.source:
The LDAP/AD authentication method for normal users to perform Dashboard login.
simple: for clear text user/password authentication.
DIGEST-MD5: for SASL authentication using MD5
GSSAPI: SASL authentication using Kerberos V5.
trans-unit.target:
The LDAP/AD authentication method for normal users to perform Dashboard login.
simple: for clear text user/password authentication.
DIGEST-MD5: for SASL authentication using MD5
GSSAPI: SASL authentication using Kerberos V5.

trans-unit.source: Specifies whether to use SSL for connecting to LDAP/AD service.
trans-unit.target: Specifies whether to use SSL for connecting to LDAP/AD service.

trans-unit.source: Specifies whether to ignore self-signed SSL certs. This is useful when you only have self-signed SSL certs for your LDAP/AD services.
trans-unit.target: Specifies whether to ignore self-signed SSL certs. This is useful when you only have self-signed SSL certs for your LDAP/AD services.

trans-unit.source: The file path for krb5.conf, if you use GSSAPI authentication method.
trans-unit.target: The file path for krb5.conf, if you use GSSAPI authentication method.

xmrk:reference.domains: (topic reference) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: The sync element contains elements for controlling synchronization.
trans-unit.target: The sync element contains elements for controlling synchronization.

trans-unit.source: States whether the Dashboard uses LDAP rather than the Eucalyptus database for log-ins. Set to true to turn on LDAP web logging. Set to false to use the Eucalyptus database for web logging. If set to false, you can ignore all other fields in this section. Default value: false
trans-unit.target: States whether the Dashboard uses LDAP rather than the Eucalyptus database for log-ins. Set to true to turn on LDAP web logging. Set to false to use the Eucalyptus database for web logging. If set to false, you can ignore all other fields in this section. Default value: false

trans-unit.source: Set to true to turn on automatic synchronization. Set to false to turn off synchronization.
trans-unit.target: Set to true to turn on automatic synchronization. Set to false to turn off synchronization.

trans-unit.source: The length in milliseconds of the automatic synchronization interval.
trans-unit.target: The length in milliseconds of the automatic synchronization interval.

trans-unit.source: Parmeter denoting whether to remove identity entities from Eucalyptus when they are deleted from LDAP. Set to true if you want Eucalyptus to remove any identities once their counterparts in LDAP are deleted. Set to false if you want these identities kept without being purged.
trans-unit.target: Parmeter denoting whether to remove identity entities from Eucalyptus when they are deleted from LDAP. Set to true if you want Eucalyptus to remove any identities once their counterparts in LDAP are deleted. Set to false if you want these identities kept without being purged.

xmrk:reference.domains: (topic reference) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: This section uses a special group in LDAP/AD to designate accounts in the Eucalyptus “accounting group.” The accounting group takes normal LDAP/AD groups as members, i.e., they are groups of groups. The accounting group’s name becomes the account name in Eucalyptus. The member groups become Eucalyptus groups in that account. And the users of all those groups become Eucalyptus users within that account and corresponding Eucalyptus groups.
trans-unit.target: This section uses a special group in LDAP/AD to designate accounts in the Eucalyptus “accounting group.” The accounting group takes normal LDAP/AD groups as members, i.e., they are groups of groups. The accounting group’s name becomes the account name in Eucalyptus. The member groups become Eucalyptus groups in that account. And the users of all those groups become Eucalyptus users within that account and corresponding Eucalyptus groups.

trans-unit.source: If you use accounting-groups, remove the groups-partition section. These two sections are mutually exclusive.
trans-unit.target: If you use accounting-groups, remove the groups-partition section. These two sections are mutually exclusive.

trans-unit.source: The base DN of accounting groups in the LDAP/AD tree.
trans-unit.target: The base DN of accounting groups in the LDAP/AD tree.

trans-unit.source: The ID attribute name of the accounting group entry in LDAP/AD tree.
trans-unit.target: The ID attribute name of the accounting group entry in LDAP/AD tree.

trans-unit.source: The LDAP/AD attribute name for members of the accounting group.
trans-unit.target: The LDAP/AD attribute name for members of the accounting group.

trans-unit.source:
The accounting groups you want to map to. This contains the following elements:
filter: The LDAP/AD searching filter used for the LDAP/AD search to get the relevant LDAP/AD entities, e.g. the users to be synchronized. (Example: objectClass=groupOfNames)
select: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities to be synchronized, in case they can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToSelect,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)
not-select: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities NOT to be synchronized, in case this can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToIgnore,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)
trans-unit.target:
The accounting groups you want to map to. This contains the following elements:
filter: The LDAP/AD searching filter used for the LDAP/AD search to get the relevant LDAP/AD entities, e.g. the users to be synchronized. (Example: objectClass=groupOfNames)
select: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities to be synchronized, in case they can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToSelect,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)
not-select: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities NOT to be synchronized, in case this can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToIgnore,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)

trans-unit.source: Like accounting-groups, groups-partition specifies how to map LDAP/AD groups to Eucalyptus accounts. However, in this section you to manually specify which LDAP/AD groups you want to map to Eucalyputs accounts.
trans-unit.target: Like accounting-groups, groups-partition specifies how to map LDAP/AD groups to Eucalyptus accounts. However, in this section you to manually specify which LDAP/AD groups you want to map to Eucalyputs accounts.

trans-unit.source: If you use groups-partition, remove the accounting-groups section. These two sections are mutually exclusive.
trans-unit.target: If you use groups-partition, remove the accounting-groups section. These two sections are mutually exclusive.

trans-unit.source: The Eucalyptus accounts are created by partitioning LDAP/AD groups. Each partition composes an Eucalyptus account. So all the groups within the partition become Eucalyptus groups within that account. All the users of those groups will become Eucalyptus users within that account and the corresponding Eucalyptus groups.
trans-unit.target: The Eucalyptus accounts are created by partitioning LDAP/AD groups. Each partition composes an Eucalyptus account. So all the groups within the partition become Eucalyptus groups within that account. All the users of those groups will become Eucalyptus users within that account and the corresponding Eucalyptus groups.

trans-unit.source: This section requires that you specify one partition at a time, using a list of JSON key-value pairs. For each entry, the key is the account name to be mapped and the value is a list of names of LDAP/AD groups to be mapped into the account. For example:
trans-unit.target: This section requires that you specify one partition at a time, using a list of JSON key-value pairs. For each entry, the key is the account name to be mapped and the value is a list of names of LDAP/AD groups to be mapped into the account. For example:

trans-unit.source: Here salesmarketing and devsupport are names for the groups partition and are used as the corresponding Eucalyptus account names.
trans-unit.target: Here salesmarketing and devsupport are names for the groups partition and are used as the corresponding Eucalyptus account names.

trans-unit.source: If you use groups-partition, remove the accounting-groups section. These two sections are mutually exclusive.
trans-unit.target: If you use groups-partition, remove the accounting-groups section. These two sections are mutually exclusive.

trans-unit.source: This groups element specifies how to map LDAP/AD groups to Eucalyptus groups. It contains the elements listed in the following table. The meanings are similar to those in accounting-groups element.
trans-unit.target: This groups element specifies how to map LDAP/AD groups to Eucalyptus groups. It contains the elements listed in the following table. The meanings are similar to those in accounting-groups element.

trans-unit.source: The base DN for searching groups.
trans-unit.target: The base DN for searching groups.

trans-unit.source: The ID attribute name of the LDAP group.
trans-unit.target: The ID attribute name of the LDAP group.

trans-unit.source: The name of the attribute for group members. Usually, it is member in modern LDAP implementation, which lists full user DN.
trans-unit.target: The name of the attribute for group members. Usually, it is member in modern LDAP implementation, which lists full user DN.

trans-unit.source:
The specific LDAP/AD groups you want to map to. This contains the following elements:
filter: The LDAP/AD searching filter used for the LDAP/AD search to get the relevant LDAP/AD entities, e.g. the users to be synchronized. (Example: objectClass=groupOfNames)
select: The LDAP/AD searching filter used for the LDAP/AD search to get the relevant LDAP/AD entities, e.g. the users to be synchronized. (Example: objectClass=groupOfNames)
not-select: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities NOT to be synchronized, in case this can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToIgnore,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)
trans-unit.target:
The specific LDAP/AD groups you want to map to. This contains the following elements:
filter: The LDAP/AD searching filter used for the LDAP/AD search to get the relevant LDAP/AD entities, e.g. the users to be synchronized. (Example: objectClass=groupOfNames)
select: The LDAP/AD searching filter used for the LDAP/AD search to get the relevant LDAP/AD entities, e.g. the users to be synchronized. (Example: objectClass=groupOfNames)
not-select: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities NOT to be synchronized, in case this can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToIgnore,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)

xmrk:reference.domains: (topic reference) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities NOT to be synchronized, in case this can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToIgnore,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)
trans-unit.target: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities NOT to be synchronized, in case this can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToIgnore,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)

trans-unit.source: The base DN for searching users.
trans-unit.target: The base DN for searching users.

trans-unit.source: The attribute ID of the LDAP user.
trans-unit.target: The attribute ID of the LDAP user.

trans-unit.source:
The specific LDAP/AD users you want to map to. This contains the following elements:
filter: The LDAP/AD searching filter used for the LDAP/AD search to get the relevant LDAP/AD entities, e.g. the users to be synchronized. (Example: objectClass=groupOfNames)
select: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities to be synchronized, in case they can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToSelect,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)
not-select: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities NOT to be synchronized, in case this can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToIgnore,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)
trans-unit.target:
The specific LDAP/AD users you want to map to. This contains the following elements:
filter: The LDAP/AD searching filter used for the LDAP/AD search to get the relevant LDAP/AD entities, e.g. the users to be synchronized. (Example: objectClass=groupOfNames)
select: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities to be synchronized, in case they can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToSelect,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)
not-select: Explicitly gives the full DN of entities NOT to be synchronized, in case this can not be specified by the search filter. (Example: cn=groupToIgnore,ou=Groups,dc=foo,dc=com)

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: The synchronization always starts when the following happens:
trans-unit.target: The synchronization always starts when the following happens:

trans-unit.source: You manually upload a LDAP/AD Integration Configuration (LIC) file. Every new or updated LIC upload triggers a new synchronization.
trans-unit.target: You manually upload a LDAP/AD Integration Configuration (LIC) file. Every new or updated LIC upload triggers a new synchronization.

trans-unit.source: If the automatic synchronization is enabled, a synchronization is started when the timer goes off.
trans-unit.target: If the automatic synchronization is enabled, a synchronization is started when the timer goes off.

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus does not allow concurrent synchronization. If you trigger synchronization more than once within a short time period, Eucalyptus only allows the first one.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus does not allow concurrent synchronization. If you trigger synchronization more than once within a short time period, Eucalyptus only allows the first one.

trans-unit.source: During a synchronization, everything specified by an LIC in the LDAP/AD tree will be downloaded into Eucalyptus’ internal database. Each synchronization is a merging process of the information already in the database and the information from LDAP/AD. There are three cases for each entity: user, group or account:
trans-unit.target: During a synchronization, everything specified by an LIC in the LDAP/AD tree will be downloaded into Eucalyptus’ internal database. Each synchronization is a merging process of the information already in the database and the information from LDAP/AD. There are three cases for each entity: user, group or account:

trans-unit.source: If an entity from LDAP/AD is not in Eucalyptus, a new one is created in the database.
trans-unit.target: If an entity from LDAP/AD is not in Eucalyptus, a new one is created in the database.

trans-unit.source: If an entity from LDAP/AD is already in Eucalyptus, the Eucalyptus version is updated. For example, if a user’s info attributes are changed, those changes are downloaded and updated.
trans-unit.target: If an entity from LDAP/AD is already in Eucalyptus, the Eucalyptus version is updated. For example, if a user’s info attributes are changed, those changes are downloaded and updated.

trans-unit.source: If an entity in Eucalyptus is missing from LDAP/AD, it will be removed from the database if the clean-deletion option in LIC is set to true. Otherwise, it will be left in the database.
trans-unit.target: If an entity in Eucalyptus is missing from LDAP/AD, it will be removed from the database if the clean-deletion option in LIC is set to true. Otherwise, it will be left in the database.

trans-unit.source: If clean-deletion is set to true, the removed entities in Eucalyptus will be lost forever, along with all its permissions and credentials. The resources associated with the entity will be left untouched. It is system administrator’s job to recycle these resources.
trans-unit.target: If clean-deletion is set to true, the removed entities in Eucalyptus will be lost forever, along with all its permissions and credentials. The resources associated with the entity will be left untouched. It is system administrator’s job to recycle these resources.

trans-unit.source: This section provides details about the tasks you perform using policies and identities. The tasks you can perform are divided up into tasks for users, tasks for groups, and tasks for policies.
trans-unit.target: This section provides details about the tasks you perform using policies and identities. The tasks you can perform are divided up into tasks for users, tasks for groups, and tasks for policies.

trans-unit.source: The following use cases detail work flows for common processes:
trans-unit.target: The following use cases detail work flows for common processes:

trans-unit.source: You can perform the following access-related tasks listed in the following sections:
trans-unit.target: You can perform the following access-related tasks listed in the following sections:

trans-unit.source: This use case details tasks for creating an administrator. These tasks require that you have your account credentials for sending requests to Eucalyptus using the command line interface (CLI) tools.
trans-unit.target: This use case details tasks for creating an administrator. These tasks require that you have your account credentials for sending requests to Eucalyptus using the command line interface (CLI) tools.

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus recommends using account credentials as little as possible. You can avoid using account credentials by creating a group of users with administrative privileges.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus recommends using account credentials as little as possible. You can avoid using account credentials by creating a group of users with administrative privileges.

trans-unit.source: Verify that the group was created.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the group was created.

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus returns a listing of the groups that have been created, as in the following example.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus returns a listing of the groups that have been created, as in the following example.

trans-unit.source: Add a Policy to the Group
trans-unit.target: Add a Policy to the Group

trans-unit.source: Add a policy to the administrators group that allows its members to perform all actions in Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: Add a policy to the administrators group that allows its members to perform all actions in Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to create a policy called admin-root that grants all actions on all resources to all users in the administrators group:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to create a policy called admin-root that grants all actions on all resources to all users in the administrators group:

trans-unit.source: Create a user for day-to-day administrative work and add that user to the administrators group.
trans-unit.target: Create a user for day-to-day administrative work and add that user to the administrators group.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to create an administrative user named alice:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to create an administrative user named alice:

trans-unit.source: Add the new administrative user to the administrators group.
trans-unit.target: Add the new administrative user to the administrators group.

trans-unit.source: To start running commands as the new administrative user, you must create an access key for that user.
trans-unit.target: To start running commands as the new administrative user, you must create an access key for that user.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to generate an access key for the administrative user:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to generate an access key for the administrative user:

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus returns the access key ID and the user's secret key.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus returns the access key ID and the user's secret key.

trans-unit.source: Open the ~/.eucarc file and replace your account credentials you just created, as in this example:
trans-unit.target: Open the ~/.eucarc file and replace your account credentials you just created, as in this example:

trans-unit.source: Open the ~/.iamrc file and replace your account credentials, as in this example:
trans-unit.target: Open the ~/.iamrc file and replace your account credentials, as in this example:

trans-unit.source: Switch euca2ools over to using the new credentials.
trans-unit.target: Switch euca2ools over to using the new credentials.

trans-unit.source: Accounts are the primary unit for resource usage accounting. Each account is a separate name space and is identified by its UUID (Universal Unique Identifier).
trans-unit.target: Accounts are the primary unit for resource usage accounting. Each account is a separate name space and is identified by its UUID (Universal Unique Identifier).

trans-unit.source: Tasks performed at the account level can only be done by the users in the eucalyptus account.
trans-unit.target: Tasks performed at the account level can only be done by the users in the eucalyptus account.

trans-unit.source: If there are resources tied to the account that you delete, the resources remain. We recommend that you delete these resources first.
trans-unit.target: If there are resources tied to the account that you delete, the resources remain. We recommend that you delete these resources first.

trans-unit.source: To delete an account using the CLI:
trans-unit.target: To delete an account using the CLI:

trans-unit.source: Use the -r option set to true to delete the account recursively. You don't have to use this option if have already deleted users, keys, and passwords in this account.
trans-unit.target: Use the -r option set to true to delete the account recursively. You don't have to use this option if have already deleted users, keys, and passwords in this account.

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus does not return any message.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus does not return any message.

trans-unit.source: Click Accounts in the Quick Links section.
trans-unit.target: Click Accounts in the Quick Links section.

trans-unit.source: Click the ID of the account you want to delete.
trans-unit.target: Click the ID of the account you want to delete.

trans-unit.source: The account, name, and Registration status are highlighted.
trans-unit.target: The account, name, and Registration status are highlighted.

trans-unit.source: The Delete selected accounts popup displays.
trans-unit.target: The Delete selected accounts popup displays.

trans-unit.source: Verify that the displayed account is the one you want, and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the displayed account is the one you want, and click OK.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Groups are used to share resource access authorizations among a set of users within an account. Users can belong to multiple groups.
trans-unit.target: Groups are used to share resource access authorizations among a set of users within an account. Users can belong to multiple groups.

trans-unit.source: A group in the context of access is not the same as a security group.
trans-unit.target: A group in the context of access is not the same as a security group.

trans-unit.source: This section details tasks that can be performed on groups.
trans-unit.target: This section details tasks that can be performed on groups.

trans-unit.target: To create a group using the CLI:

trans-unit.target: Click Accounts in the Quick Links section.

trans-unit.target: Click the ID of the account you want to add a group to.

trans-unit.target: The account, name, and Registration status are highlighted.

trans-unit.target: Click New groups in the Accounts page.

trans-unit.target: Enter the group name in the Group name field.

trans-unit.source: You can add more than one group at a time. Every group you add, however, will be in the same path.
trans-unit.target: You can add more than one group at a time. Every group you add, however, will be in the same path.

trans-unit.source: Modifying a group is similar to a "move" operation. Whoever wants to modify the group must have permission to do it on both sides of the move. That is, you need permission to remove the group from its current path or name, and put that group in the new path or name.
trans-unit.target: Modifying a group is similar to a "move" operation. Whoever wants to modify the group must have permission to do it on both sides of the move. That is, you need permission to remove the group from its current path or name, and put that group in the new path or name.

trans-unit.source: For example, if a group changes from one area in a company to another, you can change the group's path from /area_abc/ to /area_efg/. You need permission to remove the group from /area_abc/. You also need permission to put the group into /area_efg/. This means you need permission to call UpdateGroup on both arn:aws:iam::123456789012:group/area_abc/* and arn:aws:iam::123456789012:group/area_efg/*.
trans-unit.target: For example, if a group changes from one area in a company to another, you can change the group's path from /area_abc/ to /area_efg/. You need permission to remove the group from /area_abc/. You also need permission to put the group into /area_efg/. This means you need permission to call UpdateGroup on both arn:aws:iam::123456789012:group/area_abc/* and arn:aws:iam::123456789012:group/area_efg/*.

trans-unit.source: To modify a group using the CLI:
trans-unit.target: To modify a group using the CLI:

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to modify the group's name:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to modify the group's name:

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus does not return a message.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus does not return a message.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to modify a group's path:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to modify a group's path:

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus does not return a message.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus does not return a message.

trans-unit.source: To modify a group using the Dashboard:
trans-unit.target: To modify a group using the Dashboard:

trans-unit.source: Click Groups in the Quick Links section.
trans-unit.target: Click Groups in the Quick Links section.

trans-unit.source: Click the ID of the group you want to rename.
trans-unit.target: Click the ID of the group you want to rename.

trans-unit.source: In the Name field, enter the new name of the group.
trans-unit.target: In the Name field, enter the new name of the group.

trans-unit.source: In the Path field, enter the new path for the group.
trans-unit.target: In the Path field, enter the new path for the group.

trans-unit.source: The new group name displays in the Groups page.
trans-unit.target: The new group name displays in the Groups page.

trans-unit.source: When you delete a group, you have to remove users from the group and delete any policies from the group. You can do this with one command, using the euare-groupdel command with the -r option. Or you can follow the following steps to specify who and what you want to delete.
trans-unit.target: When you delete a group, you have to remove users from the group and delete any policies from the group. You can do this with one command, using the euare-groupdel command with the -r option. Or you can follow the following steps to specify who and what you want to delete.

trans-unit.source: Individually remove all users from the group.
trans-unit.target: Individually remove all users from the group.

trans-unit.source: Delete the policies attached to the group.
trans-unit.target: Delete the policies attached to the group.

trans-unit.target: To delete a group using the Dashboard:

trans-unit.target: Click the ID of the group you want to delete.

trans-unit.target: The ID, Name, Path, and Owner account line is highlighted.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: Users are subsets of accounts and are added to accounts by an appropriately credentialed administrator. While the term user typically refers to a specific person, in Eucalyptus, a user is defined by a specific set of credentials generated to enable access to a given account. Each set of user credentials is valid for accessing only the account for which they were created. Thus a user only has access to one account within a Eucalyptus system. If an individual person wishes to have access to more than one account within a Eucalyptus system, a separate set of credentials must be generated (in effect a new ‘user’) for each account (though the same username and password can be used for different accounts).
trans-unit.target: Users are subsets of accounts and are added to accounts by an appropriately credentialed administrator. While the term user typically refers to a specific person, in Eucalyptus, a user is defined by a specific set of credentials generated to enable access to a given account. Each set of user credentials is valid for accessing only the account for which they were created. Thus a user only has access to one account within a Eucalyptus system. If an individual person wishes to have access to more than one account within a Eucalyptus system, a separate set of credentials must be generated (in effect a new ‘user’) for each account (though the same username and password can be used for different accounts).

trans-unit.source: When you need to add a new user to your Eucalyptus cloud, you'll go through the following process:
trans-unit.target: When you need to add a new user to your Eucalyptus cloud, you'll go through the following process:
