trans-unit.source: To add a user using the CLI:
trans-unit.target: To add a user using the CLI:

trans-unit.source:
Eucalyptus does not return a response.
If you include the -v parameter, Eucalyptus returns a response that includes the user's ARN and GUID.
trans-unit.target:
Eucalyptus does not return a response.
If you include the -v parameter, Eucalyptus returns a response that includes the user's ARN and GUID.

trans-unit.source: To add a user using the Dashboard:
trans-unit.target: To add a user using the Dashboard:

trans-unit.source: Click Accounts in the Quick Links section.
trans-unit.target: Click Accounts in the Quick Links section.

trans-unit.source: Click the ID of the account you want to rename.
trans-unit.target: Click the ID of the account you want to rename.

trans-unit.source: The Create new users popup window displays.
trans-unit.target: The Create new users popup window displays.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name in the User names field.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name in the User names field.

trans-unit.source: You can add more than one user at a time. Every user you add, however, will be in the same path.
trans-unit.target: You can add more than one user at a time. Every user you add, however, will be in the same path.

trans-unit.source: Enter a path in the User path field.
trans-unit.target: Enter a path in the User path field.

trans-unit.source: The user is added to the account.
trans-unit.target: The user is added to the account.

trans-unit.source: Once you create a user, you must generate a password for the user to use the Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: Once you create a user, you must generate a password for the user to use the Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: To create a login profile using the CLI:
trans-unit.target: To create a login profile using the CLI:

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus does not return a response.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus does not return a response.

trans-unit.source: To create a login profile using the Dashboard:
trans-unit.target: To create a login profile using the Dashboard:

trans-unit.source: Click Users in the Quick Links section.
trans-unit.target: Click Users in the Quick Links section.

trans-unit.source: Click the ID of the user whose path you want to change.
trans-unit.target: Click the ID of the user whose path you want to change.

trans-unit.source: The Change password popup window displays.
trans-unit.target: The Change password popup window displays.

trans-unit.source: Enter the new password in the New user password field, and repeat in the New password again field.
trans-unit.target: Enter the new password in the New user password field, and repeat in the New password again field.

trans-unit.source: The login profile is now complete. If you are generating the password for a different user, let the user know the password and the URL to the Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: The login profile is now complete. If you are generating the password for a different user, let the user know the password and the URL to the Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Modifying a user is similar to a "move" operation. Whoever wants to modify a user must have permission to do it on both sides of the move. That is, you need permission to remove the user from the current path or name, and put that user in the new path or name.
trans-unit.target: Modifying a user is similar to a "move" operation. Whoever wants to modify a user must have permission to do it on both sides of the move. That is, you need permission to remove the user from the current path or name, and put that user in the new path or name.

trans-unit.source: For example, if a user changes from one team in a company to another, you can change the user's path from /team_abc/ to /team_efg/. You need permission to remove the user from /team_abc/. You also need permission to put the user into /team_efg/. This means you need permission to call UpdateUser on both arn:aws:iam::123456789012:user/team_abc/* and arn:aws:iam::123456789012:user/team_efg/*.
trans-unit.target: For example, if a user changes from one team in a company to another, you can change the user's path from /team_abc/ to /team_efg/. You need permission to remove the user from /team_abc/. You also need permission to put the user into /team_efg/. This means you need permission to call UpdateUser on both arn:aws:iam::123456789012:user/team_abc/* and arn:aws:iam::123456789012:user/team_efg/*.

trans-unit.source: To rename a user using the CLI:
trans-unit.target: To rename a user using the CLI:

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to rename a user:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to rename a user:

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus does not return a message.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus does not return a message.

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus does not return a message.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus does not return a message.

trans-unit.source: To rename a user using the Dashboard:
trans-unit.target: To rename a user using the Dashboard:

trans-unit.source: Click Users in the Quick Links section.
trans-unit.target: Click Users in the Quick Links section.

trans-unit.source: Click the ID of the user you want to rename.
trans-unit.target: Click the ID of the user you want to rename.

trans-unit.source: In the Name field, enter the new name of the user.
trans-unit.target: In the Name field, enter the new name of the user.

trans-unit.source: The new user name displays in the Users page.
trans-unit.target: The new user name displays in the Users page.

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus uses different types of credentials for different purposes. This section details tasks needed to allow access to Eucalyptus services.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus uses different types of credentials for different purposes. This section details tasks needed to allow access to Eucalyptus services.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: You can generate new credentials a number of ways. The first time you get credentials using either the Dashboard or the euca_conf command, a new secret access key is generated. On each subsequent request to get credentials, an existing active secret Key is returned. You can also generate new keys using the eucare-useraddkey command.
trans-unit.target: You can generate new credentials a number of ways. The first time you get credentials using either the Dashboard or the euca_conf command, a new secret access key is generated. On each subsequent request to get credentials, an existing active secret Key is returned. You can also generate new keys using the eucare-useraddkey command.

trans-unit.source: Each request to get a user's credentials either via the download link in the Dashboard or using euca_conf, a new pair of a private key and X.509 certificate
trans-unit.target: Each request to get a user's credentials either via the download link in the Dashboard or using euca_conf, a new pair of a private key and X.509 certificate

trans-unit.source: To generate a new key for a user by an account administrator, enter the following
trans-unit.target: To generate a new key for a user by an account administrator, enter the following

trans-unit.source: To generate a private key and an X.509 certificate pair, enter the following:
trans-unit.target: To generate a private key and an X.509 certificate pair, enter the following:

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus provides two main ways of getting user credentials. In both cases, Eucalyptus returns a zip file that contains keys, certificates, a bash script, and several other required files. To use these credentials with such CLI tools as euca2ools or ec2-tools, unzip your credentials zip file to a directory of your choice.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus provides two main ways of getting user credentials. In both cases, Eucalyptus returns a zip file that contains keys, certificates, a bash script, and several other required files. To use these credentials with such CLI tools as euca2ools or ec2-tools, unzip your credentials zip file to a directory of your choice.

trans-unit.source: An administrator with a root access to the machine on which CLC is installed can get credentials using euca_conf CLI tool on that machine.
trans-unit.target: An administrator with a root access to the machine on which CLC is installed can get credentials using euca_conf CLI tool on that machine.

trans-unit.source: Where <account> and <user_name> are the names of the account and the user whose credentials are retrieved.
trans-unit.target: Where <account> and <user_name> are the names of the account and the user whose credentials are retrieved.

trans-unit.source: You can omit the --cred-account and --cred-user options when you get credentials for the admin user of the eucalyptus account.
trans-unit.target: You can omit the --cred-account and --cred-user options when you get credentials for the admin user of the eucalyptus account.

trans-unit.source: A user can get his or her credentials by logging in into the Dashboard and clicking Download new credentials in the drop-down menu at the top of the screen. This will result in a download of a zip file.
trans-unit.target: A user can get his or her credentials by logging in into the Dashboard and clicking Download new credentials in the drop-down menu at the top of the screen. This will result in a download of a zip file.

trans-unit.source: In the following example we download the credentials zip file to ~/.euca, then change access permissions, as shown:
trans-unit.target: In the following example we download the credentials zip file to ~/.euca, then change access permissions, as shown:

trans-unit.source: The zip file with credentials contains security-sensitive information. We recommend that you remove or read- and write-protect the file from other users after unzipping.
trans-unit.target: The zip file with credentials contains security-sensitive information. We recommend that you remove or read- and write-protect the file from other users after unzipping.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can view and copy your access keys and X.509 certificates from the Dashboard after logging in, using the Navigation menu.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can view and copy your access keys and X.509 certificates from the Dashboard after logging in, using the Navigation menu.

trans-unit.target: Get administrator credentials and source eucarc:

trans-unit.target: /usr/sbin/euca_conf --get-credentials admin.zip unzip admin.zip chmod 0600 * source eucarc

trans-unit.source: Create an LDAP/AD Integration Configuration (LIC) file to specify all the details about the LDAP/AD synchronization.
trans-unit.target: Create an LDAP/AD Integration Configuration (LIC) file to specify all the details about the LDAP/AD synchronization.

trans-unit.source: Upload the LIC file to Eucalyptus using euca-modify-property.
trans-unit.target: Upload the LIC file to Eucalyptus using euca-modify-property.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: The LIC is a file in JSON format, specifying everything Eucalyptus needs to know about how to synchronize with an LDAP or AD service. Eucalyptus provides a LIC template at ${EUCALYPTUS}/usr/share/eucalyptus/lic_template. This template shows all the fields of the LIC, and provides detailed documentation and example values for each field.
trans-unit.target: The LIC is a file in JSON format, specifying everything Eucalyptus needs to know about how to synchronize with an LDAP or AD service. Eucalyptus provides a LIC template at ${EUCALYPTUS}/usr/share/eucalyptus/lic_template. This template shows all the fields of the LIC, and provides detailed documentation and example values for each field.

trans-unit.source: The above command invokes the LIC tool to create a template LIC and fill in the encrypted password for authenticating to LDAP/AD service (i.e. the password of the administrative user for accessing the LDAP/AD during synchronization). The LIC tool’s primary functions are to encrypt the LDAP/AD password and to generate the starting LIC template. The usage of the LIC tool shows different ways to invoke the command.
trans-unit.target: The above command invokes the LIC tool to create a template LIC and fill in the encrypted password for authenticating to LDAP/AD service (i.e. the password of the administrative user for accessing the LDAP/AD during synchronization). The LIC tool’s primary functions are to encrypt the LDAP/AD password and to generate the starting LIC template. The usage of the LIC tool shows different ways to invoke the command.

trans-unit.source: Once you have the LIC template, you can fill in the details by editing the *.lic file using a text editor. Each top level entity specifies one aspect of the LDAP/AD synchronization.
trans-unit.target: Once you have the LIC template, you can fill in the details by editing the *.lic file using a text editor. Each top level entity specifies one aspect of the LDAP/AD synchronization.

trans-unit.source: A Eucalyptus Machine Image (EMI) is a special type of pre-packaged operating system and application software that Eucalyptus uses to create a virtual machine instance. An EMI contains all necessary information to boot instances of your software. An EMI can contain whatever software you want to meet your needs. For example, you can create an EMI to act as an application server, or a web server, or a custom web service. The following sections contain information to help you create, configure, and modify EMIs.
trans-unit.target: A Eucalyptus Machine Image (EMI) is a special type of pre-packaged operating system and application software that Eucalyptus uses to create a virtual machine instance. An EMI contains all necessary information to boot instances of your software. An EMI can contain whatever software you want to meet your needs. For example, you can create an EMI to act as an application server, or a web server, or a custom web service. The following sections contain information to help you create, configure, and modify EMIs.

trans-unit.source: All users can upload and register images, depending on their access. However, only the admin user can upload and register kernels or ramdisks.
trans-unit.target: All users can upload and register images, depending on their access. However, only the admin user can upload and register kernels or ramdisks.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: An image defines what will run on a guest instance with your Eucalyptus cloud. Typically, an image contains one of the Linux distributions like CentOS, Fedora, Ubuntu, Debian or others. It could also contain one of the supported Windows server versions. The format for these is identical.
trans-unit.target: An image defines what will run on a guest instance with your Eucalyptus cloud. Typically, an image contains one of the Linux distributions like CentOS, Fedora, Ubuntu, Debian or others. It could also contain one of the supported Windows server versions. The format for these is identical.

trans-unit.source: Normally when we use the term "image" we mean the root file system. Once bundled, uploaded, and registered with Eucalyptus, such an image is known as a Eucalyptus machine image (EMI).
trans-unit.target: Normally when we use the term "image" we mean the root file system. Once bundled, uploaded, and registered with Eucalyptus, such an image is known as a Eucalyptus machine image (EMI).

trans-unit.source: There are, however, other types of images that support the EMI. They are the kernel (EKI) and ramdisk (ERI). They contain kernel modules necessary for proper functioning of the image. Often, one set of these ERIs and EKIs are used by multiple EMIs. Once loaded into the Eucalyptus cloud, the EKI and ERI are referred to by the image and you don't have much interaction with them directly.
trans-unit.target: There are, however, other types of images that support the EMI. They are the kernel (EKI) and ramdisk (ERI). They contain kernel modules necessary for proper functioning of the image. Often, one set of these ERIs and EKIs are used by multiple EMIs. Once loaded into the Eucalyptus cloud, the EKI and ERI are referred to by the image and you don't have much interaction with them directly.

trans-unit.source: When you run an image, you can override the image's associated kernel and ramdisk if necessary (for example, if you want to try out another kernel. For more information, see .
trans-unit.target: When you run an image, you can override the image's associated kernel and ramdisk if necessary (for example, if you want to try out another kernel. For more information, see .

trans-unit.source: To help get you started, Eucalyptus provides pre-packaged virtual machines that are ready to run in your cloud. You can get them at the Eucalyptus Machine Images page. Each Eucalyptus image from this site comes bundled with a correspoding EKI and ERI.
trans-unit.target: To help get you started, Eucalyptus provides pre-packaged virtual machines that are ready to run in your cloud. You can get them at the Eucalyptus Machine Images page. Each Eucalyptus image from this site comes bundled with a correspoding EKI and ERI.

trans-unit.source: If you find that the pre-packaged images don't meet your needs, you can add an image from an existing, non-registered image, or create your own image.
trans-unit.target: If you find that the pre-packaged images don't meet your needs, you can add an image from an existing, non-registered image, or create your own image.

trans-unit.source: Once you've selected and downloaded the image(s) you plan to use, read the details in the following section for directions about how to bundle, upload and register the images with your Eucalyptus cloud.
trans-unit.target: Once you've selected and downloaded the image(s) you plan to use, read the details in the following section for directions about how to bundle, upload and register the images with your Eucalyptus cloud.

trans-unit.source: To view the status of your newly created and registered EKI, ERI, and EMI images, use the euca-describe-images command. You can also view image status using the Dashboard's Images page.
trans-unit.target: To view the status of your newly created and registered EKI, ERI, and EMI images, use the euca-describe-images command. You can also view image status using the Dashboard's Images page.

trans-unit.source: Once you have added your image to Eucalyptus, see section for information about launching and using instances based on the image.
trans-unit.target: Once you have added your image to Eucalyptus, see section for information about launching and using instances based on the image.

trans-unit.source: An image is the basis for instances that you spin up for your computing needs. If you have access to images that meet your needs, you can skip this section. This section explains how to add an image to your Eucalyptus cloud that is customized for your needs.
trans-unit.target: An image is the basis for instances that you spin up for your computing needs. If you have access to images that meet your needs, you can skip this section. This section explains how to add an image to your Eucalyptus cloud that is customized for your needs.

trans-unit.source: There are a few ways you can add an image to Eucalyptus:
trans-unit.target: There are a few ways you can add an image to Eucalyptus:

trans-unit.source: Add an image based on an existing image. If you have an image already, read the rest of this section. Eucalyptus has stock images available to help you get started right away. You can find links to these images in the Dashboard's start page. You can also get images from the Eucalyptus Machine Images page.
trans-unit.target: Add an image based on an existing image. If you have an image already, read the rest of this section. Eucalyptus has stock images available to help you get started right away. You can find links to these images in the Dashboard's start page. You can also get images from the Eucalyptus Machine Images page.

trans-unit.source: Add an image that you modify from an existing image. If you have an image that you want to modify, see .
trans-unit.target: Add an image that you modify from an existing image. If you have an image that you want to modify, see .

trans-unit.source: Add an image that you create. If you want to create a new image, see .
trans-unit.target: Add an image that you create. If you want to create a new image, see .

trans-unit.source: Each of these three ways has a different first step, but the way you get image to Eucalyptus is the same. To enable an image as an executable entity, you do the following:
trans-unit.target: Each of these three ways has a different first step, but the way you get image to Eucalyptus is the same. To enable an image as an executable entity, you do the following:

trans-unit.source: Bundle a root disk image and kernel/ramdisk pair
trans-unit.target: Bundle a root disk image and kernel/ramdisk pair

trans-unit.source: Upload the bundled image to Walrus bucket storage
trans-unit.target: Upload the bundled image to Walrus bucket storage

trans-unit.source: Note that while all users can bundle, upload and register images, only the administrator has the required permissions to upload and register kernels and ramdisks.
trans-unit.target: Note that while all users can bundle, upload and register images, only the administrator has the required permissions to upload and register kernels and ramdisks.

trans-unit.source: Once you have an image that meets your needs, perform the tasks listed in this section to add the image to your cloud.
trans-unit.target: Once you have an image that meets your needs, perform the tasks listed in this section to add the image to your cloud.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: When you add a kernel to Walrus, you bundle the kernel file, upload the file to a bucket in Walrus that you name, and then register the kernel with Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: When you add a kernel to Walrus, you bundle the kernel file, upload the file to a bucket in Walrus that you name, and then register the kernel with Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: To add a kernel to Walrus:
trans-unit.target: To add a kernel to Walrus:

trans-unit.source:
euca-bundle-image -i euca-fedora-10-x86_64/xen-kernel/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen --kernel true ... Generating manifest /tmp/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml
euca-upload-bundle -b example_kernel_bucket -m /tmp/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml ... Uploaded image as example_kernel_bucket/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml
euca-register example_kernel_bucket/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml IMAGE eki-XXXXXXXX
trans-unit.target:
euca-bundle-image -i euca-fedora-10-x86_64/xen-kernel/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen --kernel true ... Generating manifest /tmp/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml
euca-upload-bundle -b example_kernel_bucket -m /tmp/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml ... Uploaded image as example_kernel_bucket/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml
euca-register example_kernel_bucket/vmlinuz-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml IMAGE eki-XXXXXXXX

trans-unit.source: Where the returned value eki-XXXXXXXX is the unique ID of the registered kernel image.
trans-unit.target: Where the returned value eki-XXXXXXXX is the unique ID of the registered kernel image.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: When you add a ramdisk to Walrus, you bundle the ramdisk file, upload the file to a bucket in Walrus that you name, and then register the ramdisk with Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: When you add a ramdisk to Walrus, you bundle the ramdisk file, upload the file to a bucket in Walrus that you name, and then register the ramdisk with Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: To add a ramdisk to Walrus:
trans-unit.target: To add a ramdisk to Walrus:

trans-unit.source:
euca-bundle-image -i euca-fedora-10-x86_64/xen-kernel/initrd-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen --ramdisk true ... Generating manifest /tmp/initrd-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml
euca-upload-bundle -b example_rd_bucket -m /tmp/initrd-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml ... Uploaded image as example_rd_bucket/initrd-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xm
euca-register example_rd_bucket/initrd-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml IMAGE eri-XXXXXXXX
trans-unit.target:
euca-bundle-image -i euca-fedora-10-x86_64/xen-kernel/initrd-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen --ramdisk true ... Generating manifest /tmp/initrd-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml
euca-upload-bundle -b example_rd_bucket -m /tmp/initrd-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml ... Uploaded image as example_rd_bucket/initrd-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xm
euca-register example_rd_bucket/initrd-2.6.27.21-0.1-xen.manifest.xml IMAGE eri-XXXXXXXX

trans-unit.source: Where the returned value eri-XXXXXXXX is the unique ID of the registered ramdisk image.
trans-unit.target: Where the returned value eri-XXXXXXXX is the unique ID of the registered ramdisk image.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: When you add a root filesystem to Walrus, you bundle the root filesystem file, upload the file to a bucket in Walrus that you name, and then register the root filesystem with Eucalyptus. The bundle operation can include a registered ramdisk (ERI ID) and a registered kernel (EKI ID). The resulting image would will associate the three images.
trans-unit.target: When you add a root filesystem to Walrus, you bundle the root filesystem file, upload the file to a bucket in Walrus that you name, and then register the root filesystem with Eucalyptus. The bundle operation can include a registered ramdisk (ERI ID) and a registered kernel (EKI ID). The resulting image would will associate the three images.

trans-unit.source: You can also bundle the root file system independently and associate the ramdisk and kernel with the resulting EMI at run time. For more information, see .
trans-unit.target: You can also bundle the root file system independently and associate the ramdisk and kernel with the resulting EMI at run time. For more information, see .

trans-unit.source: To add a root filesystem to Walrus:
trans-unit.target: To add a root filesystem to Walrus:

trans-unit.source:
euca-bundle-image -i euca-fedora-10-x86_64/fedora.10.x86-64.img --ramdisk eri-722B3CBA --kernel eki-5B3D3859 ... Generating manifest /tmp/fedora.10.x86-64.img.manifest.xml
euca-upload-bundle -b example_rf_bucket -m /tmp/fedora.10.x86-64.img.manifest.xml ... Generating manifest /tmp/fedora.10.x86-64.img.manifest.xml
euca-register example_rf_bucket/fedora.10.x86-64.img.manifest.xml IMAGE emi-XXXXXXXX
trans-unit.target:
euca-bundle-image -i euca-fedora-10-x86_64/fedora.10.x86-64.img --ramdisk eri-722B3CBA --kernel eki-5B3D3859 ... Generating manifest /tmp/fedora.10.x86-64.img.manifest.xml
euca-upload-bundle -b example_rf_bucket -m /tmp/fedora.10.x86-64.img.manifest.xml ... Generating manifest /tmp/fedora.10.x86-64.img.manifest.xml
euca-register example_rf_bucket/fedora.10.x86-64.img.manifest.xml IMAGE emi-XXXXXXXX

trans-unit.source: Where the returned value emi-XXXXXXXX is the unique ID of the registered machine image.
trans-unit.target: Where the returned value emi-XXXXXXXX is the unique ID of the registered machine image.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: You might find that existing images in your cloud don't meet your needs.
trans-unit.target: You might find that existing images in your cloud don't meet your needs.

trans-unit.source: Create a mount point for your image.
trans-unit.target: Create a mount point for your image.

trans-unit.source: Associate a loop block device to the image.
trans-unit.target: Associate a loop block device to the image.

trans-unit.source: where loop5 is a free device
trans-unit.target: where loop5 is a free device

trans-unit.source: Make procfs, dev and sysfs available in your chroot environment.
trans-unit.target: Make procfs, dev and sysfs available in your chroot environment.

trans-unit.source: mkdir -p temp-mnt/proc mkdir -p temp-mnt/sys mkdir -p temp-mnt/dev mount -o bind /proc temp-mnt/proc mount -o bind /sys temp-mnt/sys mount -o bind /dev temp-mnt/dev
trans-unit.target: mkdir -p temp-mnt/proc mkdir -p temp-mnt/sys mkdir -p temp-mnt/dev mount -o bind /proc temp-mnt/proc mount -o bind /sys temp-mnt/sys mount -o bind /dev temp-mnt/dev

trans-unit.source: You now have the image under temp-mnt and you can copy over what you want into it. If you want to install packages into it, you have few options:
trans-unit.target: You now have the image under temp-mnt and you can copy over what you want into it. If you want to install packages into it, you have few options:

trans-unit.source: chroot temp-mnt and use apt-get, yum, or zypper to install what you want.
trans-unit.target: chroot temp-mnt and use apt-get, yum, or zypper to install what you want.

trans-unit.source: Instruct the package manager program to use a different root (for example both dpkg and rpm uses the --root option)
trans-unit.target: Instruct the package manager program to use a different root (for example both dpkg and rpm uses the --root option)

trans-unit.source: You now have an image with your modifications. You are ready to add the image to Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: You now have an image with your modifications. You are ready to add the image to Eucalyptus.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: You can create your own image if you to deploy an instance that is customized for your specific use. For example, you can create an EMI to deploy a LAMP server, MySQL database server, or a Postgres database server. All you need is some familiarity with the creation process.
trans-unit.target: You can create your own image if you to deploy an instance that is customized for your specific use. For example, you can create an EMI to deploy a LAMP server, MySQL database server, or a Postgres database server. All you need is some familiarity with the creation process.

trans-unit.source: A Linux image is a root partition of a Linux installation. We use the convention followed by EC2 images:
trans-unit.target: A Linux image is a root partition of a Linux installation. We use the convention followed by EC2 images:

trans-unit.source: The first partition is the root partition (where the EMI is attached)
trans-unit.target: The first partition is the root partition (where the EMI is attached)

trans-unit.source: The second is the ephemeral partition (for additional storage)
trans-unit.target: The second is the ephemeral partition (for additional storage)

trans-unit.source: The third is the swap partition
trans-unit.target: The third is the swap partition

trans-unit.source: Any image you create must conform to these conditions (for example, /etc/fstab must follow this convention). Typically, the disk provided by Eucalyptus (as well as EC2) is the first SCSI disk (sda). However, you can customize it to be, for example, the first IDE disk (hda) or the first virtual disk on a paravirtual machine (xvda).
trans-unit.target: Any image you create must conform to these conditions (for example, /etc/fstab must follow this convention). Typically, the disk provided by Eucalyptus (as well as EC2) is the first SCSI disk (sda). However, you can customize it to be, for example, the first IDE disk (hda) or the first virtual disk on a paravirtual machine (xvda).

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus supports a licensed version of Windows images. Before you bundle a Windows image, you must have a valid version of Windows OS installed on your hypervisor and the Eucalyptus Windows Integration Service installed in the created Windows VM. The following sections detail how to perform these tasks.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus supports a licensed version of Windows images. Before you bundle a Windows image, you must have a valid version of Windows OS installed on your hypervisor and the Eucalyptus Windows Integration Service installed in the created Windows VM. The following sections detail how to perform these tasks.

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus is compatible with images created from licensed versions of Windows Server 2003 R2, Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows 7. Windows OS is sensitive to physical and virtual hardware changes made after installation. We recommend that you create any Windows image on the specific hypervisor (Xen, KVM, or VMware) where you plan to run instances of that Windows image. Eucalyptus does not support running a Windows image across different hypervisors.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus is compatible with images created from licensed versions of Windows Server 2003 R2, Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows 7. Windows OS is sensitive to physical and virtual hardware changes made after installation. We recommend that you create any Windows image on the specific hypervisor (Xen, KVM, or VMware) where you plan to run instances of that Windows image. Eucalyptus does not support running a Windows image across different hypervisors.

trans-unit.source: Before you begin, you will need the following room for a blank disk file:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin, you will need the following room for a blank disk file:

trans-unit.source: 8GB minimum, for Windows Server 2003 R2 (32-bit and 64-bit)
trans-unit.target: 8GB minimum, for Windows Server 2003 R2 (32-bit and 64-bit)

trans-unit.source: 15GB minimum for Windows Server 2008 (32-bit and 64-bit), Windows Server 2008 R2 (64-bit), and Windows 7 (32-bit and 64-bit)
trans-unit.target: 15GB minimum for Windows Server 2008 (32-bit and 64-bit), Windows Server 2008 R2 (64-bit), and Windows 7 (32-bit and 64-bit)

trans-unit.source: Eucalyptus implements ephemeral disks by which a running Windows instances are allocated an additional disk space based on the instance type. For example, if you assign an instance type 15 GB of disk and the registered Windows EMI is 8 GB, 7 GB of disk spaces are ephemeral disks accessible under D:\. If your Windows application uses scratch space most of time, we recommend keeping the Windows EMI small because it takes longer to launch bigger EMIs.
trans-unit.target: Eucalyptus implements ephemeral disks by which a running Windows instances are allocated an additional disk space based on the instance type. For example, if you assign an instance type 15 GB of disk and the registered Windows EMI is 8 GB, 7 GB of disk spaces are ephemeral disks accessible under D:\. If your Windows application uses scratch space most of time, we recommend keeping the Windows EMI small because it takes longer to launch bigger EMIs.

trans-unit.source: The windows image is a root file system that has no kernel and ramdisk associated with it. After creating your own Windows images, you can bundle, upload, and register it with Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: The windows image is a root file system that has no kernel and ramdisk associated with it. After creating your own Windows images, you can bundle, upload, and register it with Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: The follow sections detail how to create an image based on the hypervisor you use. To create an image, choose which hypervisor you will use, which OS you want the image to be, and then follow the directions for that choice.
trans-unit.target: The follow sections detail how to create an image based on the hypervisor you use. To create an image, choose which hypervisor you will use, which OS you want the image to be, and then follow the directions for that choice.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: Before you begin, make sure that Xen installed and properly functioning for the account you are going to use.
trans-unit.target: Before you begin, make sure that Xen installed and properly functioning for the account you are going to use.

trans-unit.source: To create a root filesystem to be used with Eucalyptus using Xen and an ISO image of the guest OS you want to install:
trans-unit.target: To create a root filesystem to be used with Eucalyptus using Xen and an ISO image of the guest OS you want to install:

trans-unit.source: Download the ISO image of the distro (guest OS) you want to install.
trans-unit.target: Download the ISO image of the distro (guest OS) you want to install.

trans-unit.source: Create a virtual disk with the desired size. For example, to create a 4 GiB disk:
trans-unit.target: Create a virtual disk with the desired size. For example, to create a 4 GiB disk:

trans-unit.source: Create a Xen configuration file (for example, xen.cfg) to boot off the ISO image. The file should look like the following:
trans-unit.target: Create a Xen configuration file (for example, xen.cfg) to boot off the ISO image. The file should look like the following:

trans-unit.source: name = "bootFromISO" kernel = "/usr/lib/xen/boot/hvmloader" memory = 1024 builder = "hvm" device_model = "/usr/lib64/xen/bin/qemu-dm" boot = "d" disk = ['file:PATH_TO_ISO,hdc:cdrom,r', 'file:PATH_TO/<image_name>,sda,w'] vif = ['mac=00:01:01:00:00:03, bridge=xenbr0'] dhcp="on" vnc = 1 vncdisplay = 7 pae = 1
trans-unit.target: name = "bootFromISO" kernel = "/usr/lib/xen/boot/hvmloader" memory = 1024 builder = "hvm" device_model = "/usr/lib64/xen/bin/qemu-dm" boot = "d" disk = ['file:PATH_TO_ISO,hdc:cdrom,r', 'file:PATH_TO/<image_name>,sda,w'] vif = ['mac=00:01:01:00:00:03, bridge=xenbr0'] dhcp="on" vnc = 1 vncdisplay = 7 pae = 1

trans-unit.source: You must modify device_model and kernel since they depend on where the distribution puts such files. Look into the Xen package file list. Also be sure that all the options are correct for your needs.
trans-unit.target: You must modify device_model and kernel since they depend on where the distribution puts such files. Look into the Xen package file list. Also be sure that all the options are correct for your needs.

trans-unit.source: Connect with a VNC viewer. For example:
trans-unit.target: Connect with a VNC viewer. For example:

trans-unit.source: Install the distro as you would normally would. Do not use lvm or md and install everything in one partition. Remember the partition in which the distro is installed.
trans-unit.target: Install the distro as you would normally would. Do not use lvm or md and install everything in one partition. Remember the partition in which the distro is installed.

trans-unit.source: Most distributions will remember the network interfaces by the MAC address, so interfaces will always be the same (that is, eth0 and eth1 will not be inverted accidentally). In Eucalyptus you have to get the distribution to forget the NIC, so that every instance will see the interface as the first interface. To do so you may want to refer to the specific distribution. For example Debian and Ubuntu use udev so check /etc/udev/rules.d/*net*. CentOS might have something in /etc/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0. Failure to do so may leave your instance without network.
trans-unit.target: Most distributions will remember the network interfaces by the MAC address, so interfaces will always be the same (that is, eth0 and eth1 will not be inverted accidentally). In Eucalyptus you have to get the distribution to forget the NIC, so that every instance will see the interface as the first interface. To do so you may want to refer to the specific distribution. For example Debian and Ubuntu use udev so check /etc/udev/rules.d/*net*. CentOS might have something in /etc/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0. Failure to do so may leave your instance without network.

trans-unit.source: Find out the starting block and the block size of the root file system.
trans-unit.target: Find out the starting block and the block size of the root file system.

trans-unit.source: Print the current partition table using p.
trans-unit.target: Print the current partition table using p.

trans-unit.source: Note the start for the partition you are interested in and the size. For this example we'll say that the start is 32256 and the size is 1024000.
trans-unit.target: Note the start for the partition you are interested in and the size. For this example we'll say that the start is 32256 and the size is 1024000.

trans-unit.source: dd if=<image_name> of=rootfs.img bs=1 skip=32256 count=1024000
trans-unit.target: dd if=<image_name> of=rootfs.img bs=1 skip=32256 count=1024000

trans-unit.source: You now have a root filesystem. Make sure that it is compatible with the kernel/initrd you are using in your cloud environment. In particular you may want to be sure you have the modules of the kernel you are going to use. Then you are ready to add the image to Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: You now have a root filesystem. Make sure that it is compatible with the kernel/initrd you are using in your cloud environment. In particular you may want to be sure you have the modules of the kernel you are going to use. Then you are ready to add the image to Eucalyptus.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you perform this task on an NC (or the host running the same Linux distributions and hypervisors as the NC). If you are creating the Windows image on a machine currently running the NC, terminate all running instances and stop the NC. To stop the NC, enter:
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you perform this task on an NC (or the host running the same Linux distributions and hypervisors as the NC). If you are creating the Windows image on a machine currently running the NC, terminate all running instances and stop the NC. To stop the NC, enter:

trans-unit.source: Included with the installation are template files that closely match those that Eucalyptus will generate at VM instantiation time. The file for KVM (libvirt-xen-windows-example.xml) is located at /usr/share/eucalyptus/doc/. We recommend that you review this file to acquaint yourself with its contents, noting required files, bridges, and resources. For more information about configuring the libvirt.xml file, go to the Domain XML format page in the libvirt documentation.
trans-unit.target: Included with the installation are template files that closely match those that Eucalyptus will generate at VM instantiation time. The file for KVM (libvirt-xen-windows-example.xml) is located at /usr/share/eucalyptus/doc/. We recommend that you review this file to acquaint yourself with its contents, noting required files, bridges, and resources. For more information about configuring the libvirt.xml file, go to the Domain XML format page in the libvirt documentation.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: The first task for creating a Windows image is installing a base Windows operating system (OS). To install a base Windows OS:
trans-unit.target: The first task for creating a Windows image is installing a base Windows operating system (OS). To install a base Windows OS:

trans-unit.source: Log in to the stopped NC server or a host that runs the same hypervisor as the NCs.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the stopped NC server or a host that runs the same hypervisor as the NCs.

trans-unit.source: Create a blank disk file. Specify your Windows VM image name using the parameter of.
trans-unit.target: Create a blank disk file. Specify your Windows VM image name using the parameter of.

trans-unit.source: dd if=/dev/zero of=windows.<image_name>.img bs=1M count=1 seek=16999
trans-unit.target: dd if=/dev/zero of=windows.<image_name>.img bs=1M count=1 seek=16999

trans-unit.source: Your image name must start with the word, windows (all lower-case).
trans-unit.target: Your image name must start with the word, windows (all lower-case).

trans-unit.source: Create a floppy and secondary blank disk to be attached to the image later, in order to test paravirtualization drivers
trans-unit.target: Create a floppy and secondary blank disk to be attached to the image later, in order to test paravirtualization drivers

trans-unit.source: dd if=/dev/zero of=floppy.img \ bs=1k count=1474 dd if=/dev/zero of=secondary.img \ bs=1M count=1 seek=1000
trans-unit.target: dd if=/dev/zero of=floppy.img \ bs=1k count=1474 dd if=/dev/zero of=secondary.img \ bs=1M count=1 seek=1000

trans-unit.source: Make available the .iso file that contains your Windows installation CD/DVD, then copy the .iso file to your working directory.
trans-unit.target: Make available the .iso file that contains your Windows installation CD/DVD, then copy the .iso file to your working directory.

trans-unit.source: Copy the libvirt-xen-windows-example.xml file to your working directory and rename it to libvirt-xen-windows.xml.
trans-unit.target: Copy the libvirt-xen-windows-example.xml file to your working directory and rename it to libvirt-xen-windows.xml.

trans-unit.source: Open the new libvirt-xen-windows.xml file and provide fully qualified paths to the VM image file and iso. Make sure that the name of the bridge is the same as the one used by the hypervisor on which you are creating the Windows image.
trans-unit.target: Open the new libvirt-xen-windows.xml file and provide fully qualified paths to the VM image file and iso. Make sure that the name of the bridge is the same as the one used by the hypervisor on which you are creating the Windows image.

trans-unit.source: Your file should look similar to this example:
trans-unit.target: Your file should look similar to this example:

trans-unit.source: <domain type='xen'> <name>eucalyptus-windows</name> <os> <type>hvm</type> <loader>/usr/lib/xen/boot/hvmloader</loader> <boot dev='cdrom'/> </os> <features> <acpi/> <apic/> <pae/> </features> <clock offset='localtime'/> <on_poweroff>destroy</on_poweroff> <on_reboot>restart</on_reboot> <on_crash>destroy</on_crash> <memory>524288</memory> <vcpu>1</vcpu> <devices> <emulator>/usr/lib64/xen/bin/qemu-dm</emulator> <disk type='file'> <source file='/root/windows_2003.img'/> <target dev='hda' bus='ide'/> </disk> <!--<disk type='file' device='disk'> <driver name='tap' type='aio'/> <source file='fully_qualified_path_to_secondary_disk'/> <target dev='xvda' bus='xen'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='floppy'> <source file='fully_qualified_path_to_floppy_disk'/> <target dev='fda'/> </disk> --> <disk type='file' device='cdrom'> <source file='/root/en_win_srv_2003_r2_enterprise_with_sp2_cd1_x13-05460.iso'/> <target dev='hdc'/> <readonly/> </disk> <interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='xenbr0'/> <script path='/etc/xen/scripts/vif-bridge'/> </interface> <serial type='pty'> <source path='/dev/pts/3'/> <target port='0'/> </serial> <input type='tablet' bus='usb'/> <input type='mouse' bus='ps2'/> <graphics type='vnc' port='-1' autoport='yes' keymap='en-us' listen='0.0.0.0'/> </devices> </domain>
trans-unit.target: <domain type='xen'> <name>eucalyptus-windows</name> <os> <type>hvm</type> <loader>/usr/lib/xen/boot/hvmloader</loader> <boot dev='cdrom'/> </os> <features> <acpi/> <apic/> <pae/> </features> <clock offset='localtime'/> <on_poweroff>destroy</on_poweroff> <on_reboot>restart</on_reboot> <on_crash>destroy</on_crash> <memory>524288</memory> <vcpu>1</vcpu> <devices> <emulator>/usr/lib64/xen/bin/qemu-dm</emulator> <disk type='file'> <source file='/root/windows_2003.img'/> <target dev='hda' bus='ide'/> </disk> <!--<disk type='file' device='disk'> <driver name='tap' type='aio'/> <source file='fully_qualified_path_to_secondary_disk'/> <target dev='xvda' bus='xen'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='floppy'> <source file='fully_qualified_path_to_floppy_disk'/> <target dev='fda'/> </disk> --> <disk type='file' device='cdrom'> <source file='/root/en_win_srv_2003_r2_enterprise_with_sp2_cd1_x13-05460.iso'/> <target dev='hdc'/> <readonly/> </disk> <interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='xenbr0'/> <script path='/etc/xen/scripts/vif-bridge'/> </interface> <serial type='pty'> <source path='/dev/pts/3'/> <target port='0'/> </serial> <input type='tablet' bus='usb'/> <input type='mouse' bus='ps2'/> <graphics type='vnc' port='-1' autoport='yes' keymap='en-us' listen='0.0.0.0'/> </devices> </domain>

trans-unit.source: Connect to the virtual console using the VNC client of your choice. On the NC, check the display number that has been allocated by looking at the process table (ps axw | grep vnc). For example, if the display number is 0, then connect to the NC using the VNC client:
trans-unit.target: Connect to the virtual console using the VNC client of your choice. On the NC, check the display number that has been allocated by looking at the process table (ps axw | grep vnc). For example, if the display number is 0, then connect to the NC using the VNC client:

trans-unit.source: You can also connect to your Windows image using the Virtual Manager and Virtual Viewer utilities with Centos/Xen systems.
trans-unit.target: You can also connect to your Windows image using the Virtual Manager and Virtual Viewer utilities with Centos/Xen systems.

trans-unit.source: Follow the standard Windows installation procedure until the VM has completed installing Windows.
trans-unit.target: Follow the standard Windows installation procedure until the VM has completed installing Windows.

trans-unit.source: On some hosts, the VNC’s display number will change when a VM restarts. Use ps to find the current number.
trans-unit.target: On some hosts, the VNC’s display number will change when a VM restarts. Use ps to find the current number.

trans-unit.source: Run virsh list to display the domain name.
trans-unit.target: Run virsh list to display the domain name.

trans-unit.source: Shut down the Windows VM you have just created. The easiest way to shutdown your VM is use the virsh destroy command, as shown:
trans-unit.target: Shut down the Windows VM you have just created. The easiest way to shutdown your VM is use the virsh destroy command, as shown:

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

xmrk:image.alt: Eucalyptus Windows Integrator select hypervisor window

trans-unit.source: Use yum or apt-get to download the Eucalyptus tool.
trans-unit.target: Use yum or apt-get to download the Eucalyptus tool.

trans-unit.source: yum install eucalyptus-windows-tools apt-get install eucalyptus-windows-tools
trans-unit.target: yum install eucalyptus-windows-tools apt-get install eucalyptus-windows-tools

trans-unit.source: Copy /usr/share/eucalyptus/eucawin.iso to the working directory of your NC.
trans-unit.target: Copy /usr/share/eucalyptus/eucawin.iso to the working directory of your NC.

trans-unit.source: Open the libvirt-xen-windows-example.xml file and make the following edits:
trans-unit.target: Open the libvirt-xen-windows-example.xml file and make the following edits:

trans-unit.source: Comment out the lines of XML code directing Xen to boot the Windows image from the CDROM.
trans-unit.target: Comment out the lines of XML code directing Xen to boot the Windows image from the CDROM.

trans-unit.source: Change the text so that eucawin.iso replaces the Windows .iso image and is mounted as cdrom.
trans-unit.target: Change the text so that eucawin.iso replaces the Windows .iso image and is mounted as cdrom.

trans-unit.source: Enter the path to the secondary disk file you created in the previous task.
trans-unit.target: Enter the path to the secondary disk file you created in the previous task.

trans-unit.source: Uncomment the lines that direct attachment of a floppy disk and secondary disk.
trans-unit.target: Uncomment the lines that direct attachment of a floppy disk and secondary disk.

trans-unit.source: Your finished file should look similar to the following example:
trans-unit.target: Your finished file should look similar to the following example:

trans-unit.source: <domain type='xen'> <name>eucalyptus-windows</name> <os> <type>hvm</type> <loader>/usr/lib/xen/boot/hvmloader</loader> <!-- <boot dev='cdrom'/> --> </os> <features> <acpi/> <apic/> <pae/> </features> <clock offset='localtime'/> <on_poweroff>destroy</on_poweroff> <on_reboot>restart</on_reboot> <on_crash>destroy</on_crash> <memory>524288</memory> <vcpu>1</vcpu> <devices> <emulator>/usr/lib64/xen/bin/qemu-dm</emulator> <disk type='file'> <source file='/root/windows_2003.img'/> <target dev='hda' bus='ide'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='disk'> <driver name='tap' type='aio'/> <source file='/root/secondary.img'/> <target dev='xvda' bus='xen'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='floppy'> <source file='/root/floppy.img'/> <target dev='fda'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='cdrom'> <source file='eucawin.iso'/> <target dev='hdc'/> <readonly/> </disk> <interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='xenbr0'/> <script path='/etc/xen/scripts/vif-bridge'/> </interface> <serial type='pty'> <source path='/dev/pts/3'/> <target port='0'/> </serial> <input type='tablet' bus='usb'/> <input type='mouse' bus='ps2'/> <graphics type='vnc' port='-1' autoport='yes' keymap='en-us' listen='0.0.0.0'/> </devices> </domain>
trans-unit.target: <domain type='xen'> <name>eucalyptus-windows</name> <os> <type>hvm</type> <loader>/usr/lib/xen/boot/hvmloader</loader> <!-- <boot dev='cdrom'/> --> </os> <features> <acpi/> <apic/> <pae/> </features> <clock offset='localtime'/> <on_poweroff>destroy</on_poweroff> <on_reboot>restart</on_reboot> <on_crash>destroy</on_crash> <memory>524288</memory> <vcpu>1</vcpu> <devices> <emulator>/usr/lib64/xen/bin/qemu-dm</emulator> <disk type='file'> <source file='/root/windows_2003.img'/> <target dev='hda' bus='ide'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='disk'> <driver name='tap' type='aio'/> <source file='/root/secondary.img'/> <target dev='xvda' bus='xen'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='floppy'> <source file='/root/floppy.img'/> <target dev='fda'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='cdrom'> <source file='eucawin.iso'/> <target dev='hdc'/> <readonly/> </disk> <interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='xenbr0'/> <script path='/etc/xen/scripts/vif-bridge'/> </interface> <serial type='pty'> <source path='/dev/pts/3'/> <target port='0'/> </serial> <input type='tablet' bus='usb'/> <input type='mouse' bus='ps2'/> <graphics type='vnc' port='-1' autoport='yes' keymap='en-us' listen='0.0.0.0'/> </devices> </domain>

trans-unit.source: There is an issue with Xen paravirtualization drivers on some Windows versions. 64-bit Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008R2, and Windows 7 have driver signing requirements that prevent unsigned drivers from being installed. The supplied drivers in the package are not signed. To resolve this issue:
trans-unit.target: There is an issue with Xen paravirtualization drivers on some Windows versions. 64-bit Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008R2, and Windows 7 have driver signing requirements that prevent unsigned drivers from being installed. The supplied drivers in the package are not signed. To resolve this issue:

trans-unit.source: Log in to the Windows VM.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the Windows VM.

trans-unit.source: Launch cmd.exe as administrator, and execute the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Launch cmd.exe as administrator, and execute the following commands:

trans-unit.source: bcdedit.exe -set loadoptions DISABLE_INTEGRITY_CHECKS bcdedit.exe -set TESTSIGNING ON
trans-unit.target: bcdedit.exe -set loadoptions DISABLE_INTEGRITY_CHECKS bcdedit.exe -set TESTSIGNING ON

trans-unit.source: Log in to Windows and find the Eucalyptus installation files in the CDROM drive.
trans-unit.target: Log in to Windows and find the Eucalyptus installation files in the CDROM drive.

trans-unit.source: For Windows Server 2003 R2, run setup.exe.
trans-unit.target: For Windows Server 2003 R2, run setup.exe.

trans-unit.source: For all others, run EucalyptusWindowsIntegration.msi. (setup.exe will automatically install .NET framework 2.0, which is not bundled in Server 2003 R2).
trans-unit.target: For all others, run EucalyptusWindowsIntegration.msi. (setup.exe will automatically install .NET framework 2.0, which is not bundled in Server 2003 R2).

trans-unit.source: In the Choose your hypervisor step, click XEN and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: In the Choose your hypervisor step, click XEN and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: Should this be a separate section, like Active Directory and Remote Desktop? Scot: maybe combine all into one process file of separate tasks.
trans-unit.target: Should this be a separate section, like Active Directory and Remote Desktop? Scot: maybe combine all into one process file of separate tasks.

trans-unit.source: During the installation of drivers, warning messages might appear asking to confirm the driver installation. Click Continue in all cases.
trans-unit.target: During the installation of drivers, warning messages might appear asking to confirm the driver installation. Click Continue in all cases.

trans-unit.source: At the end of Eucalyptus installation, the Xen driver setup will automatically start. When prompted to choose setup type, choose Complete. During the installation of drivers, warning messages might appear asking to confirm the driver installation. Click Continue in all cases.
trans-unit.target: At the end of Eucalyptus installation, the Xen driver setup will automatically start. When prompted to choose setup type, choose Complete. During the installation of drivers, warning messages might appear asking to confirm the driver installation. Click Continue in all cases.

trans-unit.source: Open the Windows device manager and check that the following drivers are found for each device:
trans-unit.target: Open the Windows device manager and check that the following drivers are found for each device:

trans-unit.source: Disk drives: XEN PV SCSI Disk Device
trans-unit.target: Disk drives: XEN PV SCSI Disk Device

trans-unit.source: SCSI and RAID controllers: Xen Block Device Driver
trans-unit.target: SCSI and RAID controllers: Xen Block Device Driver

trans-unit.source: Network adapters: Xen Net Device Driver
trans-unit.target: Network adapters: Xen Net Device Driver

trans-unit.source:
If the correct drivers are not found, question marks display on the devices.
Right-click on the devices in question and run update drivers. The new hardware wizard displays.
When the new hardware wizard asks if Windows update is to be connected, click No, not this time. Choose Install software automatically (recommended). If a confirmation popup message displays, click Continue.
trans-unit.target:
If the correct drivers are not found, question marks display on the devices.
Right-click on the devices in question and run update drivers. The new hardware wizard displays.
When the new hardware wizard asks if Windows update is to be connected, click No, not this time. Choose Install software automatically (recommended). If a confirmation popup message displays, click Continue.
