trans-unit.source: The Eucalyptus Integration service lets an enterprise with existing Active Directory domains attach Windows instances to the domains and control access to these instances using the existing AD user database. Users can log into the instance either using their domain credentials or the Administrator’s password generated with the euca-get-password command.
trans-unit.target: The Eucalyptus Integration service lets an enterprise with existing Active Directory domains attach Windows instances to the domains and control access to these instances using the existing AD user database. Users can log into the instance either using their domain credentials or the Administrator’s password generated with the euca-get-password command.

trans-unit.source: Because AD technology is tightly integrated with domain name service (DNS), the default name server contacted by the instance must be able to resolve the AD address as a proper domain controller. You can do this for all networking modes except System, by configuring the following line in the CC’s eucalyptus.conf file:
trans-unit.target: Because AD technology is tightly integrated with domain name service (DNS), the default name server contacted by the instance must be able to resolve the AD address as a proper domain controller. You can do this for all networking modes except System, by configuring the following line in the CC’s eucalyptus.conf file:

trans-unit.source: If there is no such pre-existing DNS set-up or your networking mode is System, you might need to change the VM’s network interface so that the preferred DNS server points to the domain controller.
trans-unit.target: If there is no such pre-existing DNS set-up or your networking mode is System, you might need to change the VM’s network interface so that the preferred DNS server points to the domain controller.

trans-unit.source: The Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup displays.
trans-unit.target: The Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup displays.

trans-unit.source: Click the Active Directory tab in the Eucalyptus Windows Integration window and enter the following information:
trans-unit.target: Click the Active Directory tab in the Eucalyptus Windows Integration window and enter the following information:

trans-unit.source: Enter the address of the existing Active Directory domain controller in the AD Address field.
trans-unit.target: Enter the address of the existing Active Directory domain controller in the AD Address field.

trans-unit.source: Enter the administrator username in the Admin Username field. We recommend using a generic user account that has permission to join a computer to a domain or a specific organizational unit.
trans-unit.target: Enter the administrator username in the Admin Username field. We recommend using a generic user account that has permission to join a computer to a domain or a specific organizational unit.

trans-unit.source: Enter and confirm the password in the Admin Password field. Note that the Admin username and password are required to join an instance to an Active Directory. When launched in Eucalyptus, these properties will be deleted as soon as the instance joins (or fails to join) the domain.
trans-unit.target: Enter and confirm the password in the Admin Password field. Note that the Admin username and password are required to join an instance to an Active Directory. When launched in Eucalyptus, these properties will be deleted as soon as the instance joins (or fails to join) the domain.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, enter an organizational unit in the Organizational Unit field. This specifies a container that the instances launched from this image will be attach to.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, enter an organizational unit in the Organizational Unit field. This specifies a container that the instances launched from this image will be attach to.

trans-unit.source: If the values entered in this section are incorrect, the launched instances will fail to join the domain. We recommend that you verify the information by manually joining a computer to a domain using the same information that you entered in this step. You may first log in the launched instance using administrator password (euca-get-password) and manually join the domain for verification.
trans-unit.target: If the values entered in this section are incorrect, the launched instances will fail to join the domain. We recommend that you verify the information by manually joining a computer to a domain using the same information that you entered in this step. You may first log in the launched instance using administrator password (euca-get-password) and manually join the domain for verification.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: Domain users or groups require remote desktop permission to log into an instance. By default, only the local administrator has the remote desktop permission. The Eucalyptus Integration Service provides a way to grant remote desktop permission to additional domain users or groups.
trans-unit.target: Domain users or groups require remote desktop permission to log into an instance. By default, only the local administrator has the remote desktop permission. The Eucalyptus Integration Service provides a way to grant remote desktop permission to additional domain users or groups.

trans-unit.source: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus EucaSetup.exe ).
trans-unit.target: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus EucaSetup.exe ).

trans-unit.source: The names of authorized domain users and groups display in the Authorized User/Groups field. By default, only the local administrator is listed as authorized.
trans-unit.target: The names of authorized domain users and groups display in the Authorized User/Groups field. By default, only the local administrator is listed as authorized.

trans-unit.source: In the text field below the list, enter a user and group account name in the format [DOMAIN]\[USER or GROUP]. If you add a new local user or local group, prepend the account name localhost\ instead of the domain name.
trans-unit.target: In the text field below the list, enter a user and group account name in the format [DOMAIN]\[USER or GROUP]. If you add a new local user or local group, prepend the account name localhost\ instead of the domain name.

trans-unit.source: Repeat for all user/groups that you want to add.
trans-unit.target: Repeat for all user/groups that you want to add.

trans-unit.source: When the instance launches, the members of the groups you added can log in to the instance through remote desktop.
trans-unit.target: When the instance launches, the members of the groups you added can log in to the instance through remote desktop.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: Sysprep is a Microsoft tool for deploying multiple Windows operating systems in an enterprise. Running Sysprep removes system-specific information such as security ID (SID) from the Windows OS before you clone an image. Sysprep then re-initializes the OS after the image is cloned and started on multiple computers. Use Sysprep to prepare images when you use Microsoft Key Management Service to activate license keys. Also, use Sysprep when your Windows systems are attached to Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Sysprep is a Microsoft tool for deploying multiple Windows operating systems in an enterprise. Running Sysprep removes system-specific information such as security ID (SID) from the Windows OS before you clone an image. Sysprep then re-initializes the OS after the image is cloned and started on multiple computers. Use Sysprep to prepare images when you use Microsoft Key Management Service to activate license keys. Also, use Sysprep when your Windows systems are attached to Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: In Eucalyptus, you can run Sysprep before you bundle images with the euca-bundle-image or euca-bundle-instance commands.
trans-unit.target: In Eucalyptus, you can run Sysprep before you bundle images with the euca-bundle-image or euca-bundle-instance commands.

trans-unit.source: The Eucalyptus Integration Service supports Sysprep for Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows 7.
trans-unit.target: The Eucalyptus Integration Service supports Sysprep for Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows 7.

trans-unit.source: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus EucaSetup.exe ).
trans-unit.target: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus EucaSetup.exe ).

trans-unit.source: Ensure that Format uninitialized drives is checked
trans-unit.target: Ensure that Format uninitialized drives is checked

trans-unit.source: If you want to edit the Sysprep answer file, click the Open and change button in the General tab. Otherwise skip this step.
trans-unit.target: If you want to edit the Sysprep answer file, click the Open and change button in the General tab. Otherwise skip this step.

trans-unit.source: After Sysprep is complete, close the application and shutdown the Windows VM using the Windows Programs menu.
trans-unit.target: After Sysprep is complete, close the application and shutdown the Windows VM using the Windows Programs menu.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: Think about tying this back into single bundle narrative for all image creation topics.
trans-unit.target: Think about tying this back into single bundle narrative for all image creation topics.

trans-unit.source: To enable an image as an executable entity, you must bundle and upload the Windows disk image to Walrus, and then register the uploaded image with Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: To enable an image as an executable entity, you must bundle and upload the Windows disk image to Walrus, and then register the uploaded image with Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to bundle, upload, and register your Windows disk image:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to bundle, upload, and register your Windows disk image:

trans-unit.source: Your Windows image is now ready to run as an instance.
trans-unit.target: Your Windows image is now ready to run as an instance.

trans-unit.source: After you register the image, Walrus decrypts the image bundle. This process might take a few minutes for a large Windows image to be decrypted. For example, a 10G image requires that you wait about 10 minutes before you launch the instance.
trans-unit.target: After you register the image, Walrus decrypts the image bundle. This process might take a few minutes for a large Windows image to be decrypted. For example, a 10G image requires that you wait about 10 minutes before you launch the instance.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: Before you begin, make sure that KVM installed and properly functioning for the account you are going to use.
trans-unit.target: Before you begin, make sure that KVM installed and properly functioning for the account you are going to use.

trans-unit.source: To create a root filesystem to be used with Eucalyptus using KVM and an ISO image of the guest OS you want to install:
trans-unit.target: To create a root filesystem to be used with Eucalyptus using KVM and an ISO image of the guest OS you want to install:

trans-unit.source: Download the ISO image of the distro (guest OS) you want to install.
trans-unit.target: Download the ISO image of the distro (guest OS) you want to install.

trans-unit.source: Create a virtual disk with the desired size. For example, to create a 4 GiB disk:
trans-unit.target: Create a virtual disk with the desired size. For example, to create a 4 GiB disk:

trans-unit.source: Start KVM using the CDROM as the boot device and new image as the disk.
trans-unit.target: Start KVM using the CDROM as the boot device and new image as the disk.

trans-unit.source: You need to have a SCSI as a bus because Eucalyptus expects the disk to be in /dev/sda.
trans-unit.target: You need to have a SCSI as a bus because Eucalyptus expects the disk to be in /dev/sda.

trans-unit.source: Install the distro as you would normally would. Do not use lvm or md and install everything in one partition. Remember the partition in which the distro is installed.
trans-unit.target: Install the distro as you would normally would. Do not use lvm or md and install everything in one partition. Remember the partition in which the distro is installed.

trans-unit.source: Most distributions will remember the network interfaces by the MAC address, so interfaces will always be the same (that is, eth0 and eth1 will not be inverted accidentally). In Eucalyptus you have to get the distribution to forget the NIC, so that every instance will see the interface as the first interface. To do so you may want to refer to the specific distribution. For example Debian and Ubuntu use udev so check /etc/udev/rules.d/*net*. CentOS might have something in /etc/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0. Failure to do so may leave your instance without network.
trans-unit.target: Most distributions will remember the network interfaces by the MAC address, so interfaces will always be the same (that is, eth0 and eth1 will not be inverted accidentally). In Eucalyptus you have to get the distribution to forget the NIC, so that every instance will see the interface as the first interface. To do so you may want to refer to the specific distribution. For example Debian and Ubuntu use udev so check /etc/udev/rules.d/*net*. CentOS might have something in /etc/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0. Failure to do so may leave your instance without network.

trans-unit.source: Find out the starting block and the block size of the root file system.
trans-unit.target: Find out the starting block and the block size of the root file system.

trans-unit.source: Print the current partition table using p.
trans-unit.target: Print the current partition table using p.

trans-unit.source: Note the start for the partition you are interested in and the size. For this example we'll say that the start is 32256 and the size is 1024000.
trans-unit.target: Note the start for the partition you are interested in and the size. For this example we'll say that the start is 32256 and the size is 1024000.

trans-unit.source: dd if=<image_name> of=rootfs.img bs=1 skip=32256 count=1024000
trans-unit.target: dd if=<image_name> of=rootfs.img bs=1 skip=32256 count=1024000

trans-unit.source: To speed up the process, you can increase the block size. Divide the size and the skip count by the new block size (512 in this example) and you get dd if=<image_name> of=rootfs.img bs=512 skip=63 count=2000.
trans-unit.target: To speed up the process, you can increase the block size. Divide the size and the skip count by the new block size (512 in this example) and you get dd if=<image_name> of=rootfs.img bs=512 skip=63 count=2000.

trans-unit.source: You now have a root filesystem. Make sure that it is compatible with the kernel/initrd you are using in your cloud environment. In particular you may want to be sure you have the modules of the kernel you are going to use. Then you are ready to add the image to Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: You now have a root filesystem. Make sure that it is compatible with the kernel/initrd you are using in your cloud environment. In particular you may want to be sure you have the modules of the kernel you are going to use. Then you are ready to add the image to Eucalyptus.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you perform this task on an NC (or the host running the same Linux distributions and hypervisors as the NC). If you are creating the Windows image on a machine currently running the NC, terminate all running instances and stop the NC. To stop the NC, enter:
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you perform this task on an NC (or the host running the same Linux distributions and hypervisors as the NC). If you are creating the Windows image on a machine currently running the NC, terminate all running instances and stop the NC. To stop the NC, enter:

trans-unit.source: Included with the installation are template files that closely match those that Eucalyptus will generate at VM instantiation time. The file for KVM (libvirt-xen-windows-example.xml) is located at /usr/share/eucalyptus/doc/. We recommend that you review this file to acquaint yourself with its contents, noting required files, bridges, and resources. For more information about configuring the libvirt.xml file, go to the Domain XML format page in the libvirt documentation.
trans-unit.target: Included with the installation are template files that closely match those that Eucalyptus will generate at VM instantiation time. The file for KVM (libvirt-xen-windows-example.xml) is located at /usr/share/eucalyptus/doc/. We recommend that you review this file to acquaint yourself with its contents, noting required files, bridges, and resources. For more information about configuring the libvirt.xml file, go to the Domain XML format page in the libvirt documentation.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: The first task for creating a Windows image is installing a base Windows operating system (OS). To install a base Windows OS:
trans-unit.target: The first task for creating a Windows image is installing a base Windows operating system (OS). To install a base Windows OS:

trans-unit.source: Log in to the stopped NC server or a host that runs the same hypervisor as the NCs.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the stopped NC server or a host that runs the same hypervisor as the NCs.

trans-unit.source: Create a blank disk file. Specify your Windows VM image name using the parameter of.
trans-unit.target: Create a blank disk file. Specify your Windows VM image name using the parameter of.

trans-unit.source: dd if=/dev/zero of=windows.<image_name>.img bs=1M count=1 seek=16999
trans-unit.target: dd if=/dev/zero of=windows.<image_name>.img bs=1M count=1 seek=16999

trans-unit.source: Your image name must start with the word, windows (all lower-case).
trans-unit.target: Your image name must start with the word, windows (all lower-case).

trans-unit.source: Create a floppy and secondary blank disk to be attached to the image later, in order to test paravirtualization drivers
trans-unit.target: Create a floppy and secondary blank disk to be attached to the image later, in order to test paravirtualization drivers

trans-unit.source: dd if=/dev/zero of=floppy.img \ bs=1k count=1474 dd if=/dev/zero of=secondary.img \ bs=1M count=1 seek=1000
trans-unit.target: dd if=/dev/zero of=floppy.img \ bs=1k count=1474 dd if=/dev/zero of=secondary.img \ bs=1M count=1 seek=1000

trans-unit.source: Make available the .iso file that contains your Windows installation CD/DVD, then copy the .iso file to your working directory (/usr/share/eucalyptus/doc/).
trans-unit.target: Make available the .iso file that contains your Windows installation CD/DVD, then copy the .iso file to your working directory (/usr/share/eucalyptus/doc/).

trans-unit.source: Copy the libvirt-kvm-windows-example.xml file to your working directory and rename it to libvirt-kvm-windows.xml.
trans-unit.target: Copy the libvirt-kvm-windows-example.xml file to your working directory and rename it to libvirt-kvm-windows.xml.

trans-unit.source: Open the new libvirt-kvm-windows.xml file and provide fully qualified paths to the VM image file and iso. Make sure that the name of the bridge is the same as the one used by the hypervisor on which you are creating the Windows image.
trans-unit.target: Open the new libvirt-kvm-windows.xml file and provide fully qualified paths to the VM image file and iso. Make sure that the name of the bridge is the same as the one used by the hypervisor on which you are creating the Windows image.

trans-unit.source: Your file should look similar to this example:
trans-unit.target: Your file should look similar to this example:

trans-unit.source: <domain type='kvm'> <name>eucalyptus-windows</name> <os> <type>hvm</type> <boot dev='cdrom'/> </os> <features> <acpi/> </features> <memory>524288</memory> <vcpu>1</vcpu> <devices> <emulator>/usr/bin/kvm</emulator> <disk type='file'> <source file='/root/windows_2003.img'/> <target dev='hda'/> </disk> <!-- <disk type='file' device='disk'> <source file='fully_qualified_path_to_secondary_disk'/> <target dev='vda' bus='virtio'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='floppy'> <source file='fully_qualified_path_to_floppy_disk'/> <target dev='fda'/> </disk> --> <disk type='file' device='cdrom'> <source file='/root/en_win_srv_2003_r2_enterprise_with_sp2_cd1_x13-05460.iso'/> <target dev='hdc'/> <readonly/> </disk> <interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='br0'/> <model type='rtl8139'/> </interface> <!--<interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='br0'/> <model type='virtio'/> </interface> --> <graphics type='vnc' port='-1' autoport='yes' listen='0.0.0.0'/> </devices> </domain>
trans-unit.target: <domain type='kvm'> <name>eucalyptus-windows</name> <os> <type>hvm</type> <boot dev='cdrom'/> </os> <features> <acpi/> </features> <memory>524288</memory> <vcpu>1</vcpu> <devices> <emulator>/usr/bin/kvm</emulator> <disk type='file'> <source file='/root/windows_2003.img'/> <target dev='hda'/> </disk> <!-- <disk type='file' device='disk'> <source file='fully_qualified_path_to_secondary_disk'/> <target dev='vda' bus='virtio'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='floppy'> <source file='fully_qualified_path_to_floppy_disk'/> <target dev='fda'/> </disk> --> <disk type='file' device='cdrom'> <source file='/root/en_win_srv_2003_r2_enterprise_with_sp2_cd1_x13-05460.iso'/> <target dev='hdc'/> <readonly/> </disk> <interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='br0'/> <model type='rtl8139'/> </interface> <!--<interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='br0'/> <model type='virtio'/> </interface> --> <graphics type='vnc' port='-1' autoport='yes' listen='0.0.0.0'/> </devices> </domain>

trans-unit.source: Connect to the virtual console using the VNC client of your choice. On the NC, check the display number that has been allocated by looking at the process table (ps axw | grep vnc). For example, if the display number is 0, then connect to the NC using the VNC client:
trans-unit.target: Connect to the virtual console using the VNC client of your choice. On the NC, check the display number that has been allocated by looking at the process table (ps axw | grep vnc). For example, if the display number is 0, then connect to the NC using the VNC client:

trans-unit.source: Follow the standard Windows installation procedure until the VM has completed installing Windows.
trans-unit.target: Follow the standard Windows installation procedure until the VM has completed installing Windows.

trans-unit.source: On some hosts, the VNC’s display number will change when an image restarts. Use ps to find the current number.
trans-unit.target: On some hosts, the VNC’s display number will change when an image restarts. Use ps to find the current number.

trans-unit.source: Run virsh list to display the domain name.
trans-unit.target: Run virsh list to display the domain name.

trans-unit.source: Shut down the Windows VM you have just created. The easiest way to shutdown your VM is to use the virsh destroy command, as shown:
trans-unit.target: Shut down the Windows VM you have just created. The easiest way to shutdown your VM is to use the virsh destroy command, as shown:

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

xmrk:image.alt: Eucalyptus Windows Integrator select hypervisor window

trans-unit.source: Use yum or apt-get to download the Eucalyptus tool.
trans-unit.target: Use yum or apt-get to download the Eucalyptus tool.

trans-unit.source: yum install eucalyptus-windows-tools apt-get install eucalyptus-windows-tools
trans-unit.target: yum install eucalyptus-windows-tools apt-get install eucalyptus-windows-tools

trans-unit.source: Copy /usr/share/eucalyptus/eucawin.iso to the working directory of your NC.
trans-unit.target: Copy /usr/share/eucalyptus/eucawin.iso to the working directory of your NC.

trans-unit.source: Open the libvirt-kvm-windows-example.xml file and make the following edits:
trans-unit.target: Open the libvirt-kvm-windows-example.xml file and make the following edits:

trans-unit.source: Comment out the lines of XML code directing KVM to boot the Windows image from the CDROM.
trans-unit.target: Comment out the lines of XML code directing KVM to boot the Windows image from the CDROM.

trans-unit.source: Change the text so that eucawin.iso replaces the Windows .iso image and is mounted as cdrom.
trans-unit.target: Change the text so that eucawin.iso replaces the Windows .iso image and is mounted as cdrom.

trans-unit.source: Enter the path to the secondary disk file you created in the previous task.
trans-unit.target: Enter the path to the secondary disk file you created in the previous task.

trans-unit.source: Uncomment the lines that direct attachment of a floppy disk, secondary disk, and secondary network interface.
trans-unit.target: Uncomment the lines that direct attachment of a floppy disk, secondary disk, and secondary network interface.

trans-unit.source: Your finished file should look similar to the following example:
trans-unit.target: Your finished file should look similar to the following example:

trans-unit.source: <domain type="kvm"> <name>eucalyptus-windows</name> <os> <type>hvm</type> <!-- <boot dev='cdrom'/> --> </os> <features> <acpi/> </features> <memory>524288</memory> <vcpu>1</vcpu> <devices> <emulator>/usr/bin/kvm</emulator> <disk type='file'> <source file='/root/windows_2003.img'/> <target dev='hda'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='disk'> <source file='/root/secondary.img'/> <target dev='vda' bus='virtio'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='floppy'> <source file='/root/floppy.img'/> <target dev='fda'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='cdrom'> <source file='eucawin.iso'/> <target dev='hdc'/> <readonly/> </disk> <interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='br0'/> <model type='rtl8139'/> </interface> <interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='br0'/> <model type='virtio'/> </interface> <graphics type='vnc' port='-1' autoport='yes' listen='0.0.0.0'/> </devices> </domain>
trans-unit.target: <domain type="kvm"> <name>eucalyptus-windows</name> <os> <type>hvm</type> <!-- <boot dev='cdrom'/> --> </os> <features> <acpi/> </features> <memory>524288</memory> <vcpu>1</vcpu> <devices> <emulator>/usr/bin/kvm</emulator> <disk type='file'> <source file='/root/windows_2003.img'/> <target dev='hda'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='disk'> <source file='/root/secondary.img'/> <target dev='vda' bus='virtio'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='floppy'> <source file='/root/floppy.img'/> <target dev='fda'/> </disk> <disk type='file' device='cdrom'> <source file='eucawin.iso'/> <target dev='hdc'/> <readonly/> </disk> <interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='br0'/> <model type='rtl8139'/> </interface> <interface type='bridge'> <source bridge='br0'/> <model type='virtio'/> </interface> <graphics type='vnc' port='-1' autoport='yes' listen='0.0.0.0'/> </devices> </domain>

trans-unit.source: Log in to Windows and find the Eucalyptus installation files in the CDROM drive.
trans-unit.target: Log in to Windows and find the Eucalyptus installation files in the CDROM drive.

trans-unit.source: For Windows Server 2003 R2, run setup.exe.
trans-unit.target: For Windows Server 2003 R2, run setup.exe.

trans-unit.source: For all others, run EucalyptusWindowsIntegration.msi. (setup.exe will automatically install .NET framework 2.0, which is not bundled in Server 2003 R2).
trans-unit.target: For all others, run EucalyptusWindowsIntegration.msi. (setup.exe will automatically install .NET framework 2.0, which is not bundled in Server 2003 R2).

trans-unit.source: In the Choose your hypervisor step, click KVM and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: In the Choose your hypervisor step, click KVM and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: Should this be a separate section, like Active Directory and Remote Desktop? Scot: maybe combine all into one process file of separate tasks.
trans-unit.target: Should this be a separate section, like Active Directory and Remote Desktop? Scot: maybe combine all into one process file of separate tasks.

trans-unit.source: During the installation of KVM VirtIO drivers, warning messages might appear asking to confirm the driver installation. Click Continue in all cases.
trans-unit.target: During the installation of KVM VirtIO drivers, warning messages might appear asking to confirm the driver installation. Click Continue in all cases.

trans-unit.source: At the Welcome to the Found New Hardware Wizard, click Next.
trans-unit.target: At the Welcome to the Found New Hardware Wizard, click Next.

trans-unit.source: Choose Install Software Automatically… and click Next.
trans-unit.target: Choose Install Software Automatically… and click Next.

trans-unit.source: Open the Windows device manager and check that the following drivers are found for each device:
trans-unit.target: Open the Windows device manager and check that the following drivers are found for each device:

trans-unit.source: Disk drivers: Red Hat VirtIO SCSI Disk Device
trans-unit.target: Disk drivers: Red Hat VirtIO SCSI Disk Device

trans-unit.source: SCSI and RAID controllers: Red Hat VirtIO SCSI controller
trans-unit.target: SCSI and RAID controllers: Red Hat VirtIO SCSI controller

trans-unit.source: Network adapters: Red Hat VirtIO Ethernet Adapter
trans-unit.target: Network adapters: Red Hat VirtIO Ethernet Adapter

trans-unit.source:
If the correct drivers are not found, question marks display on the devices.
Right-click on the devices in question and run update drivers. The new hardware wizard displays.
When the new hardware wizard asks if Windows update is to be connected, click No, not this time. Choose Install software automatically (recommended). If a confirmation popup message displays, click Continue.
trans-unit.target:
If the correct drivers are not found, question marks display on the devices.
Right-click on the devices in question and run update drivers. The new hardware wizard displays.
When the new hardware wizard asks if Windows update is to be connected, click No, not this time. Choose Install software automatically (recommended). If a confirmation popup message displays, click Continue.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: The Eucalyptus Integration service lets an enterprise with existing Active Directory domains attach Windows instances to the domains and control access to these instances using the existing AD user database. Users can log into the instance either using their domain credentials or the Administrator’s password generated with the euca-get-password command.
trans-unit.target: The Eucalyptus Integration service lets an enterprise with existing Active Directory domains attach Windows instances to the domains and control access to these instances using the existing AD user database. Users can log into the instance either using their domain credentials or the Administrator’s password generated with the euca-get-password command.

trans-unit.source: Because AD technology is tightly integrated with domain name service (DNS), the default name server contacted by the instance must be able to resolve the AD address as a proper domain controller. You can do this for all networking modes except System, by configuring the following line the CC’s eucalyptus.conf file:
trans-unit.target: Because AD technology is tightly integrated with domain name service (DNS), the default name server contacted by the instance must be able to resolve the AD address as a proper domain controller. You can do this for all networking modes except System, by configuring the following line the CC’s eucalyptus.conf file:

trans-unit.source: If there is no such pre-existing DNS set-up or your networking mode is System, you might need to change the VM’s network interface so that the preferred DNS server points to the domain controller.
trans-unit.target: If there is no such pre-existing DNS set-up or your networking mode is System, you might need to change the VM’s network interface so that the preferred DNS server points to the domain controller.

trans-unit.source: Click Windows Programs Eucalyptus Eucalyptus Setup .
trans-unit.target: Click Windows Programs Eucalyptus Eucalyptus Setup .

trans-unit.source: The Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup displays.
trans-unit.target: The Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup displays.

trans-unit.source: Click the Active Directory tab in the Eucalyptus Windows Integration window and enter the following information:
trans-unit.target: Click the Active Directory tab in the Eucalyptus Windows Integration window and enter the following information:

trans-unit.source: Enter the address of the existing Active Directory domain controller in the AD Address field.
trans-unit.target: Enter the address of the existing Active Directory domain controller in the AD Address field.

trans-unit.source: Enter the administrator username in the Admin Username field. We recommend using a generic user account that has permission to join a computer to a domain or a specific organizational unit.
trans-unit.target: Enter the administrator username in the Admin Username field. We recommend using a generic user account that has permission to join a computer to a domain or a specific organizational unit.

trans-unit.source: Enter and confirm the password in the Admin Password field. Note that the Admin username and password are required to join an instance to an Active Directory. When launched in Eucalyptus, these properties will be deleted as soon as the instance joins (or fails to join) the domain.
trans-unit.target: Enter and confirm the password in the Admin Password field. Note that the Admin username and password are required to join an instance to an Active Directory. When launched in Eucalyptus, these properties will be deleted as soon as the instance joins (or fails to join) the domain.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, enter an organizational unit in the Organizational Unit field. This specifies a container that the instances launched from this image will be attach to.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, enter an organizational unit in the Organizational Unit field. This specifies a container that the instances launched from this image will be attach to.

trans-unit.source: If the values entered in this section are incorrect, the launched instances will fail to join the domain. We recommend that you verify the information by manually joining a computer to a domain using the same information that you entered in this step. You may first log in the launched instance using administrator password (euca-get-passcword) and manually join the domain for verification.
trans-unit.target: If the values entered in this section are incorrect, the launched instances will fail to join the domain. We recommend that you verify the information by manually joining a computer to a domain using the same information that you entered in this step. You may first log in the launched instance using administrator password (euca-get-passcword) and manually join the domain for verification.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: Domain users or groups require remote desktop permission to log into an instance. By default, only the local administrator has the remote desktop permission. The Eucalyptus Integration Service provides a way to grant remote desktop permission to additional domain users or groups.
trans-unit.target: Domain users or groups require remote desktop permission to log into an instance. By default, only the local administrator has the remote desktop permission. The Eucalyptus Integration Service provides a way to grant remote desktop permission to additional domain users or groups.

trans-unit.source: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus Eucalyptus Setup ).
trans-unit.target: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus Eucalyptus Setup ).

trans-unit.source: The names of authorized domain users and groups display in the Authorized User/Groups field. By default, only the local administrator is listed as authorized.
trans-unit.target: The names of authorized domain users and groups display in the Authorized User/Groups field. By default, only the local administrator is listed as authorized.

trans-unit.source: In the text field below the list, enter a user and group account name in the format [DOMAIN]\[USER or GROUP]. If you add a new local user or local group, prepend the account name localhost\ instead of the domain name.
trans-unit.target: In the text field below the list, enter a user and group account name in the format [DOMAIN]\[USER or GROUP]. If you add a new local user or local group, prepend the account name localhost\ instead of the domain name.

trans-unit.source: Repeat for all user/groups that you want to add.
trans-unit.target: Repeat for all user/groups that you want to add.

trans-unit.source: When the instance launches, the members of the groups you added can log in to the instance through remote desktop.
trans-unit.target: When the instance launches, the members of the groups you added can log in to the instance through remote desktop.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: Sysprep is a Microsoft tool for deploying multiple Windows operating systems in an enterprise. Running Sysprep removes system-specific information such as security ID (SID) from the Windows OS before you clone an image. Sysprep then re-initializes the OS after the image is cloned and started on multiple computers. Use Sysprep to prepare images when you use Microsoft Key Management Service to activate license keys. Also, use Sysprep when your Windows systems are attached to Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Sysprep is a Microsoft tool for deploying multiple Windows operating systems in an enterprise. Running Sysprep removes system-specific information such as security ID (SID) from the Windows OS before you clone an image. Sysprep then re-initializes the OS after the image is cloned and started on multiple computers. Use Sysprep to prepare images when you use Microsoft Key Management Service to activate license keys. Also, use Sysprep when your Windows systems are attached to Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: In Eucalyptus, you can run Sysprep before you bundle images with the euca-bundle-image or euca-bundle-instance commands.
trans-unit.target: In Eucalyptus, you can run Sysprep before you bundle images with the euca-bundle-image or euca-bundle-instance commands.

trans-unit.source: The Eucalyptus Integration Service supports Sysprep for Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows 7.
trans-unit.target: The Eucalyptus Integration Service supports Sysprep for Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows 7.

trans-unit.source: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus Eucalyptus Setup ).
trans-unit.target: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus Eucalyptus Setup ).

trans-unit.source: Ensure that Format uninitialized drives is checked
trans-unit.target: Ensure that Format uninitialized drives is checked

trans-unit.source: If you want to edit the Sysprep answer file, click the Open and change button in the General tab. Otherwise skip this step.
trans-unit.target: If you want to edit the Sysprep answer file, click the Open and change button in the General tab. Otherwise skip this step.

trans-unit.source: After Sysprep is complete, close the application and shutdown the Windows VM using the Windows Programs menu.
trans-unit.target: After Sysprep is complete, close the application and shutdown the Windows VM using the Windows Programs menu.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: To enable an image as an executable entity, you must bundle and upload the Windows disk image to Walrus, and then register the uploaded image with Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: To enable an image as an executable entity, you must bundle and upload the Windows disk image to Walrus, and then register the uploaded image with Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to bundle, upload, and register your Windows disk image:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to bundle, upload, and register your Windows disk image:

trans-unit.source: Your Windows image is now ready to run as an instance.
trans-unit.target: Your Windows image is now ready to run as an instance.

trans-unit.source: After you register the image, Walrus decrypts the image bundle. This process might take a few minutes for a large Windows image to be decrypted. For example, a 10G image requires that you wait about 10 minutes before you launch the instance.
trans-unit.target: After you register the image, Walrus decrypts the image bundle. This process might take a few minutes for a large Windows image to be decrypted. For example, a 10G image requires that you wait about 10 minutes before you launch the instance.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: To create a root filesystem to be used with Eucalyptus using VMware and an ISO image of the guest OS you want to install:
trans-unit.target: To create a root filesystem to be used with Eucalyptus using VMware and an ISO image of the guest OS you want to install:

trans-unit.source: Run an instance of the image.
trans-unit.target: Run an instance of the image.

trans-unit.source: Attach a volume to the instance.
trans-unit.target: Attach a volume to the instance.

trans-unit.source: Make a file system on the volume and mount it to /mnt.
trans-unit.target: Make a file system on the volume and mount it to /mnt.

trans-unit.source: SCP your Eucalyptus credential zip file to the instance.
trans-unit.target: SCP your Eucalyptus credential zip file to the instance.

trans-unit.source: Unzip your Eucalyptus credentials zip to /mnt/euca.
trans-unit.target: Unzip your Eucalyptus credentials zip to /mnt/euca.

trans-unit.source: Install any other software you want on the instance so it will be part of your new image.
trans-unit.target: Install any other software you want on the instance so it will be part of your new image.

trans-unit.source: You now have a root filesystem. Make sure that it is compatible with the kernel/initrd you are using in your cloud environment. In particular you may want to be sure you have the modules of the kernel you are going to use. Then you are ready to add the image to Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: You now have a root filesystem. Make sure that it is compatible with the kernel/initrd you are using in your cloud environment. In particular you may want to be sure you have the modules of the kernel you are going to use. Then you are ready to add the image to Eucalyptus.

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: To create an image from a Windows OS in VMware you will need one network interface and one disk. This disk must be the first IDE disk. Follow the tasks listed in this section.
trans-unit.target: To create an image from a Windows OS in VMware you will need one network interface and one disk. This disk must be the first IDE disk. Follow the tasks listed in this section.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: To install the base Windows operating system (OS):
trans-unit.target: To install the base Windows operating system (OS):

trans-unit.source: Create a new VM using the VMware vSphere Client following the standard VMware procedures.
trans-unit.target: Create a new VM using the VMware vSphere Client following the standard VMware procedures.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that the Windows VM uses the LSI Logic Parallel driver as the SCSI controller. For some Windows versions, it is not the default SCSI controller in the VM setting.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that the Windows VM uses the LSI Logic Parallel driver as the SCSI controller. For some Windows versions, it is not the default SCSI controller in the VM setting.

trans-unit.source: Install the Windows OS following standard VMware procedures.
trans-unit.target: Install the Windows OS following standard VMware procedures.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

xmrk:image.alt: Eucalyptus Windows Integrator select hypervisor window

trans-unit.source: To install the Eucalyptus Windows Integration Service:
trans-unit.target: To install the Eucalyptus Windows Integration Service:

trans-unit.source: Use yum or apt-get to download the Eucalyptus tool.
trans-unit.target: Use yum or apt-get to download the Eucalyptus tool.

trans-unit.source: yum install eucalyptus-windows-tools apt-get install eucalyptus-windows-tools
trans-unit.target: yum install eucalyptus-windows-tools apt-get install eucalyptus-windows-tools

trans-unit.source: Copy $EUCALYPTUS/usr/share/eucalyptus/eucawin.iso to the Windows host that runs vSphere client. You might need SFTP client on the Windows host.
trans-unit.target: Copy $EUCALYPTUS/usr/share/eucalyptus/eucawin.iso to the Windows host that runs vSphere client. You might need SFTP client on the Windows host.

trans-unit.source: Use the VMware vSphere client to upload the ISO file to the VSphere datastore.
trans-unit.target: Use the VMware vSphere client to upload the ISO file to the VSphere datastore.

trans-unit.source: Attach the eucawin.iso to the Windows VM.
trans-unit.target: Attach the eucawin.iso to the Windows VM.

trans-unit.source: Log in to Windows and find the Eucalyptus installation files in the CDROM drive.
trans-unit.target: Log in to Windows and find the Eucalyptus installation files in the CDROM drive.

trans-unit.source: For Windows Server 2003 R2, run setup.exe. This automatically installs the .NET framework 2.0, which is not bundled in Server 2003 R2.
trans-unit.target: For Windows Server 2003 R2, run setup.exe. This automatically installs the .NET framework 2.0, which is not bundled in Server 2003 R2.

trans-unit.source: For all other versions, run EucalyptusWindowsIntegration.msi.
trans-unit.target: For all other versions, run EucalyptusWindowsIntegration.msi.

trans-unit.source: In the Choose your hypervisor step, click VMWARE.
trans-unit.target: In the Choose your hypervisor step, click VMWARE.

trans-unit.source: Should this be a separate section, like Active Directory and Remote Desktop? Scot: maybe combine all into one process file of separate tasks.
trans-unit.target: Should this be a separate section, like Active Directory and Remote Desktop? Scot: maybe combine all into one process file of separate tasks.

trans-unit.source: Click Next and continue until the end of installation.
trans-unit.target: Click Next and continue until the end of installation.

trans-unit.target: Enter and confirm the password in the Admin Password field. Note that the Admin username and password are required to join an instance to an Active Directory. When launched in Eucalyptus, these properties will be deleted as soon as the instance joins (or fails to join) the domain.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, enter an organizational unit in the Organizational Unit field. This specifies a container that the instances launched from this image will be attach to.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, enter an organizational unit in the Organizational Unit field. This specifies a container that the instances launched from this image will be attach to.

trans-unit.source: If the values entered in this section are incorrect, the launched instances will fail to join the domain. We recommend that you verify the information by manually joining a computer to a domain using the same information that you entered in this step. You may first log in the launched instance using administrator password (euca-get-passcword) and manually join the domain for verification.
trans-unit.target: If the values entered in this section are incorrect, the launched instances will fail to join the domain. We recommend that you verify the information by manually joining a computer to a domain using the same information that you entered in this step. You may first log in the launched instance using administrator password (euca-get-passcword) and manually join the domain for verification.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: Domain users or groups require remote desktop permission to log into an instance. By default, only the local administrator has the remote desktop permission. The Eucalyptus Integration Service provides a way to grant remote desktop permission to additional domain users or groups.
trans-unit.target: Domain users or groups require remote desktop permission to log into an instance. By default, only the local administrator has the remote desktop permission. The Eucalyptus Integration Service provides a way to grant remote desktop permission to additional domain users or groups.

trans-unit.source: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus Eucalyptus Setup ).
trans-unit.target: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus Eucalyptus Setup ).

trans-unit.source: The names of authorized domain users and groups display in the Authorized User/Groups field. By default, only the local administrator is listed as authorized.
trans-unit.target: The names of authorized domain users and groups display in the Authorized User/Groups field. By default, only the local administrator is listed as authorized.

trans-unit.source: In the text field below the list, enter a user and group account name in the format [DOMAIN]\[USER or GROUP]. If you add a new local user or local group, prepend the account name localhost\ instead of the domain name.
trans-unit.target: In the text field below the list, enter a user and group account name in the format [DOMAIN]\[USER or GROUP]. If you add a new local user or local group, prepend the account name localhost\ instead of the domain name.

trans-unit.source: Repeat for all user/groups that you want to add.
trans-unit.target: Repeat for all user/groups that you want to add.

trans-unit.source: When the instance launches, the members of the groups you added can log in to the instance through remote desktop.
trans-unit.target: When the instance launches, the members of the groups you added can log in to the instance through remote desktop.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: Sysprep is a Microsoft tool for deploying multiple Windows operating systems in an enterprise. Running Sysprep removes system-specific information such as security ID (SID) from the Windows OS before you clone an image. Sysprep then re-initializes the OS after the image is cloned and started on multiple computers. Use Sysprep to prepare images when you use Microsoft Key Management Service to activate license keys. Also, use Sysprep when your Windows systems are attached to Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Sysprep is a Microsoft tool for deploying multiple Windows operating systems in an enterprise. Running Sysprep removes system-specific information such as security ID (SID) from the Windows OS before you clone an image. Sysprep then re-initializes the OS after the image is cloned and started on multiple computers. Use Sysprep to prepare images when you use Microsoft Key Management Service to activate license keys. Also, use Sysprep when your Windows systems are attached to Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: In Eucalyptus, you can run Sysprep before you bundle images with the euca-bundle-image or euca-bundle-instance commands.
trans-unit.target: In Eucalyptus, you can run Sysprep before you bundle images with the euca-bundle-image or euca-bundle-instance commands.

trans-unit.source: The Eucalyptus Integration Service supports Sysprep for Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows 7.
trans-unit.target: The Eucalyptus Integration Service supports Sysprep for Windows Server 2008, Windows Server 2008 R2, and Windows 7.

trans-unit.source: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus Eucalyptus Setup ).
trans-unit.target: Open the Eucalyptus Windows Integration popup ( Windows Programs Eucalyptus Eucalyptus Setup ).

trans-unit.source: Ensure that Format uninitialized drives is checked
trans-unit.target: Ensure that Format uninitialized drives is checked

trans-unit.source: If you want to edit the Sysprep answer file, click the Open and change button in the General tab. Otherwise skip this step.
trans-unit.target: If you want to edit the Sysprep answer file, click the Open and change button in the General tab. Otherwise skip this step.

trans-unit.source: After Sysprep is complete, close the application and shutdown the Windows VM using the Windows Programs menu.
trans-unit.target: After Sysprep is complete, close the application and shutdown the Windows VM using the Windows Programs menu.

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: Convert the VMDK to an Image
trans-unit.target: Convert the VMDK to an Image

trans-unit.source: After your Windows VM image is ready on ESX/ESX-i/VCenter, use the euca_imager command to download the image and convert it to the format Eucalyptus uses. The euca_imager command converts a remote VMDK located on a datastore into a disk image on the local disk on the CC/VMware Broker machine.
trans-unit.target: After your Windows VM image is ready on ESX/ESX-i/VCenter, use the euca_imager command to download the image and convert it to the format Eucalyptus uses. The euca_imager command converts a remote VMDK located on a datastore into a disk image on the local disk on the CC/VMware Broker machine.

trans-unit.source: Log into the CC/VMware Broker machine and, if necessary, set the appropriate environment variables.
trans-unit.target: Log into the CC/VMware Broker machine and, if necessary, set the appropriate environment variables.

trans-unit.source: # export VDDK_HOME=/opt/packages/vddk/ # export EUCALYPTUS=/ # export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/packages/vddk/lib/vmware-vix-disklib/lib64/ # PATH=/usr/lib/eucalyptus/:$PATH # cd ~/.euca (or path to .eucarc) # source .eucarc
trans-unit.target: # export VDDK_HOME=/opt/packages/vddk/ # export EUCALYPTUS=/ # export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/packages/vddk/lib/vmware-vix-disklib/lib64/ # PATH=/usr/lib/eucalyptus/:$PATH # cd ~/.euca (or path to .eucarc) # source .eucarc

trans-unit.source: Enter the euca_imager command with appropriate parameters to extract and convert the VMDK to a raw disk image. Parameters are described in the following table:Verify these params and descriptions.
trans-unit.target: Enter the euca_imager command with appropriate parameters to extract and convert the VMDK to a raw disk image. Parameters are described in the following table:Verify these params and descriptions.

trans-unit.source: https URL for the vCenter Server or ESX/ESXi machine
trans-unit.target: https URL for the vCenter Server or ESX/ESXi machine

trans-unit.source: Name used to access the VMware machine
trans-unit.target: Name used to access the VMware machine

trans-unit.source: Password used to access the VMware machine
trans-unit.target: Password used to access the VMware machine

trans-unit.source: Go to vSphere client, find the virtual machine that you have installed (make sure it is in powered off state), and select the Hard disk 1 resource. There will be a Disk File field for the VMDK, and a similar field on the Option tab for the VMX file.
trans-unit.target: Go to vSphere client, find the virtual machine that you have installed (make sure it is in powered off state), and select the Hard disk 1 resource. There will be a Disk File field for the VMDK, and a similar field on the Option tab for the VMX file.

trans-unit.source: Same description as vsphere-vmdk parameter. This is optional if you’re contacting an ESX node directly, but may be required when contacting vCenter.
trans-unit.target: Same description as vsphere-vmdk parameter. This is optional if you’re contacting an ESX node directly, but may be required when contacting vCenter.

trans-unit.source: Specified name of the datacenter. This is optional if you’re contacting an ESX node directly, but may be required when contacting vCenter.
trans-unit.target: Specified name of the datacenter. This is optional if you’re contacting an ESX node directly, but may be required when contacting vCenter.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows euca_imager with the appropriate parameters as described above converting a VMDK to a raw disk image. Note that the prefix of the out parameter must begin with the word windows.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows euca_imager with the appropriate parameters as described above converting a VMDK to a raw disk image. Note that the prefix of the out parameter must begin with the word windows.

trans-unit.source: /usr/lib/eucalyptus/euca_imager debug=yes convert in= https://192.168.7.198 out=windows.disk login=Administrator password=password vsphere-vmdk="[datastore1]WindowsVM/WindowsVM.vmdk" vsphere-datacenter=DataCenter1 vsphere-vmx="[datastore1]WindowsVM/WindowsVM.vmx
trans-unit.target: /usr/lib/eucalyptus/euca_imager debug=yes convert in= https://192.168.7.198 out=windows.disk login=Administrator password=password vsphere-vmdk="[datastore1]WindowsVM/WindowsVM.vmdk" vsphere-datacenter=DataCenter1 vsphere-vmx="[datastore1]WindowsVM/WindowsVM.vmx

trans-unit.source: To enable an image as an executable entity, you must bundle and upload the Windows disk image to Walrus, and then register the uploaded image with Eucalyptus.
trans-unit.target: To enable an image as an executable entity, you must bundle and upload the Windows disk image to Walrus, and then register the uploaded image with Eucalyptus.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to bundle, upload, and register your Windows disk image:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to bundle, upload, and register your Windows disk image:

trans-unit.source: Your Windows image is now ready to run as an instance.
trans-unit.target: Your Windows image is now ready to run as an instance.

trans-unit.source: After you register the image, Walrus decrypts the image bundle. This process might take a few minutes for a large Windows image to be decrypted. For example, a 10G image requires that you wait about 10 minutes before you launch the instance.
trans-unit.target: After you register the image, Walrus decrypts the image bundle. This process might take a few minutes for a large Windows image to be decrypted. For example, a 10G image requires that you wait about 10 minutes before you launch the instance.

trans-unit.source: There are three ways that you can associate a kernel and ramdisk with an image.
trans-unit.target: There are three ways that you can associate a kernel and ramdisk with an image.

trans-unit.source: This only applies to Linux images. Windows images do not use kernels or ramdisks.
trans-unit.target: This only applies to Linux images. Windows images do not use kernels or ramdisks.

trans-unit.source: You can associate a specific kernel and ramdisk identifier with an image at the euca-bundle-image step.
trans-unit.target: You can associate a specific kernel and ramdisk identifier with an image at the euca-bundle-image step.

trans-unit.source: You can specific kernel and ramdisk at instance run time as an option to euca-run-instances command.
trans-unit.target: You can specific kernel and ramdisk at instance run time as an option to euca-run-instances command.

trans-unit.source: An administrator can set default registered kernel and ramdisk identifiers that will be used if a kernel and ramdisk are unspecified by either of the other options.
trans-unit.target: An administrator can set default registered kernel and ramdisk identifiers that will be used if a kernel and ramdisk are unspecified by either of the other options.

trans-unit.source: Bundle an Image for Amazon EC2
trans-unit.target: Bundle an Image for Amazon EC2

trans-unit.source: To bundle an image for use with Amazon EC2:
trans-unit.target: To bundle an image for use with Amazon EC2:

trans-unit.source: Locate the Amazon ec2 cert file that is provided as part of the EC2 AMI tools. This file is generally located in $EC2_AMITOOL_HOME/etc/ec2/amitools/cert-ec2.pem.
trans-unit.target: Locate the Amazon ec2 cert file that is provided as part of the EC2 AMI tools. This file is generally located in $EC2_AMITOOL_HOME/etc/ec2/amitools/cert-ec2.pem.

trans-unit.source: euca-bundle-image -i euca-centos-5.3 \ x86_64/centos.5-3.x86-64.img -u 123456789111 -c cert- \ abc.pem -k pk-abc.pem --ec2cert \ $EC2_AMITOOL_HOME/etc/ec2/amitools/cert-ec2.pem
trans-unit.target: euca-bundle-image -i euca-centos-5.3 \ x86_64/centos.5-3.x86-64.img -u 123456789111 -c cert- \ abc.pem -k pk-abc.pem --ec2cert \ $EC2_AMITOOL_HOME/etc/ec2/amitools/cert-ec2.pem

xmrk:task.domains: (topic task) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic task strictTaskbody-c)

trans-unit.source: The euca-bundle-instance command lets you bundle a new Windows image from a running Windows instance directly to Walrus storage. Using euca-bundle-instance is an efficient way to generate modified Windows VMs. You can spin up a Windows VM instance from an existing Windows VM image, modify it as needed, then save the modified image to Walrus storage, where it is immediately available for registering and running with the modifications already in place.
trans-unit.target: The euca-bundle-instance command lets you bundle a new Windows image from a running Windows instance directly to Walrus storage. Using euca-bundle-instance is an efficient way to generate modified Windows VMs. You can spin up a Windows VM instance from an existing Windows VM image, modify it as needed, then save the modified image to Walrus storage, where it is immediately available for registering and running with the modifications already in place.

trans-unit.source: You can query the progress of a bundling tasks using the euca-describe-bundle- task command. You can cancel the active bundle task using euca-cancel-bundle-task command.
trans-unit.target: You can query the progress of a bundling tasks using the euca-describe-bundle- task command. You can cancel the active bundle task using euca-cancel-bundle-task command.

trans-unit.source: The following example bundles a new Windows image from an existing Windows instance with ID i-12c4af6a, to the bucket mybucket, with image prefix windows2003_bundle:

trans-unit.source: Provides common management or configuration problems and solutions for fixing these problems.
trans-unit.target: Provides common management or configuration problems and solutions for fixing these problems.

trans-unit.source: To troubleshoot Eucalyptus, the administrator must know the location of the Eucalyptus components, that is, on which machine each component is installed. The administrator must have root access to each machine hosting the components and must know the network configuration connecting the components.
trans-unit.target: To troubleshoot Eucalyptus, the administrator must know the location of the Eucalyptus components, that is, on which machine each component is installed. The administrator must have root access to each machine hosting the components and must know the network configuration connecting the components.

trans-unit.source:
Include:
How to tell what state a component is in. Rich's bug re: 10% of instances not starting. drbd-overview is a nice command to use to watch the progress o
trans-unit.target:
Include:

trans-unit.source: Usually when an issue arises in Eucalyptus, you can find a clue or trace or record that suggests the nature of the problem either in the eucalyptus log files or in the system log files. Assuming Eucalyptus is installed in root (/), the eucalyptus logs are located on each machine hosting a component in the following directory: /var/log/eucalyptus/.
trans-unit.target: Usually when an issue arises in Eucalyptus, you can find a clue or trace or record that suggests the nature of the problem either in the eucalyptus log files or in the system log files. Assuming Eucalyptus is installed in root (/), the eucalyptus logs are located on each machine hosting a component in the following directory: /var/log/eucalyptus/.

trans-unit.source: Here are the relevant logs for each component:
trans-unit.target: Here are the relevant logs for each component:

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: When you have to troubleshoot, it's important to understand the elements of the network on your system. Here are some ideas for finding out information about your network:
trans-unit.target: When you have to troubleshoot, it's important to understand the elements of the network on your system. Here are some ideas for finding out information about your network:

trans-unit.source: It is also important to understand the elements of the network on your system. For example, you might want to list bridges to see which devices are enslaved by the bridge. To do this, use the brctl command.
trans-unit.target: It is also important to understand the elements of the network on your system. For example, you might want to list bridges to see which devices are enslaved by the bridge. To do this, use the brctl command.

trans-unit.source: You might also want to list network devices and evaluate existing configurations. To do this, use these commands: ip, ifconfig, and route.
trans-unit.target: You might also want to list network devices and evaluate existing configurations. To do this, use these commands: ip, ifconfig, and route.

trans-unit.source: If you are running Eucalyptus in Managed networking mode, you can also use vconfig to evaluate VLAN configuration.
trans-unit.target: If you are running Eucalyptus in Managed networking mode, you can also use vconfig to evaluate VLAN configuration.

trans-unit.source:
You can get further information if you use the euca-describe commands with the verbose options. For example, euca-describe-instances verbose returns all instances running by all users on the system. Other describe commands are:
euca-describe-volumes verbose
euca-describe-snapshots verbose
euca-describe-groups verbose
euca-describe-keypairs verbose
trans-unit.target:
You can get further information if you use the euca-describe commands with the verbose options. For example, euca-describe-instances verbose returns all instances running by all users on the system. Other describe commands are:
euca-describe-volumes verbose
euca-describe-snapshots verbose
euca-describe-groups verbose
euca-describe-keypairs verbose

trans-unit.source:
On Ubuntu 10.04 LTS, kernel version 2.6.32-31 includes a bug that prevents Walrus from decrypting images. This can be determined from the following line in cloud-output.log
javax.crypto. BadPaddingException: pad block corrupted If you are running this kernel:
Update to kernel version 2.6.32-33 or higher. De-register the failed image (euca-deregister). Re-register the bundle that you uploaded (euca-register <bucket>/<manifest>).
trans-unit.target:
On Ubuntu 10.04 LTS, kernel version 2.6.32-31 includes a bug that prevents Walrus from decrypting images. This can be determined from the following line in cloud-output.log
javax.crypto. BadPaddingException: pad block corrupted If you are running this kernel:
Update to kernel version 2.6.32-33 or higher. De-register the failed image (euca-deregister). Re-register the bundle that you uploaded (euca-register <bucket>/<manifest>).

trans-unit.source: Walrus physical disk is not large enough.
trans-unit.target: Walrus physical disk is not large enough.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you use LVM with your new disk drive(s).
trans-unit.target: Make sure you use LVM with your new disk drive(s).

trans-unit.source: Need to verify an existing LIC file.
trans-unit.target: Need to verify an existing LIC file.

trans-unit.source:
Enter the following command:
/usr/sbin/euca-describe-properties | grep ldap The output from the example above shows the name of the LIC file and status of the synchronization (set to false). PROPERTY authentication.ldap_integration_configuration { 'sync': { 'enable':'false' } }
trans-unit.target:
Enter the following command:
/usr/sbin/euca-describe-properties | grep ldap The output from the example above shows the name of the LIC file and status of the synchronization (set to false). PROPERTY authentication.ldap_integration_configuration { 'sync': { 'enable':'false' } }
