trans-unit.source: A typical size of Windows images is large and Eucalyptus has a set of properties that limit the size of various storage components. The first step in troubleshooting is to make sure that the values are large enough to store your Windows images. You can modify a property using
trans-unit.target: A typical size of Windows images is large and Eucalyptus has a set of properties that limit the size of various storage components. The first step in troubleshooting is to make sure that the values are large enough to store your Windows images. You can modify a property using

trans-unit.source: The properties that might affect registering Windows images are:
trans-unit.target: The properties that might affect registering Windows images are:

trans-unit.source: walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb: max bucket size enforced by Walrus; should be larger than a Windows image
trans-unit.target: walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb: max bucket size enforced by Walrus; should be larger than a Windows image

trans-unit.source: walrus.storagemaxcachesizeinmb: total size of all images that is cached in Walrus; should be larger than the sum of all images (Windows/Linux) in Walrus
trans-unit.target: walrus.storagemaxcachesizeinmb: total size of all images that is cached in Walrus; should be larger than the sum of all images (Windows/Linux) in Walrus

trans-unit.source: walrus.storagemaxtotalsnapshotsizeingb: if a Windows image is a type of EBS-backed EMI, this should be large enough to store all EBS backed images
trans-unit.target: walrus.storagemaxtotalsnapshotsizeingb: if a Windows image is a type of EBS-backed EMI, this should be large enough to store all EBS backed images

trans-unit.source: {PARTITION}.storage.maxvolumesizeingb: if a Windows image is a type of EBS-backed EMI, this should be large enough to store the image
trans-unit.target: {PARTITION}.storage.maxvolumesizeingb: if a Windows image is a type of EBS-backed EMI, this should be large enough to store the image

trans-unit.source: In addition, during the euca-run-instances, the CLC may time-out an instance while a large windows image (images in both Walrus and EBS) is being launched. We recommend that you rais the values of the following properties.
trans-unit.target: In addition, during the euca-run-instances, the CLC may time-out an instance while a large windows image (images in both Walrus and EBS) is being launched. We recommend that you rais the values of the following properties.

trans-unit.source: cloud.vmstate.instance_timeout: maximum wait time, in minutes, before the instance becomes running. Am instance cannot stay in pending longer than this. Default: 60
trans-unit.target: cloud.vmstate.instance_timeout: maximum wait time, in minutes, before the instance becomes running. Am instance cannot stay in pending longer than this. Default: 60

trans-unit.source: cloud.vmstate.ebs_volume_creation_timeout: maximum wait time, in minutes, before a volume backing a boot from EBS image is created. Default: 30
trans-unit.target: cloud.vmstate.ebs_volume_creation_timeout: maximum wait time, in minutes, before a volume backing a boot from EBS image is created. Default: 30

trans-unit.source: cloud.addresses.maxkillorphans: The public IP assigned to an instance will be expired after the time limit. The exact time-out is {maxkillorphans*5} seconds (by default it's 50 seconds). If the volume backing an EBS image is not created in time, the public IP will be released from the instance.
trans-unit.target: cloud.addresses.maxkillorphans: The public IP assigned to an instance will be expired after the time limit. The exact time-out is {maxkillorphans*5} seconds (by default it's 50 seconds). If the volume backing an EBS image is not created in time, the public IP will be released from the instance.

trans-unit.source: The time to bundle an image is proportional to the image size. Because the typical size of Windows image is big, give enough time until bundling is complete. As a rule of thumb, it may take up to 20 min. for bundling a 10 GB Windows image.
trans-unit.target: The time to bundle an image is proportional to the image size. Because the typical size of Windows image is big, give enough time until bundling is complete. As a rule of thumb, it may take up to 20 min. for bundling a 10 GB Windows image.

trans-unit.source: Make sure ‘walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb’ is large enough. If not, ask your administrator.
trans-unit.target: Make sure ‘walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb’ is large enough. If not, ask your administrator.

trans-unit.source: Typically, it takes longer to launch Windows images than Linux images as the delay is proportional to the image size. This can be especially long when the image is seeded on NCs the first time (images are cached in NCs and run within few seconds thereafter). As a rule of thumb, 10 GB Windows images may take up to 10 minutes to become ‘running’ when it is not cached in NCs.
trans-unit.target: Typically, it takes longer to launch Windows images than Linux images as the delay is proportional to the image size. This can be especially long when the image is seeded on NCs the first time (images are cached in NCs and run within few seconds thereafter). As a rule of thumb, 10 GB Windows images may take up to 10 minutes to become ‘running’ when it is not cached in NCs.

trans-unit.source: Instance stay in pending and goes to shutdown
trans-unit.target: Instance stay in pending and goes to shutdown

trans-unit.source: An instance may time-out if the Windows image is too big. Review and adjust the relevant properties.
trans-unit.target: An instance may time-out if the Windows image is too big. Review and adjust the relevant properties.

trans-unit.source: Instance is running, but not accessible using Remote Desktop.
trans-unit.target: Instance is running, but not accessible using Remote Desktop.

trans-unit.source:
after instances become running, you should wait until Windows is fully booted. If the image is sysprepped, the booting time may take up to 10 min. Also you should make sure the followings are cleared:
The port 3389 is authorized in the security group If the instance is attached to your active directory domain, the domain GPO shouldn’t block the RDP port (3389) The username should be authorized to log-in using Remote Desktop (refer to User guide: Windows integration service)
trans-unit.target:
after instances become running, you should wait until Windows is fully booted. If the image is sysprepped, the booting time may take up to 10 min. Also you should make sure the followings are cleared:
The port 3389 is authorized in the security group If the instance is attached to your active directory domain, the domain GPO shouldn’t block the RDP port (3389) The username should be authorized to log-in using Remote Desktop (refer to User guide: Windows integration service)

trans-unit.source: Finding the login username and password
trans-unit.target: Finding the login username and password

trans-unit.source: Use Administrator and the password retrieved by euca-get-password. If the instance is attached to a domain, you may use your domain username and password (make sure the username is prepended with domain name, such as YOUR_DOMAIN\Alice).
trans-unit.target: Use Administrator and the password retrieved by euca-get-password. If the instance is attached to a domain, you may use your domain username and password (make sure the username is prepended with domain name, such as YOUR_DOMAIN\Alice).

trans-unit.source: Can’t retrieve windows password using euca-get-password
trans-unit.target: Can’t retrieve windows password using euca-get-password

trans-unit.source: Make sure the platform field of your windows EMI is set to ‘windows’, not ‘linux’ (use euca-describe-images). If not, the most likely reason is that the image name does not begin with ‘windows’. You should bundle/upload/register the image with a proper name.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the platform field of your windows EMI is set to ‘windows’, not ‘linux’ (use euca-describe-images). If not, the most likely reason is that the image name does not begin with ‘windows’. You should bundle/upload/register the image with a proper name.

trans-unit.source: Instance is not attached to an Active Directory domain
trans-unit.target: Instance is not attached to an Active Directory domain

trans-unit.source: Make sure the parameters set in Windows integration service are correct. One way to verify them is to log in the instance using Administrator password and manually attach the instance to the domain (System Properties -> Computer Name) using the same parameters.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the parameters set in Windows integration service are correct. One way to verify them is to log in the instance using Administrator password and manually attach the instance to the domain (System Properties -> Computer Name) using the same parameters.

trans-unit.source: Make sure VNET_DNS in eucalyptus.conf is set to the domain controller (refer to User Guide: Configure Active Directory).
trans-unit.target: Make sure VNET_DNS in eucalyptus.conf is set to the domain controller (refer to User Guide: Configure Active Directory).

trans-unit.source: Ephemeral disks are not visible in the Windows
trans-unit.target: Ephemeral disks are not visible in the Windows

trans-unit.source: Open Disk Management console (All Programs->Administrative Tools->Server Manager->Storage) and find the uninitialized disks. You should create a partition on the disk and format it.
trans-unit.target: Open Disk Management console (All Programs->Administrative Tools->Server Manager->Storage) and find the uninitialized disks. You should create a partition on the disk and format it.

trans-unit.source: EBS volume is attached, but not visible in the Windows
trans-unit.target: EBS volume is attached, but not visible in the Windows

trans-unit.source: Open Disk Management console (All Programs->Administrative Tools->Server Manager->Storage) and find the uninitialized disks. You should create a partition on the disk and format it. You don’t have to repeat it when the volume is reattached later.
trans-unit.target: Open Disk Management console (All Programs->Administrative Tools->Server Manager->Storage) and find the uninitialized disks. You should create a partition on the disk and format it. You don’t have to repeat it when the volume is reattached later.

trans-unit.source: EBS volume is detached, but the disk drive (for example, E:\) is still visible in the Windows
trans-unit.target: EBS volume is detached, but the disk drive (for example, E:\) is still visible in the Windows

trans-unit.source: For KVM hypervisor, you should perform “remove hardware safely” before detaching the volume.
trans-unit.target: For KVM hypervisor, you should perform “remove hardware safely” before detaching the volume.

trans-unit.source: Make sure the bucket specified with ‘-b’ option doesn’t already exist and the property ‘walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb’ is large enough to store the image.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the bucket specified with ‘-b’ option doesn’t already exist and the property ‘walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb’ is large enough to store the image.

trans-unit.target: Inaccurate IP addresses display in the output of euca-describe-addresses.

trans-unit.source: This can occur if you add IPs from the wrong subnet into your public IP pool, do a cleanrestart on the CC, swap out the wrong ones for the right ones, and do another clean restart on the CC. To resolve this issue, run the following:
trans-unit.target: This can occur if you add IPs from the wrong subnet into your public IP pool, do a cleanrestart on the CC, swap out the wrong ones for the right ones, and do another clean restart on the CC. To resolve this issue, run the following:

xmrk:concept.domains: (topic concept) (topic hi-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d)

trans-unit.source: In these examples, we will assume that Walrus WS00 is the primary and WS01 is the secondary Walrus server.
trans-unit.target: In these examples, we will assume that Walrus WS00 is the primary and WS01 is the secondary Walrus server.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, WS01 refuses to go to DISABLED state. DRBD complains that it is in split brain mode. drbdadm cstate r0 shows that DRBD is in WFConnection state.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, WS01 refuses to go to DISABLED state. DRBD complains that it is in split brain mode. drbdadm cstate r0 shows that DRBD is in WFConnection state.

trans-unit.source: If you are sure that data on WS01 is out of date and can be discarded, execute the following commands to restore HA mode.
trans-unit.target: If you are sure that data on WS01 is out of date and can be discarded, execute the following commands to restore HA mode.

trans-unit.source: Shut down the eucalyptus-cloud process on WS01.
trans-unit.target: Shut down the eucalyptus-cloud process on WS01.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that the DRBD connection is down by typing "drbdadm disconnect r0" on any of the two Walrus hosts.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that the DRBD connection is down by typing "drbdadm disconnect r0" on any of the two Walrus hosts.

trans-unit.source: On the primary Walrus, WS00, set drbd as the primary by executing "drbdadm primary r0"
trans-unit.target: On the primary Walrus, WS00, set drbd as the primary by executing "drbdadm primary r0"

trans-unit.source: On the secondary Walrus, WS01, execute the following command: drbdadm -- --discard-my-data connect This command will discard all data on WS01 and synchronize data from WS00.
trans-unit.target: On the secondary Walrus, WS01, execute the following command: drbdadm -- --discard-my-data connect This command will discard all data on WS01 and synchronize data from WS00.

trans-unit.source: Monitor the state of DRBD by running: watch -n 2 cat /proc/drbd
trans-unit.target: Monitor the state of DRBD by running: watch -n 2 cat /proc/drbd

trans-unit.source: When the data on WS01 is synced, start the eucalyptus-cloud process on WS01.
trans-unit.target: When the data on WS01 is synced, start the eucalyptus-cloud process on WS01.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the primary WS00 needs to be taken out of service due to a hardware failure, such as a failed disk.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the primary WS00 needs to be taken out of service due to a hardware failure, such as a failed disk.

trans-unit.source: Shut down the eucalyptus-cloud process on WS00 if it is still running.
trans-unit.target: Shut down the eucalyptus-cloud process on WS00 if it is still running.

trans-unit.source: Monitor service status by running euca-describe-services on WS01 and ensure that WS01 has taken over as the new primary (state: ENABLED).
trans-unit.target: Monitor service status by running euca-describe-services on WS01 and ensure that WS01 has taken over as the new primary (state: ENABLED).

trans-unit.source: Shut down the host running WS00.
trans-unit.target: Shut down the host running WS00.

trans-unit.source:
If the host running WS00 is to be replaced entirely or the OS reinstalled:
On the primary CLC, enter the following to deregister WS00: euca_conf --deregister-walrus --component WS00 partition <name of partition> --host <WS00 host>
After Linux has been installed on the new WS00 host and it is ready for use, please reinstall the "eucalyptus-walrus" package. Synchronize the DRBD configuration (/etc/drbd.conf and /etc/eucalyptus/drbd*) from the WS01 host. On WS00, re-configure DRBD by following the Configure DRBD section of the Installation Guide and performing the steps that are relevant to the secondary Walrus server (WS00 is the new secondary Walrus server, in this example). Re-register WS00 with a new host name if necessary. This will synchronize keys.
trans-unit.target:
If the host running WS00 is to be replaced entirely or the OS reinstalled:
On the primary CLC, enter the following to deregister WS00: euca_conf --deregister-walrus --component WS00 partition <name of partition> --host <WS00 host>
After Linux has been installed on the new WS00 host and it is ready for use, please reinstall the "eucalyptus-walrus" package. Synchronize the DRBD configuration (/etc/drbd.conf and /etc/eucalyptus/drbd*) from the WS01 host. On WS00, re-configure DRBD by following the Configure DRBD section of the Installation Guide and performing the steps that are relevant to the secondary Walrus server (WS00 is the new secondary Walrus server, in this example). Re-register WS00 with a new host name if necessary. This will synchronize keys.

trans-unit.source:
On WS00, execute the following command:
drbdadm -- --discard-my-data connect This command will discard all data on WS00 and synchronize data from WS01.
trans-unit.target:
On WS00, execute the following command:
drbdadm -- --discard-my-data connect This command will discard all data on WS00 and synchronize data from WS01.

trans-unit.source: Monitor the state of DRBD by entering: watch -n 2 cat /proc/drbd WS01 should be marked as the primary and WS00 is the new secondary. Wait until data is synchronized.
trans-unit.target: Monitor the state of DRBD by entering: watch -n 2 cat /proc/drbd WS01 should be marked as the primary and WS00 is the new secondary. Wait until data is synchronized.

trans-unit.source: When the data on WS00 is synced from WS01, start the eucalyptus-cloud process on WS00.
trans-unit.target: When the data on WS00 is synced from WS01, start the eucalyptus-cloud process on WS00.

trans-unit.source: Monitor service status by running "euca-describe-services" on the primary CLC and ensure that WS00 is DISABLED and WS01 is ENABLED.
trans-unit.target: Monitor service status by running "euca-describe-services" on the primary CLC and ensure that WS00 is DISABLED and WS01 is ENABLED.

trans-unit.source: At this point, the Walrus service is back in HA mode.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the Walrus service is back in HA mode.

trans-unit.source: A group of resources that contains a CC, an SC and, optionally, a VMware Broker.
trans-unit.target: A group of resources that contains a CC, an SC and, optionally, a VMware Broker.

trans-unit.source: An availability zone for AWS denotes a large subset of their cloud environment. Eucalyptus refines this definition to denote a subset of the cloud that shares a local area network. Each availability zone has its own cluster controller and storage controller.
trans-unit.target: An availability zone for AWS denotes a large subset of their cloud environment. Eucalyptus refines this definition to denote a subset of the cloud that shares a local area network. Each availability zone has its own cluster controller and storage controller.

trans-unit.source: A storage container that accepts objects via PUT and GET commands.
trans-unit.target: A storage container that accepts objects via PUT and GET commands.

trans-unit.source: A virtual machine image splits the image into multiple image parts to facilitate ease of uploading. It also generates an XML manifest file containing metadata referencing the image, including image parts and kernel, which is used to assemble instances of the image.
trans-unit.target: A virtual machine image splits the image into multiple image parts to facilitate ease of uploading. It also generates an XML manifest file containing metadata referencing the image, including image parts and kernel, which is used to assemble instances of the image.

trans-unit.source: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the node managers [SM1] for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers (CCs). As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the node managers [SM1] for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers (CCs). As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks and participates in the enforcement of SLAs[SM3] as directed by the CLC. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).
trans-unit.target: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks and participates in the enforcement of SLAs[SM3] as directed by the CLC. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).

trans-unit.source: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the [5] Amazon Elastic Block Storage (EBS) and is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.
trans-unit.target: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the [5] Amazon Elastic Block Storage (EBS) and is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.

trans-unit.source: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. VMware Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy VMs on VMware infrastructure elements and mediates all interactions between the Cluster Controller (CC) and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter.
trans-unit.target: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. VMware Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy VMs on VMware infrastructure elements and mediates all interactions between the Cluster Controller (CC) and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter.

trans-unit.source: Walrus allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use Walrus to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Walrus is interface compatible with Amazon’s Simple Storage Service (S3), providing a mechanism for storing and accessing virtual machine images and user data. Note that Walrus access is global to the entire Eucalyptus cloud. This means that it can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Walrus allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use Walrus to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Walrus is interface compatible with Amazon’s Simple Storage Service (S3), providing a mechanism for storing and accessing virtual machine images and user data. Note that Walrus access is global to the entire Eucalyptus cloud. This means that it can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.

trans-unit.source: A group of resources that contains a CC, an SC and, optionally, a VMware Broker.
trans-unit.target: A group of resources that contains a CC, an SC and, optionally, a VMware Broker.

trans-unit.source: An availability zone for AWS denotes a large subset of their cloud environment. Eucalyptus refines this definition to denote a subset of the cloud that shares a local area network. Each availability zone has its own cluster controller and storage controller.
trans-unit.target: An availability zone for AWS denotes a large subset of their cloud environment. Eucalyptus refines this definition to denote a subset of the cloud that shares a local area network. Each availability zone has its own cluster controller and storage controller.

trans-unit.source: A storage container that accepts objects via PUT and GET commands.
trans-unit.target: A storage container that accepts objects via PUT and GET commands.

trans-unit.source: A virtual machine image splits the image into multiple image parts to facilitate ease of uploading. It also generates an XML manifest file containing metadata referencing the image, including image parts and kernel, which is used to assemble instances of the image.
trans-unit.target: A virtual machine image splits the image into multiple image parts to facilitate ease of uploading. It also generates an XML manifest file containing metadata referencing the image, including image parts and kernel, which is used to assemble instances of the image.

trans-unit.source: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the node managers [SM1] for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers (CCs). As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the node managers [SM1] for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers (CCs). As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks and participates in the enforcement of SLAs[SM3] as directed by the CLC. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).
trans-unit.target: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks and participates in the enforcement of SLAs[SM3] as directed by the CLC. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).

trans-unit.source: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the [5] Amazon Elastic Block Storage (EBS) and is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.
trans-unit.target: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the [5] Amazon Elastic Block Storage (EBS) and is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.

trans-unit.source: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. VMware Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy VMs on VMware infrastructure elements and mediates all interactions between the Cluster Controller (CC) and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter.
trans-unit.target: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. VMware Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy VMs on VMware infrastructure elements and mediates all interactions between the Cluster Controller (CC) and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter.

Note that Walrus access is global to the entire Eucalyptus cloud. This means that it can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.

An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.

trans-unit.source: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. VMware Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy VMs on VMware infrastructure elements and mediates all interactions between the Cluster Controller (CC) and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter.
trans-unit.target: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. VMware Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy VMs on VMware infrastructure elements and mediates all interactions between the Cluster Controller (CC) and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter.

trans-unit.source: Walrus allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use Walrus to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Walrus is interface compatible with Amazon’s Simple Storage Service (S3), providing a mechanism for storing and accessing virtual machine images and user data. Note that Walrus access is global to the entire Eucalyptus cloud. This means that it can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Walrus allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use Walrus to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Walrus is interface compatible with Amazon’s Simple Storage Service (S3), providing a mechanism for storing and accessing virtual machine images and user data. Note that Walrus access is global to the entire Eucalyptus cloud. This means that it can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.

trans-unit.source: A group of resources that contains a CC, an SC and, optionally, a VMware Broker.
trans-unit.target: A group of resources that contains a CC, an SC and, optionally, a VMware Broker.

trans-unit.source: An availability zone for AWS denotes a large subset of their cloud environment. Eucalyptus refines this definition to denote a subset of the cloud that shares a local area network. Each availability zone has its own cluster controller and storage controller.
trans-unit.target: An availability zone for AWS denotes a large subset of their cloud environment. Eucalyptus refines this definition to denote a subset of the cloud that shares a local area network. Each availability zone has its own cluster controller and storage controller.

trans-unit.source: A storage container that accepts objects via PUT and GET commands.
trans-unit.target: A storage container that accepts objects via PUT and GET commands.

trans-unit.source: A virtual machine image splits the image into multiple image parts to facilitate ease of uploading. It also generates an XML manifest file containing metadata referencing the image, including image parts and kernel, which is used to assemble instances of the image.
trans-unit.target: A virtual machine image splits the image into multiple image parts to facilitate ease of uploading. It also generates an XML manifest file containing metadata referencing the image, including image parts and kernel, which is used to assemble instances of the image.

trans-unit.source: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the node managers [SM1] for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers (CCs). As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the node managers [SM1] for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers (CCs). As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks and participates in the enforcement of SLAs[SM3] as directed by the CLC. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).
trans-unit.target: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks and participates in the enforcement of SLAs[SM3] as directed by the CLC. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).

trans-unit.source: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the [5] Amazon Elastic Block Storage (EBS) and is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.

trans-unit.source: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the [5] Amazon Elastic Block Storage (EBS) and is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.
trans-unit.target: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the [5] Amazon Elastic Block Storage (EBS) and is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.

trans-unit.source: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. VMware Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy VMs on VMware infrastructure elements and mediates all interactions between the Cluster Controller (CC) and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter.
trans-unit.target: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. VMware Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy VMs on VMware infrastructure elements and mediates all interactions between the Cluster Controller (CC) and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter.

trans-unit.source: Walrus allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use Walrus to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Walrus is interface compatible with Amazon’s Simple Storage Service (S3), providing a mechanism for storing and accessing virtual machine images and user data. Note that Walrus access is global to the entire Eucalyptus cloud. This means that it can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Walrus allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use Walrus to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Walrus is interface compatible with Amazon’s Simple Storage Service (S3), providing a mechanism for storing and accessing virtual machine images and user data. Note that Walrus access is global to the entire Eucalyptus cloud. This means that it can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.

trans-unit.source: A group of resources that contains a CC, an SC and, optionally, a VMware Broker.
trans-unit.target: A group of resources that contains a CC, an SC and, optionally, a VMware Broker.

trans-unit.source: An availability zone for AWS denotes a large subset of their cloud environment. Eucalyptus refines this definition to denote a subset of the cloud that shares a local area network. Each availability zone has its own cluster controller and storage controller.
trans-unit.target: An availability zone for AWS denotes a large subset of their cloud environment. Eucalyptus refines this definition to denote a subset of the cloud that shares a local area network. Each availability zone has its own cluster controller and storage controller.

trans-unit.source: A storage container that accepts objects via PUT and GET commands.
trans-unit.target: A storage container that accepts objects via PUT and GET commands.

trans-unit.source: A virtual machine image splits the image into multiple image parts to facilitate ease of uploading. It also generates an XML manifest file containing metadata referencing the image, including image parts and kernel, which is used to assemble instances of the image.
trans-unit.target: A virtual machine image splits the image into multiple image parts to facilitate ease of uploading. It also generates an XML manifest file containing metadata referencing the image, including image parts and kernel, which is used to assemble instances of the image.

trans-unit.source: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the node managers [SM1] for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers (CCs). As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the node managers [SM1] for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers (CCs). As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks and participates in the enforcement of SLAs[SM3] as directed by the CLC. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).
trans-unit.target: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks and participates in the enforcement of SLAs[SM3] as directed by the CLC. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).

trans-unit.source: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.

It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.

An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.

All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).

trans-unit.source: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.
trans-unit.target: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the [5] Amazon Elastic Block Storage (EBS) and is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.
trans-unit.target: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the [5] Amazon Elastic Block Storage (EBS) and is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.

trans-unit.source: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. VMware Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy VMs on VMware infrastructure elements and mediates all interactions between the Cluster Controller (CC) and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter.
trans-unit.target: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. VMware Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy VMs on VMware infrastructure elements and mediates all interactions between the Cluster Controller (CC) and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter.

trans-unit.source: Walrus allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use Walrus to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Walrus is interface compatible with Amazon’s Simple Storage Service (S3), providing a mechanism for storing and accessing virtual machine images and user data. Note that Walrus access is global to the entire Eucalyptus cloud. This means that it can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Walrus allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use Walrus to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Walrus is interface compatible with Amazon’s Simple Storage Service (S3), providing a mechanism for storing and accessing virtual machine images and user data. Note that Walrus access is global to the entire Eucalyptus cloud. This means that it can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.

trans-unit.source: A group of resources that contains a CC, an SC and, optionally, a VMware Broker.
trans-unit.target: A group of resources that contains a CC, an SC and, optionally, a VMware Broker.

trans-unit.source: An availability zone for AWS denotes a large subset of their cloud environment. Eucalyptus refines this definition to denote a subset of the cloud that shares a local area network. Each availability zone has its own cluster controller and storage controller.
trans-unit.target: An availability zone for AWS denotes a large subset of their cloud environment. Eucalyptus refines this definition to denote a subset of the cloud that shares a local area network. Each availability zone has its own cluster controller and storage controller.

trans-unit.source: A storage container that accepts objects via PUT and GET commands.
trans-unit.target: A storage container that accepts objects via PUT and GET commands.

trans-unit.source: A virtual machine image splits the image into multiple image parts to facilitate ease of uploading. It also generates an XML manifest file containing metadata referencing the image, including image parts and kernel, which is used to assemble instances of the image.
trans-unit.target: A virtual machine image splits the image into multiple image parts to facilitate ease of uploading. It also generates an XML manifest file containing metadata referencing the image, including image parts and kernel, which is used to assemble instances of the image.

trans-unit.source: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the node managers [SM1] for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers (CCs). As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.
trans-unit.target: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the node managers [SM1] for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers (CCs). As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks and participates in the enforcement of SLAs[SM3] as directed by the CLC. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).
trans-unit.target: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks and participates in the enforcement of SLAs[SM3] as directed by the CLC. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).

The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.

trans-unit.target: The Cloud Controller (CLC) is the entry-point into the cloud for administrators, developers, project managers, and end-users. The CLC queries the node managers [SM1] for information about resources, makes high-level scheduling decisions, and makes requests to the Cluster Controllers (CCs). As the interface to the management platform, the CLC is responsible for exposing and managing the underlying virtualized resources (servers, network, and storage). You can access the CLC through Amazon’s Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) and through a web-based Dashboard.

trans-unit.source: The Cluster Controller (CC) generally executes on a machine that has network connectivity to both the machines running the Node Controller (NC) and to the machine running the CLC. CCs gather information about a set of node machines and schedules virtual machine (VM) execution on specific nodes. The CC also manages the virtual machine networks and participates in the enforcement of SLAs[SM3] as directed by the CLC. All nodes associated with a single CC must be in the same broadcast domain (Ethernet).

trans-unit.source: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: A ramdisk contains drivers that direct the kernel to launch appropriate system files when instantiating a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The Node Controller (NC) executes on any machine that hosts VM instances. The NC controls VM activities, including the execution, inspection, and termination of VM instances. It also fetches and maintains a local cache of instance images, and it queries and controls the system software (host OS and the hypervisor) in response to queries and control requests from the CC. The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.

The NC is also responsible for the management of the virtual network endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The Storage Controller (SC) provides functionality similar to the [5] Amazon Elastic Block Storage (EBS) and is capable of interfacing with various storage systems (NFS, iSCSI, SAN devices, etc.). Elastic block storage exports storage volumes that can be attached by a VM and mounted or accessed as a raw block device. EBS volumes persist past VM termination and are commonly used to store persistent data. An EBS volume cannot be shared between VMs and can only be accessed within the same availability zone in which the VM is running. Users can create snapshots from EBS volumes. Snapshots are stored in Walrus and made available across availability zones. Eucalyptus with SAN support lets you use your enterprise-grade SAN devices to host EBS storage within a Eucalyptus cloud.

trans-unit.source: VMware Broker (Broker) is an optional Eucalyptus component activated only in versions of Eucalyptus with VMware support. VMware Broker enables Eucalyptus to deploy VMs on VMware infrastructure elements and mediates all interactions between the Cluster Controller (CC) and VMware hypervisors (ESX/ESXi) either directly or through VMware vCenter.

trans-unit.source: Walrus allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use Walrus to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Walrus is interface compatible with Amazon’s Simple Storage Service (S3), providing a mechanism for storing and accessing virtual machine images and user data. Note that Walrus access is global to the entire Eucalyptus cloud. This means that it can be accessed by end-users, whether the user is running a client from outside the cloud or from a virtual machine instance running inside the cloud.
